title: Dillon v. Frazer
description: In this case, arising out of an auto accident, the Court affirmed the trial court's refusal to apply Ontario law, reversed the trial judge's ruling refusing to grant a new trial absolute as to damages, and remanded.

The
  Supreme Court of South Carolina

	
		
			
				Noel and
      Elizabeth Dillon, Appellants/Respondents,
				v.
				Neil Frazer, Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	

The Honorable G. Edward Welmaker
Greenville County
Trial Court Case No.Â Â  2005-CP-23-01781
ORDER

We deny the petition for
  rehearing in this matter.Â  We now withdraw our previous opinion and substitute
  the attached opinion. 
IT IS SO ORDERED.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Â Â 

  
    
    
      s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.
        
        s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           J.
        
        s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.s/Donald W. Beatty                            J.
        s/John W. Kittredge                           J.
    
  

Columbia, South Carolina
June 1, 2009

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Noel and
      Elizabeth Dillon, Appellants/Respondents,
				v.
				Neil Frazer, Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26629
Heard January 8, 2009 - Re-filed June 1,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				Cynthia
  Barrier Patterson, of Columbia, and Donald R. Moorhead, of Greenville, for
  Appellant/Respondents.
				C.
  Stuart Mauney and T. David Rheney, both of Gallivan, White & Boyd, of Greenville, for Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  This action arose out of
  an automobile accident in which Noel Dillon was injured due to Neil Frazerâ€™s
  admitted negligence.Â  The men were co-employees of a company located in Ontario, Canada and both were residents of Ontario.Â  After a jury verdict for $6,000, Dillon[1] appealed the trial courtâ€™s refusal to grant a new
  trial absolute on damages.Â  Frazer appealed four points, all relating to
  whether or not Dillonâ€™s action should have been barred by the exclusivity
  statute found in Ontario workersâ€™ compensation law.Â  We certified the case
  pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We now affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling refusing
  to apply Ontario law, reverse the trial courtâ€™s refusal of a new trial absolute
  as to damages, and remand.
FACTS
In
  2002, Dillon and Frazer were employed by Massiv Die-Form (Massiv), a Canadian
  corporation with no facilities or place of business in South Carolina.Â  The men
  were in Greenville, South Carolina working for Massiv.Â  During their visit,
  Dillon and Frazer stayed at a hotel in Greenville and drove a rental car, all
  of which was paid for by Massiv.Â  Both Dillon and Frazer were paid 30 minutes
  per day for the travel time between their hotel and the worksite.Â  Frazer was
  the only employee authorized to drive the rental car.
Dillon sustained
  injuries in a car accident when Frazer ran a stop sign in a car in which Dillon
  was a passenger.Â  Dillon was transported by ambulance to a hospital, where it
  was determined that he had eight fractured ribs on his right side and two on
  his left, a fractured sternum, a fractured clavicle, a fractured left thumb,
  and a punctured lung.Â  He was admitted to the hospital where he remained for
  two days.Â  Once back in Canada, Dillon received physical therapy.Â  The
  remainder of his care was covered by the Canadian Health System and those costs
  were not sought in this action.
Due to his
  punctured lung, Dillon was not medically able to fly back to Canada until the Friday following his release from the hospital.Â  He did not return to work
  for at least 10 weeks.Â  Initially, Dillon returned to full-time work, but
  performed fewer overtime hours than prior to his injuries.Â  Dillon testified
  that, prior to the accident, he worked roughly between 900 and 1,100 hours of
  overtime and double time each year.Â  He stated that, after the accident, the number
  of hours he was able to work diminished.
Frazer admitted
  liability, so the only questions remaining for the jury were the amount of
  damages due Dillon and whether Dillonâ€™s wife was entitled to damages for loss
  of consortium.Â  All told, Dillonâ€™s hospital care in Greenville amounted to
  $10,518.Â  Dillon also claimed $320 for EMS transportation to the hospital and
  $1,188 in physical therapy bills.Â  In addition to compensation for medical
  care, Dillon also contended that he was entitled to $509,168 in lost past and
  future earnings, including $101,350 in lost wages from the date of injury to
  the estimated trial date and $407,818 for the post-trial period, based on calculations
  by Dillonâ€™s expert.
During
  deliberations, the jury sent questions to the judge asking whether any
  compensation had been paid to Dillon by a third party.Â  The jury awarded Dillon
  $6,000 and found for Frazer on the consortium claim by Dillonâ€™s wife.Â  Dillon
  moved for a new trial nisi additur or in the alternative, for a new
  trial absolute as to damages only.Â  The trial court granted Dillonâ€™s motion for additur and increased the damages by $15,000, bringing the total amount
  of damages to $21,000.Â  He denied all other motions.
I. 
New trial absolute
Dillon
  argues on appeal that the trial court erred by not granting a new trial
  absolute as to damages.Â  We agree.
The
  trial court has sound discretion when addressing questions of excessiveness or
  inadequacy of verdicts, and its decision will not be disturbed absent an abuse of
  discretion. Toole v. Toole, 260 S.C. 235, 239, 195 S.E.2d 389, 390 (1973).Â 
  â€œThe trial court must grant a new trial absolute if the amount of the verdict
  is grossly inadequate or excessive so as to shock the conscience of the court
  and clearly indicates the figure reached was the result of passion, caprice,
  prejudice, partiality, corruption or some other improper motive.Â  The failure
  of the trial judge to grant a new trial absolute in this situation amounts to
  an abuse of discretion and on appeal this Court will grant a new trial
  absolute.â€ Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 404-05, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723
  (Ct. App. 1996).Â  When considering a motion for a new trial based on the
  inadequacy or excessiveness of the juryâ€™s verdict, the trial court must
  distinguish between awards that are merely unduly liberal or conservative and
  awards that are actuated by passion, caprice, prejudice, or some other improper
  motive. Elam v. S.C. Dept. of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 602 S.E.2d 772
  (2004).
DISCUSSION
In Kalchthaler
  v. Workman, 316 S.C. 499, 450 S.E.2d 621 (Ct. App. 1994), the Court of
  Appeals held that a party, having requested and been granted an additur,
  cannot complain of the amount.Â  However, this does not preclude a party that is
  granted additur from appealing the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to grant a new
  trial absolute. Sullivan v. Davis, 317 S.C. 462, 467, 454 S.E.2d 907,
  911 (Ct. App. 1995).
Dillon
  presented evidence of over $500,000 in damages as a result of the accident.Â 
  While Frazer contested portions of Dillonâ€™s claim, unchallenged testimony at
  trial established the following damages: $10,518 in medical bills, $320.00 for EMS transportation to the hospital, $1,188 in physical therapy bills, and $18,000 in lost
  wages and overtime pay.Â  This totals $30,026 in undisputed damages.Â  
We
  find the jury verdict of $6,000 irreconcilably inconsistent with the unchallenged
  evidence presented at trial.Â  The disparity between the award and the admitted
  damages goes beyond a merely conservative award and suggests that the jurors were
  motivated by improper considerations.Â  
This
  suggestion is borne out by the following three questions asked by the jury
  during deliberations: (1) if it could see the deposition of the human resources
  director for Massiv; (2) whether Dillon received any compensation while he was
  not working during the ten weeks after the accident; and (3) whether medical
  bills for the accident were paid for, and if so, by whom.Â  The trial judge
  responded that those matters â€œare not for your concern.â€Â  The juryâ€™s verdict demonstrates
  that the jury failed to follow the courtâ€™s instruction. 
In Sullivan, supra, the jury sent questions to the trial judge inquiring as to what
  medical expenses had been covered by insurance. Id. at 466, 454 S.E.2d
  at 910.Â  The jury awarded $20,000 despite the plaintiffâ€™s medical bills totaling
  roughly $130,000, leading the Court of Appeals to conclude that â€œ[t]he jurors
  obviously did not follow the courtâ€™s instructions to disregard insurance. . . .
  Therefore we must set it aside and grant a new trial absolute.â€ Id. at 466-67, 454 S.E.2d at 910-11.Â  In the instant case, the record demonstrates
  that the jury ignored the trial courtâ€™s instruction to disregard matters
  relating to third party payment of medical bills.Â  
The
  juryâ€™s award of $6,000 in the face of over $30,000 in undisputed damages is
  grossly inadequate and demonstrates that the verdict was actuated by improper
  motivation.Â  No plausible reason for the amount of the verdict has been
  advanced.Â  For these reasons, the trial court erred in not granting Dillonâ€™s
  motion for a new trial absolute.
II.
Application of Ontario law
Frazer
  argues in relation to the Ontario workerâ€™s compensation exclusivity law, that
  the trial court erred: (1) in refusing to apply the exclusivity law; (2) in
  refusing to admit evidence on the exclusivity law; (3) in refusing to charge
  the jury on the exclusivity law; and (4) in denying Frazerâ€™s motion for
  judgment notwithstanding the verdict based on application of the exclusivity
  law.Â  Because each point hinges on the applicability of Ontario workerâ€™s
  compensation law and the exclusivity law, we address these points as one and
  affirm on the ground that Frazer failed to plead Ontario law and so, is barred
  under Rules 12(b) and 8(c). See Rule 12(b), SCRCP (every defense must be
  asserted in the responsive pleading); Rule 8(c), SCRCP (in a responsive
  pleading a party â€œshall set forth affirmatively . . . any other matter
  constituting an avoidance or affirmative defense.â€).[2]
Even
  if Frazerâ€™s argument was preserved, we find that lex loci delicto properly governs this case. See Lister v. Nationsbank of Delaware,
  329 S.C. 133,, 143, 494 S.E.2d 449, 454 (Ct. App. 1998) (In choice of law in South Carolina, the general rule is that the substantive law governing a tort action is the
  law of the state where the injury occurred.); Oshiek v. Oshiek, 244 S.C.
  249, 136 S.E.2d 303, 305 (1964), overruled on other grounds (In tort
  cases, the law of the place where the injury was occasioned or inflicted
  governs in respect of the right of action.).Â  
CONCLUSION
For
  the reasons stated above, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s refusal to apply Ontario law and reverse the denial of Dillonâ€™s motion for a new trial absolute.Â  Since
  Frazer admitted liability, we remand for a new trial on damages only.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Though Elizabeth Dillon filed Notice of Appeal, she did not pursue her appeal.
[2] Frazer asserted South Carolina workerâ€™s compensation law in his pleadings, but
  did not include Ontario workerâ€™s compensation law.Â  The trial court denied his
  motion to amend his pleadings to include Ontario law.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Daniel Edwards, Jr., Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Fairfield County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26657
Heard March 3, 2009 - Filed June 1, 2009
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				TaraÂ 
  Shurling, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General
  Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia, Solicitor Douglas A. Barfield, Jr., of
  Lancaster, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â Â Â Â Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the court of
  appeals opinion affirming the admission of witness intimidation evidence. Â State v. Edwards, 373 S.C. 230, 644 S.E.2d 66 (Ct. App. 2007).[1]Â 
  We affirm as modified.Â  We adhere to this Courtâ€™s jurisprudence and hold that a
  trial court may admit evidence of witness intimidation when the defendant is
  established as the source of the intimidation.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
I.
A
  jury found Daniel Edwards, Jr., guilty on three counts of criminal sexual
  conduct with a minor, second degree, and he was sentenced to prison.Â  The minor
  was his step-daughter.Â  The Stateâ€™s witnesses included the victim and her
  mother (Edwardsâ€™ wife).Â  The victimâ€™s mother testified that Edwards told her
  â€œto get in touch with [the victim] and have her not show up because he had a
  hit out on her, [and] that she wouldnâ€™t make it through the courtroom doors.â€Â 
  When asked whether Edwards ever said â€œanything about what he would do to [the
  victim] if he were to go to jail on these charges,â€ the victimâ€™s mother stated
  that â€œ[h]e told me that he would have her killed or he would kill her when he
  got out.â€Â  This evidence was admitted over Edwardsâ€™ objection.
Before
  admitting the testimony into evidence, the trial court carefully considered
  counselsâ€™ arguments and thoroughly examined the issue.Â  

	It is a
  statement by the defendant, alleged statement of the defendant.Â  Clearly there
  is a reasonable inference to be drawn from the statement that the testimony of
  the witness would be damaging to him. . . . 
	. . .Â  [It] could be construed by the jury to some
  extent as an admission that he is guilty and will be found guilty and that he
  will punish her for that, for testifying to what, considering all the evidence
  in the light most favorable to the state . . . that he is the perpetrator of
  this crime. 
	. . .Â  In this case, clearly in this situation, with
  the nature of the crime, I feel that it is tantamount to a threat, an attempted
  threat to discourage a witness from testifying.Â  
	There could be a logical inference that it wasnâ€™t
  made.Â  There could be an inference, and youâ€™re entitled to cross-examine, but
  the jury is entitled to weigh that.Â  I think that the probative value as to
  certainly being corroborative, while itâ€™s not necessary--Iâ€™m going to charge
  the jury accordingly.Â  It corroborates the Stateâ€™s position.Â  It corroborates
  the allegations that heâ€™s the perpetrator.Â  There could be no other logical
  explanation for the statement being made other than to intimidate a witness.Â  
	
	And for those reasons I think the prejudice is
  outweighed significantly by the probative value, so I will permit the testimony
  over the objection of counsel.Â  

Edwards
  appealed, contending the evidence of alleged threats and witness intimidation
  was improperly admitted because the evidence was â€œunreliable.â€Â  The court of
  appeals affirmed, relying primarily on case law from other jurisdictions,
  particularly the federal courts of appeals. The court of appeals observed
  that â€œ[t]his appears to be a novel issue to South Carolinaâ€ and concluded by
  stating:

	While the precedents from other jurisdictions are not
  controlling, we find them persuasive and in this case elect to adopt their
  analysis. Â Just as conflicting statements and attempts to flee are indicative
  of â€œguilty knowledge and intent,â€ so too are the threats communicated here.Â 
  Consequently, the trial judge did not err in admitting the evidence regarding
  threats by Edwards against the victim/witness.

Edwards, 373 S.C. at 237, 240, 644 S.E.2d at 70, 71 (internal
  citation omitted).Â  

II.
In
  criminal cases, this Court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v.
    Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).
A.
The
  question presented is not novel to South Carolina.Â  This stateâ€™s jurisprudence
  answers this challenge to the admissibility of evidence of witness intimidation,
  especially Edwardsâ€™ focus on the reliability of the evidence.[2]
In State v. Rogers, 96 S.C. 350, 80 S.E. 620
  (1914), this Court addressed the admissibility of an unsigned letter delivered
  to a witness who later testified against Rogers.Â  Rogers was â€œtried and convicted
  under an indictment charging him with willful and malicious injury to the cars
  and engine of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company, and endangering the
  lives of the train crew and passengers.â€Â  Id. at 351, 80 S.E. at 620.Â 
  The letter introduced at trial was addressed to a witness for the State; the
  letter â€œwas of a threatening nature, with a coffin drawn on it, and intended to
  intimidate.â€Â  Id. at 351, 80 S.E. at 620.Â  
At
  trial, the judge instructed the jury not to consider the letter as testimony to
  prove Rogersâ€™ guilt unless the State connected him to the letter, which it
  never did.Â  This Court found the omission harmless, but made it clear the
  admission of the letter was in error: â€œ[h]is honor should not have admitted in
  evidence the letter . . . without connecting the defendant in some manner with
  it.Â  It would have been better to require the [S]tate then and there, after it
  was admitted, to connect the defendant with it, and, upon failure to do so, to
  have ruled it out.â€Â  Id. at 352, 80 S.E. at 621.
This
  is the reliability analysis requested by Edwardsâ€”that is, the proponent of the
  evidence of intimidation must connect the defendant with the threat.Â  Without
  establishing that connection, the evidence concerning witness intimidation is
  unreliable and therefore inadmissible. Â 
This
  analysis is further supported by our reasoning and decision in State v.
    Center, 205 S.C. 42, 30 S.E.2d 760 (1944).Â  In Center, this Court addressed
  the admissibility of evidence relating to witness intimidation.Â  Center was
  convicted of violating a law dealing with the sale of alcohol.Â  At trial,
  testimony revealed that Centerâ€™s son came â€œto the shop [where one of the
  witnesses worked] and whipped [him] on [his] job.â€Â  Id. at 47, 30 S.E.2d
  at 763.Â  According to the witness, â€œ[Centerâ€™s son] said that if I got on the
  stand . . . that [what he had just done] was not half what he was going to do
  for me if I swore against his mother.â€Â  Id. at 47-48, 30 S.E.2d at 763.Â 
  The witness later revealed that being â€œwhippedâ€ meant he â€œ[b]lacked my eye.â€Â  Id. at 48, 30 S.E.2d at 763.Â  The trial court admitted the witness intimidation
  evidence and Center was convicted.Â  This Court reversed the conviction.

	There is
  no testimony whatever that the defendant had any knowledge of such transaction,
  therefore they are the acts of a third party and such testimony is prejudicial
  where it is not shown the accused was privy thereto in that it is obnoxious to
  the rule of law res inter alios acta which is defined as â€œâ€˜Things done between
  strangers ought not to injure those who are not parties thereto.â€™â€Â  
	. . . .
	In
  the above cited case the ones alleged to have made the threats were the mother
  and sister of the accused while in [the] instant case it was the son of the
  accused.Â  In neither case was there any testimony showing that the accused had
  any knowledge of such threats.

Id. at 49-50, 30 S.E.2d at 764 (internal citation
  omitted).
Center stands for the proposition that the admissibility of
  witness intimidation evidence turns on whether the source of the intimidation
  may be linked to the defendant.Â  The Rogers and Center analyses speak
  directly to the reliability sought by Edwards.Â  
In State
  v. Goodson, 225 S.C. 418, 429, 82 S.E.2d 804, 809 (1954), a concurring
  opinion from this Court recognized that â€œ[e]vidence that a person charged with [a]
  crime procured or attempted to procure [the] absence of a witness or to bribe
  or suppress testimony against him tends to show unrighteousness of defendantâ€™s
  cause and a consciousness of guilt.â€
More
  recently, in Mincey v. State, 314 S.C. 355, 444 S.E.2d 510 (1994), we
  dealt with the prejudicial effect of a solicitorâ€™s unsubstantiated reference in
  closing argument to witness intimidation.Â  Elijah Mincey was convicted of
  distributing drugs.Â  During Minceyâ€™s trial several people at the scene of the
  alleged drug distribution testified that he was not involved.Â  In the Stateâ€™s
  closing argument, the solicitor referred to Mincey as â€œa pretty intimidating
  man.â€ Â The solicitor also stated â€œ[Elijah Mincey] must be pretty intimidating
  for these guys [to deny Minceyâ€™s involvement in the drug transaction],â€ and
  concerning the confidential informer, â€œ[m]aybe sheâ€™s intimidated by Elijah.â€Â  Id. at 357-58, 444 S.E.2d at 511.Â  
Mincey sought post-conviction relief on the basis that trial
  counsel was ineffective for failing to object to the solicitorâ€™s comments
  concerning witness intimidation.Â  The post-conviction relief court denied
  relief, and we reversed and remanded for a new trial.Â  In granting post-conviction
  relief, we noted the absence of â€œevidence that Mincey intimidated any of the
  witnesses.â€Â  Id. at 358, 444 S.E.2d at 512.Â  
Today we follow Rogers, Center, the concurring
  opinion in Goodson, and Mincey and hold that witness intimidation
  evidence, if linked to the defendant, may be admitted to show a consciousness
  of guilt.Â  Establishing the defendant as the source of the intimidation
  provides the necessary reliability for admissibility.Â  Here, the mother of the
  victim identified Edwards as the author of the intimidation.Â  Because the State
  presented evidence linking Edwards as the source of the witness intimidation,
  we find no abuse of discretion in the admission of the evidence.[3]
B.
Our
  approach follows the majority of jurisdictions that have addressed the issue.Â 
  For example, in United States v. Hayden, 85 F.3d 153, 159 (4th Cir.
  1996), the court noted that â€œ[e]vidence of witness intimidation is admissible
  to prove consciousness of guilt and criminal intent under Rule 404(b), if the
  evidence (1) is related to the offense charged and (2) is reliable.â€Â  Hayden
  challenged the trial courtâ€™s admission of â€œevidence that he had written a
  threatening letter to a witnessâ€ and that he â€œtelephoned [a witness] to
  threaten [the witness] and his family if [the witness] testified.â€Â  Id. at 158-59.Â  With regard to the letter, the Hayden court found:

	There
  was no handwriting analysis, nor were there any fingerprints, and the letter
  was not signedâ€”it was sent anonymously.Â  The letterâ€™s content, however, pointed
  to [Hayden] as its author.Â  The letter referred to the recipient as owing the
  writer money for drugs unpaid for.Â  The recipient of the letter testified that
  . . . Hayden was the only person to whom he had ever owed drug money and about
  whom he was planning to testify.Â  Thus, the recipient established the identity
  of the writer of the letter to a fairly reliable degree.

Id. at 159.Â  As
  for the phone call, the court noted that the witness â€œwas able to identify the
  voice [of Hayden].â€Â  Id.Â  From the analysis in Hayden, it is
  reasonable to conclude that the Fourth Circuit equates the matter of
  reliability with the ability of the proponent of the evidence to link the
  threat to the defendant.
As noted, the prevailing view
  across the country is in accord, as our court of appeals commendably
  demonstrated in its thorough research of witness intimidation evidence in other
  jurisdictions.Â  Edwards, 373 S.C. at 238-39, 644 S.E.2d at 70-71.Â  
III.
Edwards urges this
  Court to disallow, essentially on policy grounds, the type of witness intimidation
  evidence presented here.Â  Edwards argues that the evidence is inherently
  unreliable and allowing such evidence will promote false allegations of witness
  intimidation.Â  We do not discount Edwardsâ€™ concerns.Â  Yet we ultimately trust
  our adversarial system to work as designed.Â  The trial judge serves a critical gatekeeping role, under Rule 403, SCRE, and otherwise, in determining the
  admissibility of evidence.Â  Assuming the foundation for witness intimidation
  evidence has been satisfied and the evidence further survives a Rule 403 challenge,
  we trust the collective wisdom of juries to sift through conflicting evidence
  and find the truth.Â  
In
  addition, while our jurisprudence in this area has been consistent since the
  early 1900s, it has been infrequent.Â  In light of this Courtâ€™s infrequent
  experience with this issue, and our review of other jurisdictions, we do not
  foresee a floodgate of witness intimidation evidence.Â  
And
  finally, we are persuaded that the suggested per se rule disallowing
  evidence of witness intimidation would invite the very intimidation our system
  abhors.Â  On balance, a cautious approach allowing for the admissibility of witness
  intimidation evidence serves to discourage witness intimidation as well as
  minimize the potential for false claims of witness intimidation.
IV.
Because evidence
  was presented pointing to Edwards as the source of the witness intimidation and
  the trial court, after careful consideration, determined that the probative
  value was not substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, we
  find no abuse of discretion in the admission of the evidence of witness
  intimidation.Â  The court of appeals is
AFFIRMED
  AS MODIFIED. 
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.


[1]  The court of appeals also disposed of issues concerning the admission of
  prior bad acts evidence and the denial of a motion for a mistrial.Â  Certiorari was granted only on the challenge to the witness
  intimidation evidence.
[2]  As noted, the testimony elicited during trial revealed that Edwards
  asked his wife to relay a death threat to the victim.Â  We can envision a litany
  of other forms of witness intimidation, but for purposes of uniformity, we
  believe the term witness intimidation sufficiently captures the nature of the
  evidence in most situations.
[3]  The admission of evidence, of course, remains in the sound discretion of
  the trial court.Â  Relevant evidence may be excluded for a host of reasons,
  including a finding under Rule 403, SCRE, that the probative value of the
  evidence is substantially outweighed by its prejudicial effect.

  Edward Redmond, of Darlington, pro se.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  This is an attorney
  disciplinary matter involving nine complaints against Kernard Edward Redmond
  (Respondent).Â  After a full investigation by the Office of Disciplinary Counsel
  (ODC), the Commission on Lawyer Conduct filed formal charges against
  Respondent.Â  ODC and Respondent stipulated to specific facts and rule violations.Â 
  At a hearing before the Commission on Lawyer Conduct Panel (Panel), Respondent
  acknowledged his misconduct, expressed remorse, and presented evidence of his
  current success in the practice of law.Â  A three-member majority of the Panel
  recommended that Respondent be admonished for his misconduct.Â  One member of
  the Panel recommended a public reprimand and payment of costs, while another
  member recommended a definite suspension and payment of costs.
We
  find Respondentâ€™s acknowledgement of his misconduct and remorse to be sincere
  and effective in the mitigation of his sanction.Â  We further find that as the
  investigation progressed, Respondent was cooperative with ODC. Â Nonetheless,
  due to Respondentâ€™s prior disciplinary history[1] and the gravity and cumulative nature of his misconduct, we decline to adopt
  the majorityâ€™s recommendation of an admonition.Â  Accordingly, we hereby
  publicly reprimand Respondent and order him to pay the costs of the
  disciplinary proceedings.Â  The facts, as stipulated to by ODC and Respondent,
  are as follows.
Facts
Matter A
Respondent
  represented Client A on criminal charges arising out of a 1999 incident.Â  Client
  A was tried and convicted.Â  Due to Respondentâ€™s inattention to detail and
  failure to communicate with Client A, the Office of Appellate Defense (OAD)
  declined to represent him.[2]Â 
  Respondent filed an appellate brief on Client Aâ€™s behalf, but ignored Client
  Aâ€™s requests that he move to be relieved as counsel.Â  Client A repeatedly asked
  Respondent to produce his file, but Respondent refused to do so until he reimburse
  Respondent $1,950.00 for the cost of his trial transcript. Â 
On
  multiple occasions, OAD informed Respondent that it would represent Client A if
  Respondent filed a motion to be relieved as counsel.Â  Respondent failed to
  inform Client A of OADâ€™s offer and failed to file a motion to be relieved.Â 
  Respondentâ€™s response to the notice of full investigation in Matter A was not
  timely.
Matter B
In
  January 2002, Client B hired Respondent to pursue a civil claim on his behalf.Â 
  Respondent became aware that Client B previously filed his claim in
  magistrateâ€™s court where it was dismissed with prejudice.Â  Despite knowing of
  no reason that the claim would not be dismissed, Respondent re-filed the claim
  in circuit court.Â  The claim was dismissed on res judicata grounds.Â  
Additionally,
  during the course of litigation, Respondent misplaced Client Bâ€™s photographic
  evidence and, therefore, did not timely respond to defense counselâ€™s discovery
  requests.Â  Respondent was late in responding to ODCâ€™s initial inquiry into
  Matter B as well as subsequent requests for additional information.Â  
Matter C
In
  2001, Respondent represented Client C for criminal charges to which Client C
  pled guilty.Â  After Respondent left private practice to work at the solicitorâ€™s
  office, Client Câ€™s mother asked Respondent for help in getting his sentence
  reduced.Â  Respondent referred her to his old law firm but also undertook
  certain duties consistent with continued representation.Â  Respondent admitted
  that although he intended to sever the attorney-client relationship, he never
  clearly did so and he knew Client C and his mother continued to rely on him.Â 
  Respondentâ€™s responses to ODC in Matter C were not timely.Â  
Matter D
Respondent
  represented Client D in a personal injury matter.Â  Respondent failed to notify
  Client D that he was leaving private practice and that another lawyer would
  represent her.Â  Client D was ultimately represented by another attorney in
  Respondentâ€™s former law firm.Â  At the time formal charges were filed against
  him, Respondent was unable to locate Client Dâ€™s file. Â Respondentâ€™s responses
  to ODC in Matter D were untimely.Â  
Matter E
In or
  around August 2003, Client E hired Respondent to represent him in a property
  damage case. Â Respondent continued to represent Client E even after he began to
  work at the solicitorâ€™s office.Â  Contrary to Client Eâ€™s request, Respondent
  failed to file Client Eâ€™s suit until March 2005.Â Respondentâ€™s response to ODCâ€™s inquiry in Matter E was not timely. 
Matter F
Respondent
  represented Client F in a medical malpractice matter and a disability benefits
  claim.Â  After Respondent began working at the solicitorâ€™s office, Client F
  requested his file.Â  Respondent merely told Client F to contact his old firm
  and made no effort to help Client F retrieve his file.Â  Two years after Client
  F filed his complaint with ODC, and at the suggestion of ODC, Respondent
  retrieved Client Fâ€™s file and returned it to him.Â  Respondentâ€™s responses to
  ODCâ€™s inquiries into Matter F were timely.Â  
Matter G
In November 1998,
  Respondent began to represent Client G in a civil matter.Â  Respondent filed
  suit in magistrateâ€™s court and took the file with him when he began work at the
  solicitorâ€™s office.Â  Respondent did not communicate adequately with Client G
  and, contrary to his specific directions, accepted a settlement offer of
  $500.00.Â  Respondent delivered the entire amount to Client G without deducting
  a fee.Â  Client G signed a release.Â  Respondentâ€™s response to ODC in Matter G
  was timely.Â  

Matter H
Before
  and after Respondent left private practice to work at the solicitorâ€™s office,
  he represented Client H in a civil rights matter.Â  The matter was tried and the
  jury rendered a verdict against Client H.Â  Client H requested that Respondent
  turn over his file.Â  Respondent ignored this request.Â  Only after Client H
  filed a complaint with ODC did Respondent attempt to locate the file.Â  The file
  was never found. Â Respondentâ€™s response to ODCâ€™s initial inquiry in Matter H
  was not timely.Â  
Matter I
While
  working at the solicitorâ€™s office, Respondent was assigned to the prosecution
  of a defendant whose brother he had represented in private practice.Â  Because
  of this prior relationship, Respondent referred the case to a colleague.Â  Nonetheless,
  the defendant complained to ODC that Respondent had engaged in a conflict of
  interest.Â  The defendantâ€™s complaint in Matter I is without merit; however,
  Respondentâ€™s response to ODCâ€™s initial inquiry in this matter was not timely. 
Law
ODC argues that due to the gravity of Respondentâ€™s
  misconduct and his disciplinary history, the Panel erred in recommending an
  admonition.Â  ODC argues that Respondentâ€™s actions warrant a harsher sanction.Â 
  We agree.
Respondent
  stipulated that, by his misconduct, he violated the following provisions of the
  Rules of Professional conduct, Rule 407, SCACR: Rule 1.1 (a lawyer shall
  provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.2 (a lawyer shall abide
  by a clientâ€™s decisions concerning the objectives of representation and shall
  consult with the client as to the means by which they are to be pursued); Rule
  1.3 (a lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in
  representing a client); Rule 1.4 (a lawyer shall reasonably consult with the
  client about the means by which the clientâ€™s objectives are to be accomplished,
  keep the client reasonably informed about the status of the matter, and
  promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 1.16 (a lawyer
  shall not represent a client under certain circumstances and should those
  circumstances come to light after an attorney-client relationship has been
  established, a lawyer must withdraw from representation in an appropriate
  manner); Rule 3.1 (a lawyer shall not bring or defend a claim unless there is a
  non-frivolous basis in law and fact for doing so); and Rule 8.1 (a lawyer, in
  connection with a disciplinary matter, shall not knowingly fail to respond to a
  lawful demand for information from a disciplinary authority).
Furthermore,
  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline
  under Rule 7(a)(1) of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413,
  SCACR (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the Rules of
  Professional Conduct).Â  Accordingly, we find that a public reprimand is an
  appropriate sanction under these circumstances.Â  Â Â  Â Â 
Conclusion
We decline to adopt the Panel majorityâ€™s
  recommendation of an admonition due to Respondentâ€™s prior disciplinary history
  and the gravity and cumulative nature of his misconduct.Â  Nonetheless, because
  Respondent recognizes his misconduct and expresses sincere remorse, we hereby
  publicly reprimand Respondent and order him to pay the costs of this action
  within ninety days of the filing of this opinion. 
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] On July 26, 2000, Respondent received a Letter of
  Caution in a matter unrelated to the complaints before us here.
[2] Respondent was given, but did not timely forward to his
  client, an affidavit of indigence required to be filled out by OAD
  applicants.Â Â

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Wyatt Breland
      Willoughby, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No.Â  26660
Submitted May 4, 2009 - Filed June 1, 2009 
PUBLIC REPRIMAND


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and William C. Campbell, Assistant Disciplinary
  Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Wyatt
  Breland Willoughby, of Myrtle Beach, pro se.Â Â Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel
  (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent
  pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits
  misconduct and consents to the imposition of an admonition or a public
  reprimand.Â  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts,
  as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Due to a down turn in business and
  resulting economic hardship, respondent closed his law practice.Â  Respondent
  admits he failed to comply with Rule 1.17 of the Rules of Professional Conduct,
  Rule 407, SCACR, in closing his practice.Â  In particular, respondent admits he
  failed to personally safeguard client files in that he left the files in the
  hands of his paralegal instead of personally supervising the delivery of the
  files to a title insurance company.Â  In addition, he admits there were
  communication failures concerning the delivery of the files to the title
  insurance company.Â  Specifically, respondent failed to confirm his arrangements
  for delivery of files to the title insurance company management and that, at
  the time of delivery, a number of files were still awaiting final post-closing
  activities such as the issuance of final title policies.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits
  that, by his misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules
  of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall safekeep
  client property); Rule 1.17 (stating requirements for sale of law practice);
  and Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the
  Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct
  constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary
  Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for
  discipline for a lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct
  warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.Â 
  Within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall pay the
  costs incurred by ODC and the Commission on Lawyer Conduct in the investigation
  and prosecution of this matter.Â  
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

description: In this case, the Court reversed the circuit court's determination that Respondents are entitled to recoup sales tax payments.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				South Carolina
      Department of Revenue, Appellant,
				v.
				Anonymous
      Company A and Anonymous Company B, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Michelle Childs, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26661
Heard April 8, 2009 - Filed June 1, 2009 
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Managing
  Counsel for Litigation Milton G. Kimpson, Counsel for Litigation Craig M.
  Pisarik, Director Ray N. Stevens, Chief of Staff Harry T. Cooper, Jr., and General
  Counsel for Litigation Nicholas P. Sipe, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
				John
  D. Hawkins, ofÂ  The Hawkins Law Firm, of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
			
		
	


JUSTICE PLEICONES: Companies
  A and B (Respondents) are two separate corporations with the same owners.Â 
  Company A (Dealer) sells used cars and then sells the retail installment sales
  contracts to Company B (Finance Company).Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-36-90(2)(h),
  allows a taxpayer to take a sales tax credit for those installment contracts on
  which the purchaser fails to make payments and which are consequently charged
  off as bad debts or uncollectible accounts.Â  Pursuant to the statute, Respondents
  seek a refund of sales taxes for installment contracts which became uncollectible
  after Dealer sold them to Finance Company.
Respondents
  contested the South Carolina Department of Revenueâ€™s (SCDOR) ruling that they
  are ineligible for relief under the statute.Â  The Administrative Law Court
  (ALC) ruled for Respondents and the circuit court affirmed.Â  As more fully
  explained below, to qualify under the statute, Dealer and Finance Company must
  constitute one â€œpersonâ€ and one â€œtaxpayerâ€ within the definitions set forth in Title
  12, Chapter 36 of the South Carolina Code, also known as the Sales and Use Tax
  Act.Â  Whether or not the parties together meet these definitions is the
  critical question in the instant case.Â  We find that the parties are not one
  â€œpersonâ€ under the terms of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-36-30 and so, reverse the
  decision of the circuit court.
FACTS
Timothy
  Brown (Husband) and his wife Noreen (Wife) are the sole shareholders of Dealer
  and Finance Company, which are sub-chapter S corporations doing business in South Carolina.Â  Husband testified that the main purpose for Finance Companyâ€™s existence is
  to take advantage of tax benefits.Â  By selling its contracts to Finance
  Company, Dealer is able to avoid recognizing as income the full amount of the
  contract and can instead recognize only the discounted amount it receives from
  Finance Company.[1]
The
  sales tax on the purchase of each vehicle sold is included in the installment
  loan contract purchased by Finance Company.Â  Only Dealer has a retail license and
  therefore, must pay sales tax to DOR.Â  Dealer, along with Finance Company, submitted
  a Claim for Refund to DOR.Â  The claimed amount covered 1,731 loans and totaled
  $330,274.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe
  construction of a statute by an agency charged with its administration is
  entitled to the most respectful consideration and should not be overruled
  absent compelling reasons.â€ Â Sloan v. S.C. Bd. of Physical Therapy Examiners,
  370 S.C. 452, 636 S.E.2d 598 (2006).Â  The circuit courtâ€™s scope of review is
  set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610(C) (2008).Â  On appeal, this Courtâ€™s
  scope of review is the same as that of the circuit court. Â See Brown
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health and Environmental Control, 348 S.C. 507, 560 S.E.2d
  410 (2002).
ISSUE
Did
  the circuit court err in finding that Dealer and Finance Company are entitled
  to sales tax relief under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-36-90(2)(h), also known as the
  â€œbad debt statute?â€
DISCUSSION
S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 12-36-90(2)(h) allows for a tax credit for sales tax paid on
  installment contracts that become worthless or uncollectible and are charged
  off as bad debt.[2]Â 
  It provides in part:

	A taxpayer who pays the tax on the unpaid balance of
  an account which has been found to be worthless and is actually charged off for
  state income tax purposes may take a deduction for the sales price charged off
  as a bad debt or uncollectible account on a return filed pursuant to this
  chapter, except that if an amount charged off is later paid in whole or in part
  to the taxpayer, the amount paid must be included in the first return filed
  after the collection and tax paid.Â  The deduction allowed by this provision
  must be taken within one year of the month the amount was determined to be a
  bad debt or uncollectible account.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  12-36-90(2)(h) (2008). [3]
The
  Code defines â€œtaxpayerâ€ as â€œany person liable for taxes under this chapter.â€ Â S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 12-36-40 (2008).Â  The Code further defines â€œpersonâ€ as:

	any individual, firm, partnership, limited liability
  company, association, corporation, receiver, trustee, any group or combination
  acting as a unit, the State, any state agency, any instrumentality, authority,
  political subdivision, or municipality.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-36-30
  (2008).
Though
  the statute does not explicitly say so, the logical reading of Â§ 12-36-90(2)(h)
  is that the same taxpayer who paid the sales tax must be the taxpayer who
  charged the debt off for income tax purposes.Â  To hold otherwise would be to
  render the second part of the bad debt statute meaningless.Â  By providing that
  the taxpayer must include the amount in a return if the amount charged off is
  later repaid, it is apparent that the statute is meant to benefit only
  retailers who suffered financially from a customerâ€™s non-payment.Â  
Since
  Dealer paid the sales tax and Finance Company charged off the bad debt, Dealer
  and Finance Company must together meet the definition of â€œpersonâ€ and
  â€œtaxpayerâ€ in order to meet the terms of the deduction statute.
Respondents
  contend, and the circuit court and ALC agreed, that Dealer and Finance Company
  together constitute a â€œpersonâ€ under Â§ 12-36-30.Â  Therefore, in the view of the
  circuit court, they are together a â€œtaxpayerâ€ as one person liable for sales
  tax and â€œDealer, as a member of this unit, may take a deduction on its sales
  returns for debts that are actually charged off by Finance Company, the second
  member of the taxpayer unit.â€Â  Because we find that the two corporations do not
  constitute one person within the meaning of Â§ 12-36-30, we do not reach Respondentsâ€™
  status as a â€œtaxpayer.â€
A. The Circuit Court erred in finding that Dealer and
  Finance Company together constitute one â€œpersonâ€

	As
  noted above, Â§ 12-36-30 defines a â€œpersonâ€ as follows:
	any individual, firm, partnership, limited liability
  company, association, corporation, receiver, trustee, any group or combination
  acting as a unit, the State, any state agency, any instrumentality, authority,
  political subdivision, or municipality.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-36-30
  (2008).
The
  phrase â€œany group or combination acting as a unitâ€ has not been interpreted by South Carolina courts.Â  Respondents argue that they constitute a â€œunitâ€ because they are
  owned by the same individuals and â€œFinance Companyâ€™s sole reason for existence
  is to purchase Dealerâ€™s installment sales contracts.â€ Â The circuit court agreed
  with Respondents.Â  It found it significant that the previous version of the
  statute read â€œor any other group or combinationâ€ and the word â€œotherâ€ was not
  included in the current version.Â  The circuit court noted that â€œ[h]ad the
  legislature wanted to limit â€˜any group or combination acting as a unitâ€™ to only
  non-incorporated entities, as suggested by the Department, it could have kept
  the word â€˜otherâ€™ in the statute, as in the former version . . . .â€
DOR
  contends that the â€œunitâ€ clause is a catch-all clause and, regardless of the
  presence or absence of the word â€œother,â€ two corporations may not constitute
  one person under the statute. Â We agree with DOR.
The
  Supreme Court of Kansas considered a similar statute in Pemco, Inc. v.
    Kansas Department of Revenue, 907 P.2d 863 (Kan. 1995).Â  Pemco leased
  construction equipment to its wholly-owned subsidiaries and argued that it did
  not owe sales tax for the leases.Â  The company argued that it and one of its
  subsidiaries constituted a â€œunitâ€ under the definition of â€œperson,â€ which
  provides:

	â€œPersonsâ€ means any individual, firm, copartnership,
  joint adventure, association, corporation, estate or trust, receiver or
  trustee, or any group or combination acting as a unit . . . .

Kan. Stat. Ann. Â§ 79-3602(a) (1994 Supp.).Â  The Supreme
  Court of Kansas held that the parent company and subsidiary could not
  constitute a single â€œpersonâ€ under the statute:

	Note that the statute is simply defining what a person
  is for purposes of the Act.Â  It first lists the usual types of entities
  recognized at law and then adds, â€œor any group or combination acting as a
  unit.â€Â  There is nothing to indicate an intent that this catch-all phrase was
  intended to alter the status of any of the specifically listed entities.Â  A
  logical interpretation is that it was intended to extend â€œpersonâ€ status to
  groups or combinations acting as a unit even though the group or unit does not
  fit within the legal definition of any of the specifically designated
  entities.Â  Thus, an improperly incorporated corporation could not escape sales
  tax liability by relying on its legal infirmities.Â  Also, tax liability could
  not be avoided by claiming a weird type of group or unit not fitting into a
  standard type of organization.

Pemco, 907 P.2d at 866.
We
  agree with the reasoning of the court in Pemco in that â€œ[t]here is nothing
  to indicate an intent that this catch-all phrase was intended to alter the
  status of any of the specifically listed entities.â€ Â Id.Â  Dealer and
  Finance Company are each â€œpersonsâ€ within the meaning of Â§ 12-36-30 since each
  is a corporation.Â  To allow the two corporations to present themselves as one
  â€œpersonâ€ by combining to form a unit would be to rewrite the statute. 
Respondents argue
  that policy arguments weigh in their favor since, by avoiding application of
  the Â§ 12-36-90(2)(h), â€œthe government keeps money it was never owed.â€Â  We note
  that whether or not sales tax is owed depends on the sale of an item rather
  than the fulfillment of the installment contract. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  12-36-910 (2008).Â  Thus, Respondentsâ€™ argument is flawed since the Government
  was owed the money at the time of sale.Â  By enacting the â€œbad debt statute,â€
  the General Assembly created a method by which a taxpayer may recoup sales tax
  paid on installment contracts that ultimately prove uncollectible.Â  Respondents
  could have availed themselves of this method if not for their election to
  obtain income tax savings pursuant to IRS regulations.[4]
Because we find
  that Dealer and Finance Company are bound by their chosen forms, we reverse the
  decision of the circuit court.
B. Finance Company is not entitled to relief under the
  doctrine of assignment
Respondents
  posit as an additional sustaining ground that Finance Company is entitled to
  recoup sales tax based on the doctrine of assignment.Â  We disagree.
DOR
  contends that Respondents did not appeal from adverse rulings by the ALC and
  circuit court on this issue and so, the rulings are the law of the case.Â  We
  note, however, that the successful party in the lower court may raise on appeal
  any additional reasons the appellate court should affirm the lower courtâ€™s
  ruling. Â See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C.
  406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000).Â  
Exercising our discretion under Iâ€™On and considering the merits of the additional sustaining ground, we find that
  the lower courts correctly held that Finance Company is barred from the refund
  by Â§ 12-60-470(C).Â  â€œA refund of taxes is solely a matter of governmental or
  legislative grace and any person seeking such relief must bring himself clearly
  within the terms of the statute authorizing the same.â€ Â Guaranty Bank &
    Trust Co. v. S.C. Tax Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 82, 90, 173 S.E.2d 367, 370 (1970).Â 
  Section 12-60-470(C)(2) provides that a taxpayer legally liable for the tax may
  assign a refund to another person â€œonly after the taxpayerâ€™s claim is allowed,
  the amount of the refund is finally decided, and the department has approved
  the refund.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-470(C)(2) (2008).Â  In the instant case, if
  an assignment occurred, it took place well before the event giving rise to a
  claim for relief under the bad debt statute.Â  In fact, according to Husband,
  the only assignment cited by Respondents occurs almost immediately after the
  customer signs the installment agreement. Â Consequently, any assignment to
  Finance Company cannot meet the requirements of Â§ 12-60-470(C)(2) and therefore, Finance Company is not
  entitled to a refund on this basis.
C. Dealer is not entitled to the tax credit on its own
Finally, Respondents offer as an
  additional sustaining ground the theory that Dealer may be entitled to the tax
  credit on its own based on the idea that it has â€œbad debtâ€ â€œbecause it sells
  its contracts to Finance Company for an amount determined by the historical
  default rate of its customers.â€Â  The lower court declined to reach this
  argument and we find it without merit.Â  According to the â€œAgreement to Purchase
  Automobile Contractsâ€ between the two companies, Dealer assigns all right,
  title, and interest to Finance Company.Â  Dealer therefore, having sold the
  contract, has no bad debt.
CONCLUSION
We hold that the circuit court erred in
  finding that Dealer and Finance Company together constitute a â€œpersonâ€ under Â§
  12-36-30.Â  The decision of the circuit court is therefore
REVERSED.
WALLER, ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE, BEATTY,
  KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.


[1] Dealer sells its contracts to Finance Company for an amount determined by the
  historical default rate of its customers.Â  The Internal Revenue Service allows
  Dealer to report this discounted rate as income rather than the full amount of
  the contract.
[2] Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary defines â€œcharge-offâ€ in part as follows: â€œTo treat (an
  account receivable) as a loss or expense because payment is unlikely; to treat
  as bad debt.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 227 (7th ed. 1999).
[3] Section 12-39-90(2)(h) provides relief to a taxpayer in the form of a tax
  deduction on a future tax return.Â  However, the ALC held, and the circuit court
  agreed, that the Dealer may demand a refund of the bad debt credit.Â  DOR notes
  that its argument in this regard was rejected by the circuit court.Â  It has not
  pursued this point on appeal.Â  
[4] In pursuing a tax deduction under the â€œbad debt statute,â€ Dealer seeks to
  benefit twice from defaults on the installment contracts.Â  Dealer testified
  that he paid lower income taxes by selling the contracts to Finance Company for
  an amount less than face value based on the assumption that a certain number of
  the installment contracts would fail.Â  See supra note 1 and
  accompanying text.Â  Now that a number of the installment contracts have failed,
  as predicted, Dealer seeks an additional benefit through the sales tax
  deduction provided by the â€œbad debt statute.â€

REMEDY 
The Petitioners in the Edwards Action seek a declaratory judgment
  that Â§1607(b) of the ARRA allows the General Assembly to request, accept, and distribute the SFS funds, which the General Assembly included in the Budget, and that

  14-3-310 (1976).Â  Mandamus is the highest judicial writ known to the law.Â  Brackenbrook N. Charleston, LP v. County of Charleston, 360 S.C. 390, 400, 602 S.E.2d 39,

Petitioners Edwards and Williams (petitioners) seek a declaration
  that respondent Sanford (the Governor) must perform the actions required by the
  American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA)[1] to apply for the State Fiscal
  Stabilization (SFS) Funds available under that Act.  I would grant the

In
  enacting the ARRA, Congress, exercising its authority pursuant to the spending
  clause,[2] provided two methods by which a state could express its desire to receive ARRA
  funds.  Section 1607 of the ARRA is entitled “ADDITIONAL FUNDING DISTRIBUTION
  AND ASSURANCE OF APPROPRIATE USE OF FUNDS.”  Under § 1607(a), entitled
  “CERTIFICATION BY GOVERNOR,” the ARRA provides “for funds provided to any State
  or agency thereof, the Governor of the State shall certify that:  (1) the State
  will request and use funds provided by this Act  . . . .”  In § 1607(b), entitled
  “ACCEPTANCE BY STATE LEGISLATURE,” the act provides “If funds provided . . . in
  any division of this Act are not accepted for use by the Governor, then
  acceptance by the State legislature, by means of the adoption of a concurrent
  resolution, shall be sufficient to provide funding to such State.”  As the
  legislative history makes clear, § 1607(b) was included in the ARRA in response
  to suggestions from the Governor that he was averse to accepting federal funds.
 Under my reading of the ARRA, either a certification or a
  concurrent resolution is required in order for ARRA funds to be received by a
  state.  Section 1607 vests the decision to exercise discretion first in the
  Governor, and then, as to any funds which he chooses not to accept, discretion
  vests in the General Assembly.  
The
  Governor did provide a timely letter[3] expressing his intent to accept ARRA funds, and his desire that the letter
  serve as his § 1607(a) certification.  In this certification letter, however,
  the Governor stated that he was not applying for the SFS Funds, and expressed
  his “reservations about accepting these funds.”  
In
  response to the Governor’s letter indicating that he was certifying but not
  accepting SFS Funds, the General Assembly exercised the discretion afforded it
  by § 1607(b) and enacted a concurrent resolution accepting the SFS Funds. 
  Although the Governor argues that such a resolution does not have the force of
  law in this State, he misapprehends the purpose for which this resolution was
  passed: to exercise the discretion given the General Assembly under federal law
  to accept funds which the Governor had declined.
Here,
  we have a certification from the Governor under § 1607(a) which declines to
  accept the SFS Funds, followed by a concurrent resolution under § 1607(b) by
  which the General Assembly exercised its discretionary power to accept the SFS
  Funds.  
The ARRA further requires that in order to receive SFS Funds, “the
  Governor of a State desiring to receive an allocation [of these funds]
  shall submit an application . . . .”  § 14005 (emphasis supplied).  While there
  is some debate as to the proper grammatical construction of this statutory
  phrase, I conclude that § 14005 was drafted to accommodate the two methods, certification
  or concurrent resolution, by which a state can demonstrate that it desires SFS
  Funds.  South Carolina has manifested its desire for SFS Funds through the
  concurrent resolution method provided for in § 1607(b). Once a state has
  expressed its desire to receive SFS funds through § 1607, it is my view that
  the state’s governor is obligated to obtain those funds by complying with the
  requirements in § 14005. 
If a state expresses its desire to receive ARRA funds through a
  concurrent resolution, § 1607(c) of the ARRA then requires that “funding to the
  State will be for distribution to local governments, councils of government,
  public entities, and public-private entities within the State either by formula
  or at the State’s discretion.”  Here, through the adoption of the annual
  appropriations act, the General Assembly has provided for the distribution of
  the SFS Funds and thus has met the mandate of § 1607(c).  In short, South Carolina has fulfilled all the requirements set forth in federal law to demonstrate
  that it desires SFS Funds.  
The
  Governor contends that the appropriations act offends the South Carolina Constitution’s
  separation of powers clause[4] to the extent it purports to compel him to apply for the SFS Funds.  As
  explained above, I read § 1607 to give the governor of a state or, under
  certain circumstances, its legislature, the authority to determine whether a
  state desires ARRA funds.  Under my view of the ARRA, the Governor’s obligation
  to complete the SFS Funds application process found in § 14005 arises from the
  General Assembly’s compliance with the provisions of § 1607(b) and (c), and is
  not based upon the appropriations act itself.  The appropriations act is
  relevant to my analysis only to the extent that it fulfills the requirement of
  § 1607(c).  I perceive no separation of powers issue here.
Petitioners
  request the Court issue a declaratory judgment that, the General Assembly
  having fulfilled the requirements of § 1607(b) and (c), the Governor and the
  executive branch must perform any and all acts necessary for the State to receive
  SFS Funds from the federal government.  I would grant this relief.


[1] Pub. L. 111-5 (Feb. 17, 2009).
[2] U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, cl. 1.
[3] Letter from the Governor to the Director of The
  Office of Management and Budget dated April 3, 2009.
[4] S.C. Const. art. I, § 8.

description: Appellants filed suit against Respondents asserting several causes of action stemming from Hilton Head Regional Medical Centerâ€™s (HHRMC) administration of hundreds of unauthorized therapeutic cardiac catheterizations.  The trial court dismissed Appellantsâ€™ complaint in its entirety.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Robert J. Dema,
      Edward M. Finn, and Joyce E. Gadson, on behalf of themselves and all others
      similarly situated, Appellants,
				v.
				Tenet Physician
      Services- Hilton Head, Inc. and AMISUB (Hilton Head), Inc., collectively
      d/b/a Hilton Head Regional Medical Center, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Beaufort County
Â Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26663
Heard March 18, 2009 - Filed June 8, 2009Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				A. Hoyt
  Rowell, T. Christopher Tuck, Michael J. Brickman, all of Richardson, Patrick,
  Westbrook & Brickman, of Mt. Pleasant, Daniel S. Haltiwanger, of
  Richardson, Patrick, Westbrook & Brickman, of Barnwell, Mark C. Tanenbaum
  and John P. Algar, both of Charleston, for Appellants.
				E.
  Douglas Pratt-Thomas, of Pratt-Thomas & Walker, of Charleston, William H. Jordan and Samuel R. Rutherford, both of Alston & Bird, of Atlanta, for Respondents.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: Â Appellants
  filed suit against Respondents asserting several causes of action stemming from
  Hilton Head Regional Medical Centerâ€™s (HHRMC) administration of hundreds of
  unauthorized therapeutic cardiac catheterizations.Â  The trial court dismissed
  Appellantsâ€™ complaint in its entirety.Â  We affirm.Â  
Factual/Procedural
  Background
Between 1997 and
  2000, HHRMC[1] performed over 200 unauthorized therapeutic
  cardiac catheterizations (TCCs) in violation of State Certification of Need and
  Health Facility Licensure Act (CON Act), S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-110, et seq. (Supp. 2008).Â  The Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) issued
  a fine of $100 for each unauthorized procedure for a total of $24,200.
In
  February 2006, Appellants filed their complaint alleging that they received
  unauthorized TCCs at HHRMC in 1998 or 1999.Â  Appellants asserted claims for
  violations of South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act (SCUTPA), S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 39-5-10, et seq. (Supp. 2008) violations, unjust enrichment,
  battery, and outrage.Â  The complaint also referenced a federal qui tam complaint filed against HHRMC by Dr. Lowman, a doctor formerly employed with
  Respondents, alleging that HHRMC fraudulently billed Medicare as a result of
  performing the unauthorized TCCs.Â  Respondents removed the complaint to
  federal court pursuant to federal question jurisdiction based on the reference
  to the Lowman complaint, but the district court remanded the case to state
  court. 
Respondents
  filed a motion to dismiss, and following a hearing, the trial court dismissed
  the complaint in its entirety.Â  The trial court found that it lacked subject
  matter jurisdiction over the case since DHEC was the sole agency empowered with
  authority to resolve claims regarding violations of the CON Act.Â  The trial
  court further ruled that even if it had jurisdiction, Appellants could not
  maintain an unjust enrichment or SCUTPA claim because a private right of action
  did not exist for violations of the CON Act.Â  The trial court dismissed the SCUTPA
  claims on the additional grounds that the claims fell under the regulatory
  exception, the allegations were not capable of repetition, and SCUTPA prohibits
  class action suits.[2]Â  
We
  certified the case pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and Appellants present the
  following issues[3] for review:

	
		
			I.   
			Did the trial court err in ruling that it did not 
			have subject matter jurisdiction over the case?
 
		
		
			II. 
			Did the trial court err in ruling that the CON Act 
			did not create a private cause of action?
 
		
		
			III.  
			Did the trial court err in dismissing the SCUTPA claims?
 
		
		
			IV. 
			Did the trial court err in dismissing 
			Appellantâ€™s unjust enrichment claim?
		
	

Standard of Review
Generally,
  in considering a motion to dismiss,
  the trial court must base its ruling solely upon the allegations set forth on
  the face of the complaint.Â  Doe
    v. Greenville County Sch. Dist., 375
  S.C. 63, 66-67, 651 S.E.2d 305, 307 (2007).Â 
  The motion may not be sustained if the facts alleged in the complaint
  and the inferences that can be drawn therefrom would entitle the plaintiff to
  relief under any theory.Â  Id.
Law/Analysis
I. Subject Matter
  Jurisdiction
Appellants
  argue that the trial court erred in ruling that it did not have subject matter
  jurisdiction to hear the case.Â  We agree.
Subject matter jurisdiction is the power to hear and determine cases of the general class to
  which the proceedings in question belong.Â  Skinner
    v. Westinghouse Elec. Corp., 380
  S.C. 91, 93, 668 S.E.2d 795, 796 (2008).Â 
  South Carolina trial courts are vested with general original jurisdiction in
  civil and criminal cases, except those cases in which exclusive jurisdiction
  shall be given to inferior courts.Â  S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 11.Â  In determining
  whether the Legislature has given another entity exclusive jurisdiction over a
  case, a court must look to the relevant statute.Â  See Unisys Corp. v. South Carolina Budget and
    Control Bd. Div. of Gen. Servs. Info. Mgmt. Office, 346
  S.C. 158, 175, 551 S.E.2d 263, 273 (2001) (examining the language of the
  statute to determine the legislative intent regarding exclusive jurisdiction).Â  
We hold that the
  trial court erred in ruling it did not have subject matter jurisdiction over
  this case.Â  Appellants did not file suit
  seeking a determination from the trial court that HHRMC was acting in violation
  of the CON Act.Â  Rather, Appellantsâ€™ suit involved civil claims arising out HHRMCâ€™s
  violations of the CON Act, which DHEC had already determined HHRMC had
  committed.Â  While DHEC has exclusive subject matter jurisdiction to determine
  whether a violation has occurred,[4] it does not have subject matter jurisdiction to hear civil claims
  for damages resulting from those violations.[5] Â Therefore, we hold that the trial courtâ€™s ruling was erroneous. 
II. Private Cause of Action
Appellants argue
  that the trial court erred in ruling that the CON Act did not create a private
  cause of action.Â  We disagree.
Where not expressly
  provided, a private right of action may be created by implication if the
  legislation was enacted for the special benefit of the private party. Â Citizens for Lee County, Inc. v. Lee County, 308 S.C. 23, 28, 416 S.E.2d 641,
  645 (1992).Â  If the overall purpose of the statute is to
  aid society and the public in general, the statute is not enacted for the
  special benefit of a private party.Â  Adkins v. South Carolina Dept. of Corr.,
  360 S.C. 413, 419, 602 S.E.2d 51, 54 (2004). 
We
  hold that no private right of action may be implied from the CON Act.Â  The
  purpose of the Act is:


	to
  promote cost containment, prevent unnecessary duplication of health care
  facilities and services, guide the establishment of health facilities and
  services which will best serve public needs, and ensure that high quality services
  are provided in health facilities in this State.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-120
  (Supp. 2008).Â  In our view, this expressly-stated purpose clearly indicates
  that in enacting the CON Act, the Legislature intended to advance the quality
  of healthcare provided in this State for all people receiving the care, not for
  a particular individual.Â  The fact that the Act considers violations a
  misdemeanor and imposes fines as well as license denial, revocation, or
  suspension further supports the conclusion that the CON Act does not create a
  private cause of action by implication.Â  See Adkins, 360 S.C. at 419,
  602 S.E.2d at 51 (acknowledging that a violation of the Prevailing Wage Statute
  is considered a misdemeanor and thus finding that nothing in the statute
  indicated a legislative intent to create civil liability for a violation).Â  In
  other words, the enforcement mechanism of the CON Act is DHECâ€™s authority to impose
  sanctions and not civil liability. 
For these reasons,
  we hold that the CON Act does not provide a private cause of action for
  violations.
III. SCUTPA
Appellants argue
  the trial court erred in dismissing their SCUTPA claim.Â  We disagree.
Appellants filed this suit as a class
  action.Â  Class action suits are representative lawsuits in which a single
  individual or a small group of individuals represent the interests of a larger
  group.Â  SCUTPA, however, prohibits a plaintiff from bringing a suit in a
  representative capacity.Â  See Â§Â§ 39-5-20 and 140 (providing that that
  any person who suffers a loss as a result of an unfair act or practice may
  â€œbring an action individually, but not in a representative capacityâ€). Federal
  courts have recognized that class action suits may not be brought pursuant to
  SCUTPA.Â  See Gunnells v. Healthplan Servs., Inc., 348 F.3d 417 (4th Cir. 2003)
  (impliedly affirming the district courtâ€™s refusal to certify a SCUTPA suit as a
  class action pursuant to Â§ 39-5-140); In re Microsoft Corp.
    Antitrust Litig., 127 F. Supp 2d 702, 727 (D. Md. 2001) (dismissing class
  action claims under SCUTPA because â€œ[t]hat Act does not permit suits for
  damages to be maintained as class actions.â€).Â  Additionally, other
  jurisdictions with a similar provision in their Unfair Trade Practices Acts
  have also reached the conclusion that such a claim may not be maintained as a
  class action suit. See Danielson v. DBM, Inc., No. 1:05-CV-2091-WSD,
  slip op. at 4 (N.D. Ga. August 11, 2005); Morris
    v. Sears, Roebuck and Co., 765 So.2d 419, 421 (La. App. 2000) (recognizing that a
  provision in the Louisiana Unfair Trade Practices Act providing that a
  plaintiff â€œmay bring an action individually but not in a representative
  capacityâ€ expressly prohibits a private class action).Â  Accordingly, because SCUTPA claims may not be maintained
  in a class action law suit, the trial court properly dismissed Appellantsâ€™
  claim.[6]
IV. Unjust Enrichment
Finally, Appellants
  argue the trial court erred in dismissing their unjust enrichment claim.Â  We disagree. 

A
  party may be unjustly enriched when it has and retains benefits or money which
  in justice and equity belong to another.Â  Unjust enrichment is an equitable
  doctrine which permits the recovery of that amount the defendant has been
  unjustly enriched at the expense of the plaintiff.Â  Ellis v. Smith Grading
    and Paving, Inc., 294 S.C. 470, 473, 366 S.E.2d 12, 14 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  
HHRMC
  argues that Hambrick v. GMAC Mortg. Corp., 370 S.C. 118, 634 S.E.2d 5 (Ct. App.
  2006) is directly on point and thus precludes Appellantsâ€™ unjust enrichment
  claim.Â  In Hambrick, the plaintiffs brought several causes of action,
  including an unjust enrichment claim, against GMAC after
  GMAC allegedly engaged in the unauthorized practice of law (UPL) in
  preparing loan documents for the plaintiffs.Â  Citing Linder v. Ins. Claims
    Consultants, Inc., 348 S.C. 477, 483, 560 S.E.2d 612, 616 (2002), the court
  of appeals determined that there was no private right of action for UPL, and
  therefore, held that the trial court properly dismissed the case.Â  
Appellants,
  on the other hand, argue that Hambrick is not controlling and that Inoco v. Jensen Constr. Co., 622 F.2d 1291 (8th Cir. 1980) is instructive.Â  In Inoco,
  Jensen Construction was the lowest bidder on a small-business construction
  contract and Inoco was the next lowest bidder.Â  After the contract was awarded
  to Jensen, Inoco discovered that Jensen falsely certified itself as a
  â€œsmall-businessâ€ under the Small Business Act (SBA) regulations and therefore should
  not have been awarded the bid.Â  Inoco filed an unjust enrichment claim against
  Jensen.Â  The Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals held that although no private
  right of action existed under the SBA, the court could look to the SBA to
  determine whether a party has committed fraud or has been unjustly enriched.Â  
In the
  instant case, we find that HHRMC was undoubtedly unjustly enriched.Â  HHRMC was
  not authorized to perform TCCs, but did so and realized a benefit in the form
  of tremendous revenues and profits from performing these highly lucrative, yet
  unlawful, procedures.Â  Nonetheless, even if we were to hold that Hambrick was not controlling and allow independent actions against a facility that
  violates the CON Act, just as the Inoco court allowed an independent
  action for violations of the SBA, Appellantsâ€™ claim still fails.Â  Whether HHRMC
  was authorized to perform TCCs was irrelevant to Appellantsâ€™ need for the
  procedure, and Appellants would have received the TCCs from another provider
  had HHRMC not administered them.Â  In other words, Appellants have suffered no
  injury even if HHRMC has been unjustly enriched.Â  For these reasons, we must
  affirm the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of Appellantsâ€™ unjust enrichment claim.Â  
Conclusion
Our
  Legislature enacted the CON Act with the purpose of promoting quality
  healthcare to the citizens of South Carolina, and when healthcare facilities
  perform unauthorized medical procedures, they act in direct derogation of this purpose.Â 
  This problem is further exacerbated by inadequate penalties that a defiant
  facility receives for violating the Act.Â  While DHEC is authorized to issue
  fines and even though a violation is considered a misdemeanor, such sanctions
  amount to a mere â€œslap on the wristâ€ penalty and provide no meaningful deterrence,
  especially in light of the lucrative and profitable nature of some medical
  procedures.Â  In our view, HHRMCâ€™s actions are no different than an unauthorized
  healthcare provider from a foreign country setting up its operations in South
  Carolina, a scenario which would certainly cause great outrage.Â  Nonetheless,
  we can find nothing in the CON Act implying a private cause of action and
  Appellants cannot show that they were injured as a result of HHRMCâ€™s actions.Â 
  Accordingly, we must affirm the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of Appellantsâ€™
  complaint.
WALLER,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Respondents Tenet Physician Services-Hilton Head, Inc. and AMISUB (Hilton
  Head), Inc. own and operate HHRMC.
[2] The trial court also dismissed the battery and outrage claim, but Appellants
  have not appealed these rulings.
[3] Appellants also appeal the trial courtâ€™s ruling regarding recovery of Medicare
  and Medicaid payments.Â  Specifically, the trial court ruled that Appellants lacked
  standing to recover Medicare or Medicaid payments, were judicially estopped
  from seeking such payments, and any such claims were preempted by the federal
  False Claims Act.Â  We decline to address this issue since Appellants contend
  that they are not seeking such payments.
[4] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  44-7-140 (Supp. 2008) (providing that â€œ[DHEC] is designated the
  sole state agency for control and administration of the granting of
  Certificates of Need and licensure of health facilities and other activities
  necessary to be carried out under this article.â€).Â  
[5] Whether the CON Act creates a private cause of action or whether a
  party may maintain an independent civil private cause of action seeking damages
  as a result of CON Act violations, both cases over which a trial court would
  have subject matter jurisdiction and discussed infra, is a distinct
  issue from whether a healthcare facility violated the CON Act, a case over
  which DHEC has exclusive subject matter jurisdiction.Â  See Â§ 44-7-140.
[6] Although the trial court properly dismissed the claim pursuant to SCUTPAâ€™s
  prohibition of class action suits, it erroneously dismissed the claim pursuant
  to the regulatory exception, which provides that SCUTPA does not apply to:
  â€œactions or transactions permitted under laws administered by any regulatory
  body.â€Â  Â§ 39-5-40.Â  This exception exempts an entity from liability where its
  actions are lawful or where it â€œâ€˜does something required by law, or does
  something that would otherwise be a violation of the Act, but which is allowed
  under other statutes or regulations.â€™â€ Ward v. Dick Dyer & Assocs.,
  304 S.C. 152, 155, 403 S.E.2d 310, 312 (1991), quoting Skinner v. Steele,
  730 S.W.2d 335, 337 (Tenn. Ct. App. 1987).Â  This provision lends no support to
  HHRMC because Appellants alleged HHRMC performed unauthorized TCCs.Â
