THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Raymond Bovain,
      Jr., as Personal Representative of the Estate of Willor Dean Bovain, Appellant,
				v.
				Canal
      Insurance, Roy R. Greene d/b/a Rusty Greene Tree Service, and John R.
      Frazier, Inc., Defendants,
				Of Whom Canal
      Insurance is the Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26664
Heard March 5, 2009 - Filed June 8, 2009Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Carl B.
  Grant, of Orangeburg; and Richard A. Harpootlian and Graham L. Newman, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
				BrianÂ 
  Dumas, of Peake Fowler & Associates, of Columbia, and Robert D. Moseley,
  Jr., Â of Smith, Moore, Leatherwood, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BEATTY:Â  Raymond
  Bovain, Jr. brought this declaratory judgment action as the Personal
  Representative of the Estate of Willor Dean Bovain, his late wife, after she
  died in a collision with a logging truck that was insured by Canal Insurance.Â 
  Bovain asserted the truck driver was a â€œmotor carrierâ€ and sought reformation
  of the insurance policy to increase its limit of coverage to $750,000 pursuant
  to 23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 38-414 (Supp. 2008) (requiring heightened insurance
  coverage for â€œmotor carriersâ€).Â  Canal Insurance opposed the request and sought
  a declaration that the $40,000 of combined limits coverage carried on the truck
  was sufficient under South Carolina law.Â  Both parties moved for summary
  judgment.[1]Â 
  The circuit court granted summary judgment to Canal Insurance, finding the
  truck driver was not a â€œmotor carrierâ€ under state law and was not subject to
  the insurance requirement of Regulation 38-414.Â  Bovain appeals. Â We reverse
  and remand for entry of summary judgment in favor of Bovain.
FACTS
On September 9,
  2004, Bovainâ€™s wife died after she collided with a logging truck driven by Roy
  R. Greene.Â  Greene was pulling onto Interstate 26 from the side of the road
  when Bovainâ€™s wife struck him from behind.Â  Her car burst into flames and she
  died at the scene.Â  
Greene, who does
  business as Rusty Greene Tree Service, is in the business of hauling cut trees
  to various pulpwood and paper companies.Â  At the time of the accident, Greene
  was picking up logs from a worksite beside Interstate 26 and planned to take
  them to a paper mill in Eastover, South Carolina.Â  Greene had insurance
  coverage on the logging truck with Canal Insurance in a combined single
  liability limit of $40,000.Â  The truck was a ten-wheeler weighing approximately
  26,000 pounds that Greene had purchased used.Â  It had an attachment on the
  front for moving logs.Â  
On November 4,
  2005, Bovain filed this declaratory judgment action against Canal Insurance asserting
  Greene was a â€œmotor carrierâ€ and seeking to reform the insurance policy to
  increase the coverage to $750,000 pursuant to 23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 38-414.Â 
  Under Regulation 38-414, which is applicable to â€œmotor carriers,â€ trucks
  weighing 10,000 or more pounds (GVWR)[2] that carry non-hazardous material must be insured under a policy carrying at
  least $750,000 of coverage.Â  Bovain argued Greene was a motor carrier and thus
  was subject to the increased level of coverage required by Regulation 38-414.Â Â Â  
Canal Insurance
  asserted Greene transported his own property and thus was not a motor carrier.Â 
  Canal Insurance further argued that, even if Greene was a motor carrier, he was
  exempt from Regulation 38-414 because he was using his truck to haul cut trees.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 38-407(4) (Supp. 2008) (providing an exemption
  for â€œ[l]umber haulers engaged in transporting lumber and logs from the forest
  to the shipping points in this Stateâ€).Â  
The circuit court
  granted summary judgment to Canal Insurance.Â  Bovain appeals, alleging the
  circuit court erred (1) in ruling the insurance policy at issue cannot be
  reformed to increase the limit of coverage to $750,000 pursuant to 23A S.C.
  Code Ann. Regs. 38-414, (2) in finding Greene was not a â€œmotor carrierâ€ within
  the purview of Regulation 38-414, and (3) in finding that, even if Greene
  qualified as a â€œmotor carrier,â€ he fell within the â€œlumber haulerâ€ exception
  contained in 23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 38-407(4) and thus was exempt from
  Regulation 38-414â€™s coverage requirement.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Rule 56(c) of the
  South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provides that a trial court may grant a
  motion for summary judgment â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to
  interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any,
  show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving
  party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  
â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact
  exist, the court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences that may be drawn from the
  evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Brockbank v.
    Best Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 378-79, 378, 534 S.E.2d 688,
  692 (2000).Â  An appellate court reviews the granting of summary judgment
  under the same standard applied by the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Id. at 379, 534 S.E.2d at 692.Â  
(A)Â  Insurance for Motor
  Carriers Under Regulation 38-414 
Bovain first asserts the circuit court erred in
  finding Greene was not a â€œmotor carrierâ€ subject to the increased minimum
  insurance requirements of Regulation 38-414.Â  We agree.
South Carolina law
  contains both statutes and regulations governing â€œmotor carriers.â€Â  At issue in
  this case is Regulation 38-414, which provides for heightened insurance requirements
  for certain â€œmotor carriersâ€ for hire as part of a group of Economic
  Regulations.
Specifically,
  Regulation 38-414 provides that â€œ[i]nsurance policies and surety bonds for
  bodily injury and property damage will have limits of liability not less thanâ€
  $750,000 per incident for trucks weighing 10,0000 or more pounds GVWR that
  carry non-hazardous freight.Â  23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 38-414 (Supp. 2008).Â 
  This regulation applies â€œto any person . . . or corporation which is . . .
  engaged as a motor carrier for hire within the State of South Carolinaâ€ unless
  they are otherwise exempted.Â  23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 38-401 (Supp. 2008).
A â€œcarrier,â€ in the
  legal sense, refers to one who undertakes to transport persons or property from
  place to place.Â  Huckabee Transp. Corp. v. W. Assurance Co., 238 S.C.
  565, 121 S.E.2d 105 (1961); Windham v. Pace, 192 S.C. 271, 6
  S.E.2d 270 (1939).Â  The term â€œmotor carrierâ€ includes â€œboth a common carrier by
  motor vehicle and a contract carrier by motor vehicle.â€Â  23A S.C. Code Ann.
  Regs. 38-402(8) (Supp. 2008).
Statutory law also
  controls motor carriers.Â  Section 58-23-20 provides:Â  â€œNo corporation or person
  . . . may operate a motor vehicle for the transportation of persons or property for compensation on an improved public highway in this Stateâ€ without
  complying with the applicable statutory provisions and the regulations and
  authority of the Public Service Commission.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 58-23-20 (Supp.
  2008) (emphasis added).
â€œThe term â€˜motor
  vehicle carrierâ€™ [as used in the portion of the Code concerning the regulation
  of motor vehicles for compensation] means every corporation or person . . .
  owning, controlling, operating or managing any motor propelled vehicle . . .
  used in the business of transporting persons or property for compensation over any improved public highway in this State[.]â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  58-23-10(4) (1977) (emphasis added).
The phrase â€œfor
  compensationâ€ as used in section 58-23-20 â€œmeans a return in money or property
  for transportation of persons or property by motor vehicle over public
  highways, whether paid, received or realized, and shall specifically include
  any profit realized on the delivered price of cargo where title or ownership is
  temporarily vested during transit in the carrier as a subterfuge for the
  purpose of avoiding regulation under this chapter.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 58-23-30 (1977).
In the case before
  us, the circuit court found Greene was a private carrier, not a motor carrier,
  so he was not subject to the insurance requirements in Regulation 38-414.Â  The
  circuit court found â€œGreene is not a motor carrier for hire because he does not
  transport the property of others for compensation.â€Â  The circuit court stated:Â 
  â€œGreene cuts trees, picks up trees that have been cut and abandoned to him by
  other tree services, and hauls and sells those trees to pulpwood and paper
  companies.Â  When he sells the trees, he receives their market value, not a fee
  for handling them as cargo.Â  Greene is transporting and selling his own
  property and is not subject to regulation as a motor carrier for hire.â€Â  
The circuit court
  stated because Greene is a private carrier, â€œhe is not required to carry a
  certificate of authority issued by the Public Service Commission (PSC) . . . .Â 
  Instead, as a private carrier, Greene is governed by the general South Carolina
  Financial Responsibility Act, which, at the time of the collision, only
  required him to maintain minimum liability limits of $15,000/$30,000/$10,000
  or, in this case, combined single limits of $40,000,â€ citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  38-77-140.Â  The circuit court concluded that reformation of the policy issued
  by Canal Insurance to provide the minimum coverage for a motor carrier of
  $750,000 was not appropriate as â€œGreene complied with the law as it applies to private
  carriers.â€Â  
On appeal, Bovain
  contends the circuit court erred in finding that Greene is not a motor carrier
  subject to the increased limits of coverage in Regulation 38-414.Â  Bovain asserts
  the temporary transfer of ownership of the logs to Greene may not be used to
  avoid application of the limits of coverage in Regulation 38-414.Â  
Canal Insurance, in
  contrast, maintains Greene is not compensated for transporting the wood;
  rather, Greene owns the trees and takes them to the mills of his choice.Â  Canal
  Insurance asserts â€œ[t]he fact that Greene is paid by a timber broker [John
  Frazier] for providing logs to various mills and pulpwood producers does not
  contradict the fact that he is selling the wood as his own property . . . .â€Â  
During his deposition
  testimony, Greene testified that, on the date of the accident with Bovainâ€™s
  wife, he had responded to a call from a tree cutting service that was removing
  trees under a contract with the highway department near Interstate 26.Â  Greene
  testified that he was asked to pick up the wood, which he was told â€œwas on I-26
  in between the Lexington hospital and no. 1 exit going toward Charleston.â€Â 
  Greene had loaded his truck with cut wood on the side of Interstate 26 and then
  was pulling onto Interstate 26 to take it to a mill in Eastover when the
  collision occurred.Â  
Greene stated he
  had worked with John Frazier for approximately ten years.Â  Greene testified
  that he picks up wood at various locations for himself, but stated, â€œI just
  sell it through Frazier. Â Thatâ€™s how I get rid of it.â€Â  Greene does not charge
  anything for picking up the wood because he plans to sell it.Â  Greene conceded that
  when he took the lumber to the mills, he would not be paid at that time.Â 
  Instead, Frazier would pay him based on the amount of wood procured.Â  Greene
  acknowledged that Frazier â€œtells me where I can go with it.â€Â  Greene stated he
  did not talk directly to the mills, but did so only â€œ[t]hrough Frazier.â€Â Â Â  
Greene stated he was
  under Frazierâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation coverage.Â  In addition, Frazier loaned
  him money to purchase his logging trucks, including the one that was involved
  in this accident.Â  Greene stated he purchased the insurance policy with a
  combined single limit of $40,000 as that was the absolute minimum level he
  could acquire based on the truckâ€™s weight.[3]Â  
John Frazier, a
  self-identified broker and timber dealer, testified in his deposition that
  Greene would take the wood to the mill, which would then issue a ticket, and
  Greene would bring the ticket to him.Â  Frazier would then take out a percentage
  of the amount for â€œhandlingâ€ and give Greene the remainder.Â  
Frazier
  acknowledged that when Greene brought logs to a mill, the sale price would be
  credited to his [Frazierâ€™s] account, and Greene would bring him the ticket.Â 
  Frazier stated he has contracts with the paper companies and they pay him, not
  Greene.Â  Frazier frequently gave â€œadvancesâ€ to Greene, and usually kept about
  ten to twenty percent of the proceeds for being the â€œmiddle manâ€ and then gave
  Greene the remainder.Â  Frazier stated he usually paid Greene and others,
  including loggers (those he subcontracted with to cut the wood) and vendors,
  every Friday.Â  Frazier stated Greene procured virtually all of the wood on his
  own.Â  When asked why Greene did not just sell the wood himself, i.e., why did
  he need him [Frazier], Frazier conceded:Â  â€œHe doesnâ€™t.â€ Â However, Frazier
  explained that the mills like to work with people they know, and he had a
  reputable company with sixty years of experience in the business so they liked
  doing business with him.Â  
We find the
  evidence in the record indicates that Greene sold the logs in the name of John
  Frazier for at least ten years, that the mills paid John Frazier, not Greene,
  and that Frazier directed him as to which mills to sell to.Â  Under these
  circumstances, Frazier is the true seller, and Greene is merely transporting the
  logs for the convenience of Frazier.Â  
The fact that
  Greene temporarily held title to the logs does not preclude the finding that he
  was being paid to transport materials.Â  See S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 58-23-30 (1977) (The phrase â€œfor compensationâ€ as used in section
  58-23-20 â€œmeans a return in money or property for transportation of persons or
  property by motor vehicle over public highways, whether paid, received or
  realized, and shall specifically include any profit realized on the delivered
  price of cargo where title or ownership is temporarily vested during transit in
  the carrier as a subterfuge for the purpose of avoiding regulation under this
  chapter.â€).Â  
Since Greene knew
  when he was picking up the logs that he would promptly sell them in the name of
  John Frazier, Greene was merely holding title temporarily until he took the
  logs to the mill.Â  Thus, we conclude Greene was transporting the wood for
  Frazier and hold that he qualifies as a motor carrier under South Carolina
  law.Â  See 13 Am. Jur. 2d Carriers Â§ 5 (2000) (â€œThe nature of a
  carrier is determined by its method of operation.Â  Thus, it has been said that
  a carrierâ€™s status is determined by what it does rather than by what it says it
  does.â€ (footnote omitted)). Â 
(B)Â  Exemption for Lumber
  Haulers in Regulation 38-407(4)
Bovain next argues
  the circuit court erred in determining that, â€œ[e]ven assuming . . . Greene is a
  â€˜motor vehicle carrierâ€™ for hire, Greene would be exempt from the insurance
  requirements in Title 58 and under the regulations because he is a lumber
  hauler.â€Â  [R 7]Â  Bovain asserts Canal Insurance failed to establish that the
  lumber hauler exemption was applicable here.Â  We agree. Â 
Regulation 38-407
  provides for exemptions from the Economic Regulations for certain motor
  carriers.Â  In particular, Regulation 38-407(4) provides an exemption for qualifying
  â€œ[l]umber haulers engaged in transporting lumber and logs from the forest to the shipping points in this State.â€Â  23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 38-407(4)
  (Supp. 2008) (emphasis added).Â  The phrase â€œfrom the forestâ€ is not defined in
  the regulation.Â  
Bovain argued the
  exemption did not apply because Greene was not transporting logs â€œfrom the
  forest,â€ but was, instead, picking up logs left by a tree cutting operation
  that was working in an area along Interstate 26.Â  The circuit court found
  Bovain was â€œreading the exemption in an overly-restrictive mannerâ€ and that
  â€œ[t]his exemption is a â€˜farm to marketâ€™ exemption and applies when an
  individual hauls an agricultural product from the point of production to the
  point of sale.â€Â Â Â  
On appeal, Bovain
  contends the circuit court interpreted this exemption in a manner that is
  inconsistent with the plain language of the regulation.Â  Bovain asserts Greene
  was not a hauler engaged in transporting logs â€œfrom the forest,â€ and carriers
  such as Greene who regularly utilize the Stateâ€™s highways to carry on their
  business are not entitled to the protection of the â€œfarm-to-marketâ€ exemption,
  which was intended to exempt the infrequent transportation of agricultural
  products to the market, not the almost daily transportation of items for profit
  as done by Greene.Â  
The burden of
  proving the entitlement to an exemption is on the party asserting the
  exemption.Â  See Ga. Cas. & Sur. Co. v. Jernigan, 305
  S.E.2d 611, 614 (Ga. Ct. App. 1983) (finding a truck owner and its insurer
  failed to meet their burden of showing a pulpwood truck came within the terms
  of an exemption from the general statutory definition of â€œmotor contract
  carrierâ€ where they did not prove the truck was engaged exclusively in the
  transportation of agricultural products from the forest to the mill or other
  place of manufacture).Â  In this case, the burden was on Canal Insurance to
  prove the exemption was applicable, and there was no burden on Bovain in this
  regard.Â  See id. (stating there is no burden on the opposing
  party).
In general,
  exemptions are an act of legislative grace and, as such, they are to be
  strictly and reasonably construed.Â  See State v. Life Ins. Co.,
  254 S.C. 286, 293-94, 175 S.E.2d 203, 206-07 (1970) (noting exemptions are provided
  as an act of legislative grace and are to be construed strictly; a party must
  meet the specified conditions to obtain the benefit conferred by the exemption); see also Village of Lannon v. Wood-Land Contractors, Inc., 672
  N.W.2d 275, 278 (Wis. 2003) (applying a â€œstrict but reasonable constructionâ€ in
  interpreting the application of a personal property tax exemption specifically
  established for logging equipment).Â  
The words used in
  legislation â€œmust be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to
  subtle or forced construction to limit or expand [their] operation.â€Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846
  (1992); see Owen Indus. Prods., Inc. v. Sharpe, 274 S.C.
  193, 195, 262 S.E.2d 33, 34 (1980) (stating the general rule that a
  statutory exemption â€œmust be given its plain, ordinary meaning and must be
  construed strictly against the claimed exemptionâ€); State
    v. Hood, 49 S.C.L. (15 Rich.) 177, 185 (1868) (â€œEvery exemption must be couched in such plain and unambiguous language as to
  satisfy the Court beyond doubt that the Legislature intended to create the exemption. Â Such a right can never arise by mere implication, and all
  laws granting the exemption are to be most strictly construed.â€ (citation omitted)). 
As noted by one
  treatise, â€œforestâ€ is synonymous with â€œwoods,â€ and in its commonly understood
  sense, refers to an extensive area of land covered by trees:

	The
  term â€œwoodâ€ is often used in the plural, with the same force as in the
  singular, as indicating a large and thick collection of trees. Â It is synonymous with â€œforest,â€ and has been so defined, although the latter term is
  sometimes said to imply a wood of considerable extent.Â  Both terms are broad enough to
  include not only the trees but the land on which they stand.Â  When referring to land, the term
  â€œwoodsâ€ means forest lands in their natural state, as distinguished from lands
  cleared and enclosed for 


cultivation, and â€œforestâ€ means a tract of
  land covered with trees, or a tract of woodland with or without enclosed
  intervals of open and uncultivated ground. 
98 C.J.S. Woods and Forests Â§ 1 (2002) (footnotes omitted).
The Supreme Court
  of Illinois has also found that â€œ[a] forest is defined as
  a tract of land covered with trees; a wood, usually of considerable extent.â€Â  Forest
    Preserve Dist. v. Jirsa, 168 N.E. 690, 691 (Ill. 1929) (alteration in
  original); see also People v. Long Island R.R. Co., 110 N.Y.S.
  512, 512 (N.Y. App. Div. 1908) (stating â€œ[a] forest is defined as being â€˜a
  tract of land covered with trees; a wood, usually one of considerable extent; a
  tract of woodland with or without [e]nclosed intervals of open and uncultivated
  groundâ€™â€ (citation omitted)). 
We find the
  definitions above persuasive, and believe that the plain meaning of â€œforestâ€ is
  that it commonly refers to an area of land covered with trees, usually of
  considerable extent.Â  The express language of Regulation 38-407(4) exempts
  those hauling lumber from a forest as the point of production.Â  We see
  no reason to deviate from the plain language of the regulation.
Canal Insurance
  submitted an affidavit from David Findlay, the Administrator of the Motor
  Carrier Services Division (MCS) of the South Carolina Department of Motor
  Vehicles, who stated that â€œMCS interprets this regulation broadly as
  applying to persons like Greene who haul cut trees to lumber processors.Â  These
  exemptions are generally referred to as farm-to-market exemptions.â€Â  (Emphasis
  added.)Â  Similarly, Findlay stated that MCS interprets a statute governing the
  transporting of â€œforest products from the farm to the first marketâ€ to be
  applicable â€œto lumber haulers that haul cut trees to sell to pulpwood
  processors regardless of whether the trees are actually obtained from a
    â€˜forest.â€™â€Â  (Emphasis added.)Â  
MCS applies the
  wrong standard of construction as exemptions are to be construed narrowly, not
  broadly.Â  Further, MCS is not responsible for overseeing the Economic
  Regulations.Â  Consequently, its interpretation is not determinative.
Because Regulation
  38-407 is meant to be a farm-to-market exception, it should apply to areas of
  usual harvesting, not just small areas where trees can be cut.Â  See
    generally 17 Words and Phrases Forestation 43 (Supp. 2008)Â  (citing Cascade
      Floral Prods., Inc. v. Depâ€™t of Labor & Indus., 177 P.3d 124 (Wash. Ct.
  App. 2006), which found that Washingtonâ€™s farm labor contractor act did not
  apply to the brush picking industry as it was not â€œforestationâ€ within the
  meaning of the act because the statutory definition of â€œforestationâ€ required
  cultivation or commercial planting).
A broad
  interpretation of â€œforestâ€ as pertaining to any site where trees are cut would
  eviscerate the language that the exemption applies to those hauling logs â€œfrom
  the forest to the shipping points in this State.â€Â  We do not believe that is a
  reasonable and strict construction of all of the pertinent terms of the
  exemption.Â  The legislature could have easily used broader language and stated
  that anyone hauling lumber or logs is exempted if that were its intent.Â  Cf. State v. Alls, 330 S.C. 528, 531, 500 S.E.2d 781,
  782 (1998) (stating legislative provisions must be read as a whole and
  sections which are part of the same law should be construed together and each
  given effect, if it can be done by any reasonable construction).Â  In this case,
  we conclude Canal Insurance did not meet its burden of establishing that the
  exemption applied here as there was no evidence that Greene was transporting lumber
  and logs â€œfrom the forest to the shipping points in this State.â€Â  
Having found Greene qualified as a motor carrier, and that he did not
  meet the requirements for exemption as a lumber hauler, we hold the policy
  issued by Canal Insurance should be reformed because it does not conform to the
  legal requirements for coverage as mandated by Regulation 38-414.Â  See Hamrick
    v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 270 S.C. 176, 179, 241 S.E.2d 548,
  549 (1978) (â€œA policy of insurance issued pursuant to statutory law must
  at a minimum give the protection therein described.Â  It may give more
  protection but not less, and a policy issued pursuant to the law which gives
  less protection will be interpreted by the court as supplying the protection
  which the legislature  intended.â€); Jordan v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 264
  S.C. 294, 297, 214 S.E.2d 818, 820 (1975) (stating while parties are
  generally permitted to contract as they desire, this freedom is not absolute
  and insurance coverage required by law may not be omitted because statutory
  provisions relating to an insurance contract are part of the contract).
Although Canal
  Insurance argues that reformation is appropriate only for automobile insurance
  policies issued under the South Carolina Financial Responsibility Act, we find
  no reason to impose this arbitrary distinction.Â  
Regulation 38-414
  provides:Â  â€œInsurance policies and surety bonds for bodily injury and property
  damage will have limits of liability not less thanâ€
  $750,000 per incident for trucks weighing 10,0000 or more pounds GVWR that
  carry non-hazardous freight.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 38-414 (emphasis added).Â  The
  South Carolina Legislature has mandated a level of coverage for larger vehicles
  in order to protect the public from the increased dangers inherent with their
  operation on our stateâ€™s highways.Â  It would be unreasonable to interpret the
  language of Regulation 38-414 differently from the mandated coverage under the
  Financial Responsibility Act, as the potential for catastrophic damage is much
  greater with these larger vehicles.Â  We find insurance carriers have a duty to
  issue policies in accordance with the mandated minimum levels of coverage and
  that reformation of the Canal Insurance policy to provide the mandated minimum level
  of coverage is appropriate.
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, we hold Greene is a motor carrier as defined in the South Carolina
  Code and that the exemption from the Economic Regulations for lumber haulers is
  not applicable here.Â  We find insurers have a duty to issue insurance in
  accordance with the mandate of Regulation 38-414 and conclude Bovain is
  entitled to reformation of the Canal Insurance policy to conform to the $750,000
  minimum level of coverage required by Regulation 38-414.Â  Accordingly, we
  reverse and remand for entry of summary judgment in favor of Bovain.

REVERSED AND
  REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, J. and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur. KITTREDGE, J., concurring
  in part, dissenting in part in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â  I concur with the majorityâ€™s holding that Roy R.
  Greene was, as a matter of law, a motor carrier under South Carolina law on the
  accident date of September 9, 2004.Â  I respectfully dissent, however, from the legal
  determination that Greene may not avail himself of the exemption contained in
  Regulation 38-407(4).Â  23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 38-407(4) (Supp. 2008)
  (providing an exemption for â€œ[l]umber haulers engaged in transporting lumber
  and logs from the forest to the shipping points in this Stateâ€).Â  I do not
  believe the applicability or inapplicability of the exemption may be determined
  on the current record to the exacting summary judgment standard.Â  I would
  reverse the grant of summary judgment in favor of Greene and remand to the
  trial court for further consideration of the claimed exemption.


[1]Â  The remaining defendants are not parties to this
  appeal, so all references are solely to Canal Insurance.
[2]Â  â€œGVWRâ€ stands for Gross Vehicle Weight Rating, i.e.,
  the maximum total weight of a vehicle and its cargo.Â  
[3]Â  In his affidavit, Greene stated he explained the
  nature of his business to his insurance agent and requested the minimum
  liability limits allowed by law.Â Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Timothy Mark
          Hopper, Employee/Claimant,
        v.
        Terry Hunt
          Construction, Employer, Uninsured, South Carolina Uninsured Employers Fund,
          Kajima USA, Inc., Statutory Employer, and Zurich American Insurance Company,
          Carrier, Defendants,
        of whom Kajima
          USA, Inc., Statutory Employer, and Zurich American Insurance Company, Carrier
          are, Petitioners,
        and South
          Carolina Employers’ Fund is, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
APPEALS

Appeal from Greenwood County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26665
  Heard February 19, 2009 - Filed June 15,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Steven
          Michael Rudisill and Bradley Horace Smith, both of Â Rudisill, White &
          Kaplan, of Charlotte, for Petitioners.
        Amy V. Cofield, of Lexington, and Latonya Dilligard
          Edwards, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the court of appeals held that
  Petitioner Kajima USA, Inc. (â€œKajimaâ€)
  and Petitioner Zurich
  American Insurance Company (â€œZurichâ€) could not transfer liability to Respondent South Carolina Employersâ€™ Fund
  (â€œFundâ€).Â  Hopper v. Terry Hunt Constr., 373 S.C. 475, 646 S.E.2d 162
  (Ct. App. 2007).Â  This Court granted a writ of certiorari to review that
  decision.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Kajima hired Terry Hunt Construction (â€œHuntâ€) as a
  subcontractor to install pipe at a jobsite in Greenwood, South Carolina.Â  On
  February 19, 2004, Claimant Timothy Mark Hopper suffered an injury while
  working for Hunt at the Greenwood jobsite.Â  Hunt had worked for Kajima on a
  previous project and had presented an Acord Form 25-S Certificate of Insurance indicating
  that Hunt had a workersâ€™ compensation policy.Â  The Certificate indicated that
  the policy was effective from May 2, 2002 through December 31, 2002, and the
  block labeled â€œDESCRIPTION OF OPERATIONS/ LOCATIONSâ€ on the Certificate provided
  certain â€œWorkers Comp Informationâ€ including the project number, the
  subcontract number, and the claim deductible amount.Â  Before beginning work on
  the Greenwood project, Hunt presented another Certificate to Kajima.Â  This
  Certificate showed that the policy was effective from January 1, 2003 through
  December 31, 2003, but unlike the previous Certificate of Insurance, the
â€œDESCRIPTION OF 

OPERATIONS/ LOCATIONSâ€ on
  this Certificate was blank.Â  At the time of Claimantâ€™s accident, Hunt did not
  have workersâ€™ compensation insurance, and Kajima therefore remained liable to
  pay benefits.
The single
  commissioner found that the Claimant suffered a compensable injury, but ruled
  that Kajima and Zurich could
  not shift liability pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415 (Supp. 2008) because the
  Certificate of Insurance did not indicate that Hunt had coverage in South Carolina.[1]Â 
  The full commission adopted the single commissionerâ€™s order in its entirety.Â 
  The circuit court reversed and found that there was no evidence that the
  Certificate of Insurance showed that there was coverage only in Georgia and no coverage in South Carolina.Â  The court of appeals reversed the circuit court, and
  held that Petitioners could not transfer liability because substantial evidence
  in the record showed that Kajima did not comply with the requirements of Â§
  42-1-415.
This
  Court granted Petitionersâ€™ request for a writ of certiorari to review the court
  of appealsâ€™ decision, and Petitioner presents the following issue for review:

  Did the
    court of appeals err in holding that Petitioners could not transfer liability
    to the Fund pursuant to Â§ 42-1-415?

STANDARD OF
REVIEW
This Court must affirm the findings of fact made by the full
  commission if they are supported by substantial evidence. Lark v. Bi-Lo,
    Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 136, 276 S.E.2d 304, 307 (1981).Â  However, the
  appellate court may reverse the full commissionâ€™s decision if it is based on an
  error of law.Â  Therrell v.
    Jerryâ€™s Inc., 370 S.C. 22, 26, 633 S.E.2d 893,
894-95 (2006).Â  The issue of
  interpretation of a statute is a question of law for the Court.Â  Catawba Indian Tribe of South Carolina v. State, 372
S.C. 519, 524, 642 S.E.2d 751, 753 (2007).

LAW/ANALYSIS
Petitioners argue that the court of appeals erred in holding that
  they could not transfer liability.Â  We disagree.
Generally, a higher tier contractor is considered the
  statutory-employer of an employee of a lower tier contractor, and thus, the
  high tier contractor remains liable to pay benefits to an employee if he
  sustains a compensable injury.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-400 (Supp. 2008).Â  Section
  42-1-415(A), however, provides a narrow exception to this rule:

  [U]pon the submission of documentation to the commission that a
    contractor or subcontractor has represented himself to a higher tier
    subcontractor, contractor, or project owner as having workersâ€™ compensation
    insurance at the time the contractor or subcontractor was engaged to perform
    work, the higher tier subcontractor, contractor, or project owner must be
    relieved of any and all liability under this title except as specifically
    provided in this section.

Liability may only be transferred from the higher tier
  contractor to the Fund after the higher tier contractor has properly documented
  the lower tier contractorâ€™s claim that it retains workersâ€™ compensation
  insurance.Â  See Barton v. Higgs, 381 S.C. 367, 371, 674 S.E.2d 145, 147
  (2009) (holding liability could not be transferred to the Fund where the Certificate
  of Insurance was not signed).Â  
We find substantial
  evidence in the record to support the commissionâ€™s finding that Kajima failed
  to comply with the requirements of Â§ 42-1-415(A).Â  The Description of Operation
  box on the Certificate of Insurance was left blank and unlike the previous
  Certificate of Insurance that Kajima accepted, this Certificate contained no
  information regarding the coverage that the policy provided, the deductible
  amount, or the project to which the policy applied. In failing to fill out the
  entire Acord Form, Hunt essentially submitted an incomplete document purporting
  to show that it had a workersâ€™ compensation policy, which Kajima accepted.Â  In
  our view, accepting an incomplete Acord Form does not constitute proper
  documentation.Â  
Furthermore,
  even if Hunt had submitted a completed Certificate, we find an additional
  sustaining ground in the record to affirm the commissionâ€™s decision.Â  We have held that â€œengaged to perform workâ€ means â€œeach
  time a subcontractor is actually hired to perform work.â€Â  See Hardee v.
    McDowell, 381 S.C. 445, 453, 673 S.E.2d 813, 817 (2009) (explaining the
  definition of â€œengaged to perform workâ€ and overruling South Carolina
    Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 602 S.E.2d 81 (Ct. App.
  2004) to the extent it was inconsistent with the opinion).Â  In addition to this
  definition, we now hold that the statuteâ€™s language that the â€œsubcontractor has
  represented himself . . . as having workersâ€™ compensation insuranceâ€ in
  conjunction with â€œat the time the contractor or
  subcontractor was engaged to perform workâ€ encompasses a continuous spectrum
  and includes the complete time frame in which the subcontractor is
  engaged to perform the work.Â  In other words, in order to transfer liability to
  the Fund, a general contractor may not rely upon a Certificate reflecting an
  expired policy as documentation of workersâ€™ compensation insurance.[2] Â To interpret the language in the statute otherwise would allow a general
  contractor to turn a blind eye to information which is readily evident upon a
  cursory inspection of the Certificate.Â  Such an interpretation would lead to an
  absurd result not possibly intended by the legislature.Â  See Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications,
    Inc., 312
  S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994)
  (recognizing that the courts will reject that meaning when
  to accept it would lead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not
  possibly have been intended by the Legislature or would defeat the plain
legislative intention).
In the instant case, in an attempt to establish its right to transfer
  liability for an accident occurring on February 19, 2004, Kajima relied on a document
  explicitly providing that the workersâ€™ compensation coverage expired on
  December 31, 2003.Â  Thus, on January 1, 2004 and any time thereafter, Kajima no
  longer had documentation showing that Hunt had workersâ€™
  compensation insurance at the time Hunt was engaged to perform work.Â  Accordingly,
we hold that Kajima could thus not transfer liability to the Fund.
Section 42-1-415 is
  a very narrow exception to the general rule that a general contractor, as the
  statutory employer, remains liable to pay benefits if a subcontractorâ€™s
  employee sustains an injury.Â  In order to protect the privilege to transfer
  what would otherwise be the general contractorâ€™s responsibility, the statute
  requires the general contractor to take minimal steps to properly document that
  the subcontractor has workersâ€™ compensation insurance.Â  We hold that an
  incomplete Acord Form does not constitute proper documentation and that a
  general contractor may not rely upon a Certificate showing an expired workersâ€™
  compensation policy to show â€œdocumentationâ€ of the subcontractorâ€™s workersâ€™
  compensation insurance.Â  Therefore, we uphold the commissionâ€™s order finding
  Kajima could not transfer liability to the Fund.[3]
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, we affirm the court of appealsâ€™ decision.
KITTREDGE, J.
  and Acting Justice Timothy M. Cain, concur. PLEICONES, J. dissenting in a
  separate opinion in which WALLER, J.
Â concurs.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In September 2003, Kajima
  entered a contract with Hunt Construction for work that commenced in November
  2003.Â  Hunt gave Kajima an Acord 25-S Certificate of Liability Insurance
  indicating Hunt had workers compensation coverage through December 31, 2003.Â 
  Pursuant to S.C. Reg. 67-415, this form, if issued by the carrier for the
  insured and dated, signed, and issued by an authorized representative of the
  carrier, â€œshall serve as documentation of insuranceâ€ for purposes of S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 42-1-415 (Supp. 2008). See Barton v. Higg,Â  381 S.C. 367,
  674 S.E.2d 145(2009) (majority holds compliance with reg.â€™s four requirements
  are necessary to constitute statutory documentation).Â  Here, the form was
  issued, dated, and signed by an authorized representative and thus met Â§
  42-1-415â€™s documentation requirement.Â  Id.Â  Nothing in either the
  statute or the regulation requires, as would the majority here, that the formâ€™s
  block nominated â€œDESCRIPTION OF OPERATIONS/LOCATIONSâ€ be filled in, nor that
  the form contain coverage information or the amount of the deductible.Â  In my
  opinion, there is no evidence in the record to support the ruling of the Full
  Commission, upheld by the Court of Appeals, that Kajima accepted an incomplete
  form and therefore did not have â€œdocumentation of insuranceâ€Â  â€œat the time the
  contractor or subcontractor was engaged Â to perform workâ€, i.e., in September
  2003.Â  
I also dissent from
  the additional sustaining ground found by the majority.Â  Section 42-1-415 (A)
  provides in relevant part:

  Notwithstanding
    any other provision of law, upon the submission of documentation to the
    commission that a contractor or subcontractor has represented himself to a
    higher tier subcontractor, contractor, or project owner as having workersâ€™
    compensation insurance at the time the contractor or subcontractor was engaged
    to perform work, the higher tier subcontractor, contractor, or project owner
    must be relieved of any and all liability under this title except as
    specifically provided in this section.

The statute only requires
  that the lower tier contractor represented himself as having workersâ€™
  compensation insurance (not that it actually has such coverage) â€œat the time
  the contractor or subcontractor was engaged to perform work.â€Â Â  The majority
  interprets that term to mean that the general contractor is under a continuing
  duty to assure itself of coverage during â€œthe complete time frame in which the
  subcontractor is engaged to perform the work.â€Â  I disagree.
In South
  Carolina Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 602 S.E.2d 81
  (Ct. App. 2004) modified on other grounds Hardee v. McDowell, 381
  S.C. 445, 673 S.E.2d 813(2009), the Court of Appeals held that Â§ 42-1-415 does
  not require the general contractor to continue to collect proof of insurance
  after the initial documentation. As Judge Stilwell wrote for the court:

  We are
    loath to read such a requirement into a statute that otherwise contains such
    straightforward language.
  Subsection
    (C) of section 42-1-415 is directed toward the subcontractor, places upon it
    the duty to notify the higher-tier contractor of any lapse in coverage, and
    sets forth the consequences of the subcontractorâ€™s failure to do so when it
    provides, in relevant part:
  
    Knowing and willful failure to notify, by
      certified mail, the higher tierâ€¦contractorâ€¦who originally was provided
      documentation of workersâ€™ compensation coverage of a lapse in coverage within
      five days after the lapse is considered fraud and subjects theâ€¦subcontractor
      who represented himself as having workersâ€™ compensation insurance to the
      penalties for fraud provided by law.
    S.C.
      Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415(C).
  
  The use
    in subsection (C) of the word â€œoriginallyâ€ lends support to the reasoning that
    the information given at the inception of the engagement is the controlling
    factor, negating any statutory requirement on the part of the higher-tier contractor
    to continue collection proof of insurance.
  House, 360 S.C. at 472, 602 S.E.2d at 83.

I
  agree with the Court of Appeals in House and would hold that Kajima is
  relieved of liability under Â§ 42-1-415 because it received an Acord form which
  complied with the regulatory requirements of Reg. 67-415 at the time Hunt was
  engaged to perform the work.
For
  the reasons given above, I respectfully dissent.
WALLER,
J., concurs.


[1] The single commissioner found that the Certificate of Insurance reflected a Georgia workersâ€™ compensation policy and that the Certificate did not indicate that the
policy had an all-states endorsement.
[2] In our view, the plain language of Â§ 42-1-415(A) is
  clear that a subcontractor must represent that he has workersâ€™ compensation coverage
  while he is engaged to perform work.Â  Therefore, we disagree with the dissent
  in looking to section Â§ 42-1-415(C) to clarify Â§ 42-1-415(A).Â  
[3] Although the commission found that Petitioners could not transfer liability
  based on a separate reason, we may affirm the commissionâ€™s decision for any
ground appearing in the record.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR.

description: This medical malpractice case turns on whether the six-year statute of repose in section 15-3-545(A) of the South Carolina Code (2005) applies to causes of action arising under the Tort Claims Act.  We hold that it does and affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Frank W. Kerr,
          as personal representative for the Estate of Marta Butler Kerr, deceased, Appellant,
        v.
        Richland Memorial Hospital, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
  Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No.Â  26667
Heard April 8, 2009 - Filed June 15, 2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Charles
          L. Henshaw, Jr., of Furr, Henshaw & Ohanesian, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        William
          H. Davidson, II and Andrew F. Lindemann, both of Davidson, Morrison &
          Lindemann, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 
JUSTICE
  KITTREDGE: This medical malpractice case turns on whether the six-year statute of repose in section 15-3-545(A) of
  the South Carolina Code (2005) applies to causes of action arising under the
  Tort Claims Act.Â  We hold that it does and affirm.
I.
In 1996, Marta
  Kerrâ€™s excised mole was allegedly misdiagnosed as benign by a pathologist at Richland Memorial Hospital (Hospital).Â  In 2001, Kerr learned the 1996 specimen, upon
  reexamination, contained evidence of melanoma.Â  This misdiagnosis allegedly
  contributed to Kerrâ€™s death in 2002 due to complications of melanoma cancer.Â 
  Kerrâ€™s estate brought suit in 2003 against Hospital, more than six years after
  the alleged misdiagnosis.
The
  trial court granted summary judgment to Hospital after holding the statute of
  repose bars such a case and the Tort Claims Act shields a governmental entity
  from liability for an independent contractorâ€™s actions.Â  The case is before
  this Court via Rule 204(b), SCACR, certification.
II.
The threshold issue
  is whether the statute of repose affects actions against government entities
  under the Tort Claims Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-10 to -220 (Supp. 2008).Â  We hold the statute of repose
  applies.
This
  Court previously held, â€œthe six-year repose provision in [section] 15-3-545 â€˜constitutes an outer limit beyond which a medical
  malpractice claim is barred, regardless of
  whether it has or should have been discovered.â€™â€Â  Harrison v. Bevilacqua, 354 S.C. 129,
    137-38, 580 S.E.2d 109, 113 (2003) (quoting Hoffman v. Powell,
  298 S.C. 338, 339-40, 380 S.E.2d 821, 821 (1989)).Â  In Harrison, this
  Court rejected the continuous treatment rule as such a rule would â€œrun afoul of
  the absolute limitations policy the Legislature has clearly set . . . .â€Â  354
  S.C. at 138, 580 S.E.2d at 114.
Specifically,
  section 15-3-545(A), which has not been amended since Harrison, states:

  In
    any action, . . . to recover
    damages for injury to the person arising out of any medical . . . treatment . .
    . by any licensed health care provider . . . acting within the scope of his
    profession must be commenced within three years from the date of the treatment,
    omission, or operation giving rise to the cause of action or three years from
    date of discovery or when it reasonably ought to have been discovered, not
      to exceed six years from date of occurrence, or as tolled by this section.

(emphasis added).Â 
  Accordingly, the statute of repose provision within section 15-3-545(A) applies
  as an absolute outer limit applicable in any medical malpractice action.
Additionally,
  the statute of repose portion of section 15-3-545(A) is substantive law, unlike
  a statute of limitations, which is procedural law.Â  Capco of Summerville,
    Inc. v. J.H. Gayle Const. Co., Inc., 368 S.C. 137, 142, 628 S.E.2d 38, 41
  (2006) (â€œA statute of limitations is a procedural device that operates as a
  defense to limit the remedy available from an existing cause of action. Â A
  statute of repose creates a substantive right in those protected to be free
  from liability after a legislatively determined period of time.â€).Â  Further,
  when the Legislature enacted the Tort Claims Act, the Legislature knew of the absolute
  time limit imposed by the statue of repose.Â  Berkebile v. Outen, 311
  S.C. 50, 53, 426 S.E.2d 760, 762 (1993) (citation omitted) (â€œA basic
  presumption exists that the legislature has knowledge of previous legislation
  when later statutes are passed on a related subject.â€).
Next,
  we turn to the Tort Claims Act itself.Â  â€œThe primary rule of statutory
  construction is to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the
  legislature.â€Â  Mid-State Auto Auction of Lexington, Inc. v. Altman, 324
  S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996) (citation omitted).Â  The General
  Assembly indicated its intent in the Tort Claims Act by stating, â€œ[t]he provisions of this chapter establishing limitations on and
  exemptions to the liability of the State, its political subdivisions, and employees,
  while acting within the scope of official duty, must be liberally construed in
  favor of limiting the liability of the State.â€Â  S.C. Code
    Ann. Â§ 15-78-20(f) (2005).
When reading the Tort Claims Act as a whole, which we must, we
  hold the above unambiguous expression of intent pervades the entire act.Â  Mid-State Auto, 324 S.C. at 69, 476 S.E.2d at
  692 (â€œIn ascertaining the intent of the
  legislature, a court should not focus on any single section or provision but
  should consider the language of the statute as a whole.â€).Â  Specifically,
  section 15-78-40 of the South Carolina Code (2005) states, â€œ[t]he State, an agency, a political subdivision, and a governmental
  entity are liable for their torts in the same manner and to the same extent as
  a private individual under like circumstances, subject to the limitations upon
  liability and damages, and exemptions from liability and damages, contained
  herein.â€Â  Similarly, section
  15-78-50(b) of the South Carolina Code (2005) provides, â€œ[i]n no
  case is a governmental entity liable for a tort of an employee where that
  employee, if a private person, would not be liable under the laws of this
  State.â€Â  Accordingly, the Legislature clearly intended to limit government
  liability through the Tort Claims Act, and at no time did the Legislature intend
  government liability to exceed that of a private entity.
Conversely, Kerr is inviting this Court to contravene the
  unambiguous intent of the Legislature and expand liability for a government
  hospital beyond a private hospitalâ€™s potential liability.Â  In fact, Kerrâ€™s
  counsel conceded the statute of repose bar in a private action when stating,
  â€œby the time this client came to see me, [the estate] had clearly lost [its]
  right under [section] 15-3-545(A), the right to pursue any private entity because of the
  medical malpractice statute of repose.Â  Six years had transpired.â€Â  To permit
  this medical malpractice action to proceed beyond the statute of repose would
  be to disregard the Tort Claims Act, particularly sections 15-78-40 and 15-78-50(b).
Having
  found Hospital was entitled to summary judgment based on the statute of repose,
  we need not reach the additional ground relied upon by the trial court. Â Wilson v. Moseley, 327 S.C. 144, 147, 488 S.E.2d 862, 864 (1997) (holding if one ground
  proves dispositive, then this Court need not address the remaining grounds
relied on by a trial court when it granted summary judgment).

III.
As the six-year
  statute of repose in section 15-3-545(A) applies
  as an absolute outer limit applicable in any medical malpractice, the
  grant of summary judgment to the Hospital is 
AFFIRMED.
WALLER, ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE, PLEICONES, BEATTY JJ., and Acting
  Justice James E. Moore, concur.

description: In this case, the circuit court denied Appellantsâ€™ motion to enforce arbitration on the grounds that the designated arbitrator had become unavailable and that the unavailability voided the arbitration agreement.  This Court affirmed the circuit court.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        James O. Grant,
          Individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of Lessie Mae P.
          Grant, Respondent,
        v.
        Magnolia
          Manor-Greenwood, Inc; THI of South Carolina at Greenwood, LLC; THI of South
          Carolina, LLC; THI of Baltimore Management, Inc.; THI Holdings, LLC; Trans
          Healthcare, Inc; ABE Briarwood Corporation; and Jane Doe 1-10, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26668
  Heard January 8, 2009 - Filed June 15,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Perry D.
          Boulier and Ginger D. Goforth, both of Holcombe Bomar, of Spartanburg, for
          Appellants.
        Fred
          Thompson, III and Kimberly D. Barone, both of Motley Rice, LLC, of Mount Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this case, the circuit
  court denied Appellantsâ€™ motion to enforce arbitration on the grounds that the
  designated arbitrator had become unavailable and that the unavailability voided
  the arbitration agreement.Â  Appellants appealed, and we certified this case
  pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Respondent
  James O. Grant (â€œRespondentâ€) is the surviving husband of Lessie Mae P. Grant
  (â€œGrantâ€) and the personal representative of her estate.Â  On December 4, 2003,
  at the age of 72, Grant was admitted to the Magnolia Manor-Greenwood nursing
  home.Â  Upon admission, Respondent executed an admission contract as a
  â€œfiduciary partyâ€ on behalf of Grant, who was unable to sign the contract
  herself.Â  The admission contract contained an arbitration provision, which
  states as follows:
VI:Â  Arbitration

  Pursuant
    to the Federal Arbitration Act, any action, dispute, claim, or controversy of
    any kind (e.g., whether in contract or in tort, statutory or common law,
    legal or equitable, or otherwise) now existing or hereafter arising between the
    parties in any way arising out of, pertaining to or in connection with the
    provision of health care services, any agreement between the parties, the
    provision of any other goods or service by the Health Care Center or other
    transactions, contracts or agreements of any kind whatsoever, any past,
    present, or future incidents, omission, acts errors, practices, or occurrence
    causing injury to either party whereby the other party or its agents, employees
    or representatives may be liable, in whole or in part, or any other aspect of
    the past, present, or future relationships between the parties shall be
    resolved by binding arbitration administered by the National Health Lawyers
    Association (the â€œNHLAâ€).[1] 

On
  January 1, 2004, the AHLA amended its rules for arbitrating health care
  liability claims.Â  Under the new rules, the AHLA would only arbitrate claims
  pursuant to arbitration agreements entered into after the alleged injury
  occurred.Â  The parties did not modify the admission contract to reflect the
  AHLA policy change.Â  
On
  January 11, 2005, Grant fell and sustained a large hematoma above her left
  eye.Â  Five days later, Grant died as a result of this injury.Â  Respondent
  instituted this action against Appellants for survival, wrongful death, and
  loss of consortium.Â  
Appellants
  filed a motion to enforce arbitration and stay the proceedings.Â  Respondent
  contested Appellantsâ€™ motion on the grounds that the AHLA no longer arbitrated
  personal injury claims arising under pre-injury arbitration agreements and that
  the arbitration clause was therefore unenforceable.Â  Appellants argued in reply
  that Section 5 of the Federal Arbitration Act (â€œFAAâ€) allowed for the
  appointment of a replacement arbitrator when the designated arbitrator became
  unavailable.Â  Following oral arguments, the circuit court entered an order
  denying Appellantsâ€™ motion to enforce arbitration and stay the proceedings.Â  In
  reviewing the arbitration agreement, the circuit court found that the AHLA had
  become unavailable as an arbitrator, found that the designation of the AHLA as
  arbitrator was a material term of the agreement, and declined to appoint a new
  arbitrator because â€œthere would no longer be a meeting of the minds between the
  parties.â€Â  Appellants present the following questions for review:

  
    I. 
    Did the circuit court err in
  finding the arbitration agreement void and unenforceable because of the
  unavailability of the designated arbitrator?
  
  
  
    II.
    Did the circuit court err in
  failing to appoint a substitute arbitrator or in failing to allow the parties
  to consent to a substitute arbitrator in accordance with Section 5 of the
  Federal Arbitration Act?
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Determinations of arbitrability are
  subject to de novo review.Â  Stokes v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co.,
  351 S.C. 606, 609, 571 S.E.2d 711, 713 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, the circuit
  courtâ€™s factual findings will not
  be overruled if there is any evidence reasonably supporting them. Â Liberty
    Builders, Inc. v. Horton, 336 S.C. 658, 664-665, 521 S.E.2d 749, 753 (Ct. App.
  1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS 
Appellants
  argue that the circuit court erred in denying their motion to enforce
  arbitration due to the AHLAâ€™s unavailability to act as arbitrator. Â We disagree.Â  
We
  observe at the outset that it is the policy of this state to favor the
  arbitration of disputes.Â  Tolerâ€™s Cove Homeowners Assâ€™n, Inc. v. Trident
    Const. Co., Inc., 355 S.C. 506, 612, 583 S.E.2d 581, 585 (2003).Â  Accordingly, any doubts concerning the
  scope of arbitrable issues should be resolved in favor of arbitration. Â Zabinski
    v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 597, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001).Â  A
  motion to compel arbitration made pursuant to an arbitration clause in a
  written contract should only be denied where the clause is not susceptible to
  any interpretation which would cover the
  asserted dispute.Â  Id. at 597, 553 S.E.2d at 118-119.Â  
Nevertheless, arbitration is a matter
  of contract, and our evaluation of the enforceability of an arbitration
  agreement is guided by general principles of contract law.Â  Munoz v. Green
    Tree Fin. Corp., 343 S.C. 531, 538, 542 S.E.2d 360, 364 (2001).Â  The
  parties to an arbitration agreement are at liberty to choose the terms under
  which they will arbitrate.Â  Dowling v. Home Buyers Warranty Corp., II,
  311 S.C. 233, 236, 428 S.E.2d 709, 710 (1993).Â  In order to have a valid and
  enforceable contract, there must be a meeting of the minds between the parties
  with regard to all essential and material terms of the contract.Â  Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 105, 382 S.E.2d 891 (1989).Â  
The partiesâ€™ arbitration agreement provides that the arbitration
  shall be administered pursuant to the FAA.Â  Section
  5 of the FAA states in part:

  If in
    the agreement provision be made for a method of naming or appointing an
    arbitrator or arbitrators or an umpire, such method shall be followed; but if
    no method be provided therein, or if a method be provided and any party thereto
    shall fail to avail himself of such method, or if for any other reason there
    shall be a lapse in the naming of an arbitrator or arbitrators or umpire, or in
    filling a vacancy, then upon the application of either party to the controversy
    the court shall designate and appoint an arbitrator or arbitrators or umpire,
    as the case may require, who shall act under the said agreement with the same
    force and effect as if he or they had been specifically named therein . . . .

9 U.S.C. Â§ 5 (2007). Â 
Appellants
  argue that the unavailability of AHLA has created a â€œlapseÂ  . . . in filling a vacancyâ€
  that Section 5 was designed to remedy.Â  We disagree.
There is a dispute in the case law as to whether Section 5 applies in cases where, as here, the parties have specified an exclusive
  arbitral forum, but that forum is no longer available.Â  Some courts,
  particularly the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, have
  held that Section 5 does not apply in such instances.Â  See In re Salomon Inc. Sâ€™holdersâ€™ Derivative Litig., 68 F.3d 554, 560 (2d Cir. 1995) (defining the term â€œlapseâ€ in
  Section 5 to mean â€œa lapse in time in the naming of the arbitrator or in the
  filling of a vacancy on a panel of arbitrators, or some other mechanical
  breakdown in the arbitrator selection processâ€ and holding that Section 5 is therefore
  inapplicable to cases where the specifically designated arbitrator becomes
  unavailable); Â Dover Ltd. v. A.B. Watley, Inc., No. 04-7366, 2006 WL 2987054, *6 (S.D. N.Y Oct. 18, 2006) (recognizing
  that â€œSection 5 . . . is inapplicable when the parties
  have specified an exclusive arbitral forum, but that forum is no longer
  availableâ€).Â  
Other jurisdictions have interpreted Section 5 so as to generally
  allow for the appointment of new arbitrators when the named arbitrator could
  not or would not proceed.Â  See Ex parte Warren, 718 So.2d 45, 48 (Ala. 1998) (expressing the general rule that, â€œwhere the
  arbitrator named in the arbitration agreement cannot or will not arbitrate the
  dispute, a court does not void the agreement but instead appoints a different arbitrator.â€); Zechman v. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., 742 F.Supp. 1359, 1364 (N.D. Ill. 1990) (same).Â  However,
  these cases have also identified an exception to this rule, which provides that
  â€œ[o]nly if the choice of forum is an integral part of the
  agreement to arbitrate, rather than an â€˜ancillary logistical concernâ€™ will the
  failure of the chosen forum preclude arbitration.â€ Â Brown v. ITT Consumer
    Fin. Corp., 211 F.3d 1217, 1220 (11th
  Cir. 2000). Â Importantly, â€œ[n]one of these cases . .
  . stand for the proposition that district courts may use Â§ 5 to circumvent the partiesâ€™ designation of an exclusive
  arbitral forum.â€Â  In re Salomon Inc., 68 F.3d at 561.
We see great merit in the Second Circuitâ€™s view that Section 5
  does not apply in cases where a specifically designated arbitrator becomes
  unavailable.Â  However, we may assume without deciding that Section 5 applies in
  the present case and reach the same result because, in our view, the specific designation of
  the AHLA as arbitrator is an integral term of this arbitration agreement.
To determine whether a named arbitrator is an integral part of the
  agreement or an ancillary logistical concern, courts look to the â€œessenceâ€ of
  the arbitration agreement. Â Warren, 718
  So.2d at 49 (citingZechman, 742 F.Supp. at 1364).Â  Under
  the AHLA policy, the parties may not vary the rules on communications, service,
  counting of days, publication and form of the award, release of documents, or
  administration.Â  The parties are bound by a panel of arbitrators selected by
  the service.Â  In our view, the partiesâ€™ waiver of this set of rights in
  agreeing to arbitrate before the AHLA reflects their specific intent to
  arbitrate exclusively before that body.Â  Furthermore, the designation of
  a forum such as the AHLA â€œhas wide-ranging substantive implications that may
  affect, inter alia, the arbitrator-selection process, the law,
  procedures, and rules that govern the arbitration, the enforcement of the
  arbitral award, and the cost of the arbitration.â€Â  Singleton v. Grade A
    Market, Inc., No. 08-1385, 2009 WL 996015, *6 (D. Conn. April 13, 2009). Â Where
  designation of a specific arbitral forum has implications that may
  substantially affect the
  substantive outcome of the resolution, we believe that it is neither
  â€œlogisticalâ€ nor â€œancillary.â€Â  See Smith Barney, Inc. v. Critical Health Systems of North
    Carolina, Inc., 212 F.3d 858, 862 (4th Cir. 2000) (â€œIt is far better to interpret the
  agreement based on what is specified, rather than attempt to incorporate other
  remote rules by reference.â€); Wall
    Street Associates v. Becker Paribas, Inc. 818 F.Supp. 679, 683 (S.D. N.Y. 1993), affd. 27 F.3d 845 (2d Cir. 1994) (â€œ[A]n agreement to arbitrate before a particular forum is
  as integral a term of a contract as any other, which courts must enforce.â€).Â 
  Accordingly, we hold that the arbitration agreement is unenforceable and that
  the circuit court did not err in refusing to appoint a substitute arbitrator
  pursuant to Section 5.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, we affirm the judgment of the circuit court and remand for further
  proceedings. 
WALLER, BEATTY
and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in result.


[1] The NHLA has since become the American Health Lawyers Association (the â€œAHLAâ€)
and hereinafter will be referred to by that name.Â

PER
  CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered

  RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and
  consents to the issuance of an admonition, public reprimand, or definite
  suspension not to exceed ninety (90) days.Â Â Â  See Rule 7(b),
  RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the Agreement and
  definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state for a
  ninety (90) day period.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as
  follows.Â  
 FACTS
Respondent pled guilty to
  Failure to Pay Tax or File Return in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  12-54-44(B)(3) (2000).Â  On October 8, 2008, he was sentenced to eight (8)
  months imprisonment and a fine of $1,000, provided that, upon payment of $500

  upon service of one (1) year of probation.Â  On May 6, 2009, a circuit court
  judge found respondent had violated several conditions of his probation, continued
  respondentâ€™s probation until October 7, 2013, and reduced the restitution
  payments to $50.00 per month beginning June 8, 2009.Â  Respondent has been
  cooperative and forthright with ODC throughout its investigationÂ Â Â  
LAW
Respondent
  admits that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline pursuant to Rule
  7, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for
  discipline for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct or any
  other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers) and
  Rule 7(a)(4) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to be convicted
  of crime of moral turpitude or serious crime).Â  Further, he admits he has
  violated the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, specifically Rule
  8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate Rules of
  Professional Conduct), Rule 8.4(b) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to commit a
    criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness,
    or fitness as a lawyer in other respects), and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional
    misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the
    administration of justice).
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law for a ninety
  (90) day period.Â  Respondent shall fulfill all obligations of his sentence,
  including probation and payment of restitution, before he may file a Petition
  for Reinstatement under Rule 32, RLDE.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this
  opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing
  that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.

  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

        In the Matter of Marvin Lee
          Robertson, Jr.,  Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26670
Submitted May 19, 2009 - Filed June 15, 2009

DISBARRED


  
    
      
        Lesley M.
          Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and William C. Campbell, Assistant Disciplinary
          Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        M. Baron
          Stanton, of Stanton Law Offices, PA, of Columbia, for Â respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule
  413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to
  disbarment pursuant to Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In addition,
  respondent agrees to pay full restitution to clients, banks, and other persons
  and entities who have incurred losses as a result of his misconduct and to
  reimburse the Commission on Lawyer Conduct (the Commission) and ODC for costs
  incurred in this matter.Â  We accept the agreement and disbar respondent from
  the practice of law in this state.Â  Further, respondent shall pay full
  restitution to clients, banks, and other persons and entities who have incurred
  losses as a result of his misconduct and reimburse the Commission and ODC for
  costs incurred in this matter.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are
  as follows.Â  
FACTS
Matter I
Respondent
  admits he failed to close this case and disburse the clientâ€™s share of the
  funds for a period of approximately eighteen (18) months after receiving the
  settlement proceeds.Â  He further admits he did not safeguard the clientâ€™s funds
  and that the funds were not available on deposit in his trust account for at
  least the last twelve (12) months prior to disbursement.Â  
Matter II
Respondent
  admits he closed the real estate transaction in this matter but did not make
  the first mortgage payoff of $350,366.10 as shown on the closing statement.Â  Instead,
  for some months after the closing, respondent made monthly mortgage payments on
  the unsatisfied mortgage from various accounts under his control.Â  Further,
  respondent admits that no title insurance policy was issued after the closing
  despite fees of $791.70 being shown on the closing statement as withheld for
  the policy.Â  Respondent admits he cannot account for the funds shown on the
  closing statement as received and reserved for the first mortgage payoff and
  title insurance policy and that the funds were not available on deposit in his
  trust account at the time of his interim suspension on February 22, 2008.Â  Respondent
  acknowledges he was the closing attorney for the first mortgage in a separate
  much earlier transaction and failed to record that mortgage.Â Â  
Matter III
In March
  2007, respondent received a $42,000 settlement check.Â  Respondent admits he
  negotiated the settlement check but did not disburse the clientâ€™s share of the
  funds.Â  Respondent admits he failed to safeguard the funds and the funds were
  not available on deposit in his trust account at the time of his February 22,
  2008 interim suspension.Â  
Matter IV
Respondent
  admits he undertook to represent a client in a domestic matter seeking to
  negotiate a child support reduction and the Â modification of an agreement.Â  On
  January 29, 2008, he was paid a flat fee of $2,500 for the representation.Â  As
  a result of his interim suspension, respondent did not serve the opposing
  party.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
Matter V
Respondent admits
  he undertook to represent a client in an expungement and was paid $500.Â  He did
  not complete the work on the matter.Â  
Matter VI
Respondent
  admits he received a $6,000 settlement check.Â  He negotiated the settlement
  check but did not disburse the clientâ€™s share of the funds to the client.Â 
  Respondent admits he failed to safeguard the funds and that the funds were not
  available on deposit in his trust account at the time of his February 22, 2008
  interim suspension.Â Â  
Matter VII
Respondent
  admits he received a $10,000 settlement check.Â  He negotiated the settlement
  check but did not disburse the clientâ€™s share of the funds to the client.Â 
  Respondent admits he failed to safeguard the funds and that the funds were not
  available on deposit in his trust account at the time of his February 22, 2008
  interim suspension.Â Â  
Matter VIII
Respondent
  admits he received a $6,000 settlement check in October 2007.Â  He admits he
  negotiated the settlement check without his clientâ€™s signature.Â  Respondent did
  not disburse the clientâ€™s share of the funds until after his interim suspension
  on February 22, 2008.Â  Respondent agrees he initially failed to safeguard the
  funds and that he neglected to promptly remit the clientâ€™s share of the funds.Â  
Matter IX
In June
  2005, respondent admits he received a $75,000 settlement check.Â  He admits he
  negotiated the check but did not disburse the clientâ€™s share of the funds to
  the client.Â  Respondent admits he failed to safeguard the funds and that the
  funds were not available on deposit in his trust account at the time of his
  February 22, 2008 interim suspension.Â Â  
Matter X
In March
  2007, respondent received a settlement check in the amount of $1,419.Â 
  Respondent negotiated the check but did not disburse the clientâ€™s share of the
  funds to his client or disburse the funds to the medical providers.Â  Respondent
  admits he failed to safeguard the funds and that the funds were not available
  on deposit in his trust account at the time of his February 22, 2008 interim
  suspension.Â Â  
Matter XI
In March
  2004, respondent received two personal injury protection (PIP) checks totaling
  $1,000 from a client.Â  Respondent admits he negotiated the checks but did not
  disburse the clientâ€™s share of the funds to his client or disburse funds to the
  medical providers.Â  Respondent admits he failed to safeguard the funds and that
  the funds were not available on deposit in his trust account at the time of his
  February 22, 2008 interim suspension.Â Â  
Matter XII
In 2004,
  respondent undertook to represent a client in a personal injury case.Â  He
  admits he failed to act with reasonable diligence on the matter and failed to
  obtain a written settlement agreement from opposing counsel.Â  Further,
  respondent admits that, in May 2007, he mistakenly told the court that the case
  was settled.Â  Ultimately, the case was dismissed by the court.Â  
Matter XIII
Respondent
  admits that, in October 2006, he obtained two medical payment checks in the
  amount of $3,000 from a client.Â  Respondent admits he negotiated the checks but
  did not disburse the funds to the client or medical providers.Â  Respondent
  admits he failed to safeguard the funds and that the funds were not available
  on deposit in his trust account at the time of his February 22, 2008 interim
  suspension.Â Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his
  misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of
  Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide
  competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness
    in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep a client reasonably informed about
      the status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for
      information); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall hold property of clients
  in the lawyerâ€™s possession in connection with a representation separate from
  the lawyerâ€™s own property); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a
  lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is
  professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial
  to the administration of justice).Â  In addition, respondent admits he violated
  Rule 417, SCACR.Â  
Further, respondent admits his
  misconduct is grounds for discipline under Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR,
  specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to
  violate Rules of Professional Conduct) and 7(a)(5) (it shall be ground for
  discipline for lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the
  administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into
  disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law).Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline
  by Consent and disbar respondent. Â Further, we order respondent to pay full
  restitution to all clients, banks, and other persons and entities, including
  the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection, who have incurred losses as a result
  of his misconduct and to reimburse the Commission and ODC for costs incurred in
  this matter.Â  Within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion, ODC and
  respondent shall enter into a restitution plan which complies with this opinion
  and includes a timeline for reimbursement of the Commissionâ€™s and ODCâ€™s costs.Â 
  Under no circumstances shall respondent be permitted to file a Petition for
  Reinstatement until full restitution and payment of costs have been made.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Within fifteen (15) days of the date of
  this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court
  showing that he has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also
  surrender his Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of
  Court.Â  
DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES,
  BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
