THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      Mikal D. Mahdi, Petitioner,
      v.
      State of South Carolina, Respondent.
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI 

Appeal from Calhoun County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26671
  Heard February 18, 2009 - Filed June 15,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate
          Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
          of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General J.
          Anthony Mabry, all of Columbia, and Solicitor David Michael Pascoe, Jr., of
          Orangeburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  Petitioner[1] pleaded guilty to murder, second
  degree burglary, and grand larceny.Â  The trial judge imposed a death sentence
  for murder finding two aggravating circumstances,[2] and consecutive sentences of fifteen
  years (burglary) and ten years (larceny).Â  This opinion combines the issue
  raised on certiorari and the sentencing review mandated by S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-3-25 (2003).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On July 15, 2004,
  petitioner killed an employee while robbing a gas station in North Carolina.Â 
  Petitioner shot the North Carolina victim twice in the face at point blank
  range using a gun he had stolen from his grandmotherâ€™s neighbor.Â  He was
  driving a vehicle stolen from Virginia, on which he had placed stolen license
  plates. Â Two days later, petitioner car-jacked a man in Columbia at 3:30 a.m.
  using the same weapon.Â  Early that same morning, petitioner pulled into the Wilco Travel Plaza located off Interstate 26 in Calhoun County.Â  Employees at the Travel Plaza became suspicious when petitioner was repeatedly unable to purchase gasoline
  from the pumps, while attempting to use stolen credit and/or check cards.Â  The
  employees called law enforcement, and when officers arrived, petitioner fled on
  foot.Â  He ran to a nearby farm property owned by Captain and Mrs. Myers.[3]Â 
  The Myers did not reside on the rural property, but there was a shed in which
  they kept equipment and in which Mrs. Myers had an office.
Petitioner found a
  .22 caliber semi-automatic rifle in the shed where he apparently spent the
  day.Â  When Captain Myers stopped by the farm that evening, petitioner shot him
  nine times with the .22:Â  three bullets struck the victim in the head.Â 
  Petitioner then poured diesel fuel over the body and lit it.Â  He stole Myersâ€™
  truck and various firearms from the shed and drove to Florida, where he was
  arrested three days later after a chase.
After a
  jury was selected but before it was sworn, petitioner elected to enter a guilty
  plea to the charges of murdering Captain Myers, burglarizing the shed, and
  stealing the personal property.Â  The trial judge conducted a sentencing
  hearing, following which he issued an eleven and a half page sentencing order.
ISSUE

  Whether petitionerâ€™s capital sentence should be reversed because
    the trial judge improperly based his decision to impose a death sentence on
    petitionerâ€™s assertion of his right to a jury trial, thereby effectively
    punishing him for exercising this constitutional right?

ANALYSIS
Petitionerâ€™s
  argument relates to the following passage from the sentencing order, which is
  the last paragraph in the section of the order titled â€œMitigating
  Circumstances:â€

  The defense further argues as non-statutory mitigating
    circumstance that the Court should consider the Defendantâ€™s guilty plea in
    determining the appropriate sentence to be imposed.Â  The Defendantâ€™s guilty
    plea occurred during the fourth day of his trial, following jury selection but
    prior to the jury being sworn.Â  This was one day following his attempted escape
    through the use of the homemade key.Â  In addition, Mr. Mahdi has failed to
    demonstrate any remorse for his actions at any point in time known to the
    Court.Â  Therefore, I conclude that no significant weight should be given to
    this non-statutory mitigating circumstance in the Courtâ€™s ultimate decision as
    to the sentence to be imposed.

Petitioner contends
  this paragraph, specifically the second sentence, â€œThe Defendantâ€™s guilty plea
  occurred during the fourth day of his trial, following jury selection but prior
  to the jury being sworn,â€ demonstrates the judge improperly punished petitioner
  for initially exercising his right to a jury trial.Â  See e.g. State
    v. Hazel, 317 S.C. 368, 453 S.E.2d 879 (1995) (judge cannot consider
  defendants exercise of right to jury trial sentencing).Â  The State maintains,
  to the contrary, that this sentence is merely a factual recitation, or at most
  a partial explanation why the judge declined to consider the plea as a significant
  mitigator, but that it is not indicative of any punitive intent.Â  Since, as
  petitioner conceded at oral argument, there was no objection to this passage at
  trial, no issue has been preserved for this Courtâ€™s review.Â  State v. Owens,
  378 S.C. 636, 664 S.E.2d 80 (2008) (strict error preservation rules apply to
  capital cases).
PROPORTIONALITY REVIEW
Pursuant to Â§
  16-3-25(c), we have conducted a proportionality review and find the death
  sentence was not the result of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary
  factor.Â  Furthermore, a review of other decisions demonstrates that
  petitionerâ€™s sentence is neither excessive nor disproportionate.Â  See e.g. State v. Byram, 326 S.C. 107, 485 S.E.2d 360 (1997) (capital sentence
  upheld where aggravators were burglary and armed robbery).
CONCLUSION
Petitionerâ€™s
  conviction and sentences are
AFFIRMED.
WALLER, BEATTY
and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. Â TOAL, C.J., concurring in a separate opinion.

CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Although
  I concur with the majority, I write separately to record the facts of this
particularly heinous case.Â  
On
  July 14, 2004, Petitioner, then a resident of Virginia, embarked upon a crime
  spree that would span four states.Â  Petitioner stole a .380 caliber pistol from
  his neighbor, a set of Virginia license plates, and a station wagon.Â 
Petitioner left Virginia and headed to North Carolina.
On
  July 15, Petitioner entered an Exxon gas station in Winston-Salem, North Carolina armed with the .380 pistol.Â  Petitioner took a can of beer from a cooler and
  placed it on the counter.Â  The store clerk, Christopher Jason Boggs, asked
  Petitioner for identification.Â  As Boggs was checking Petitionerâ€™s
  identification, Petitioner fatally shot him at point-blank range.Â  Petitioner
  fired another shot into Boggs as he lay on the floor.Â  Petitioner then
  attempted unsuccessfully to open the storeâ€™s cash register.Â  Petitioner left
the store with the can of beer, and headed to South Carolina.
Early
  in the morning of July 17, Petitioner approached Corey Pitts as he sat at a
  traffic light in downtown Columbia, South Carolina.Â  Petitioner stuck his gun
  in Pittsâ€™ face, forced him out of his car, and stole Pittsâ€™ Ford Expedition.Â 
  Petitioner replaced the Expeditionâ€™s license plates with the plates he had
stolen in Virginia, and headed southeast on I-26.Â  
About
  thirty-five minutes down the road, Petitioner stopped at a Wilco Hess gas
  station in Calhoun County and attempted to buy gas with a credit card.Â  The
  pump rejected the card, and Petitioner spent forty-five minutes to an hour
  attempting to get the pump to work.Â  Due to his suspicious behavior, the store
  clerks called the police.Â  Aware that the clerksâ€™ suspicions had been alerted,
  Petitioner left the Expedition at the station and fled on foot through woods
behind the station.Â  
About
  a quarter to half mile from the station, Petitioner came upon a farm owned by
  Captain James Myers, a thirty-one year veteran law enforcement officer and
  fireman.Â  Petitioner broke into a work shop on the Myers property.Â  Once inside
  the work shop, Petitioner watched television and examined Myersâ€™ gun
  collection.Â  Petitioner found Myersâ€™ shotgun and used the tools in the shop to
  saw off the barrel and paint it black.Â  Petitioner also took Myersâ€™ .22 caliber
rifle and laid in wait for Myers.
That
  day, Myers had been at the beach celebrating the birthdays of his wife, sister,
  and daughter.Â  Myers had visited with his father before returning to his farm.Â 
  Upon arriving at the farm, Myers stopped by the work shop, where he was
  confronted by Petitioner.Â  Petitioner shot Myers nine times with the .22
  rifle.Â  Petitioner then poured diesel fuel on Myerâ€™s body and set the body on
  fire.Â  Petitioner stole Myersâ€™ police-issued truck, and left with Myersâ€™
shotgun, his .22 rifle, and Myersâ€™ police-issued assault rifle.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Later
  that evening, Myersâ€™ wife, also a law enforcement officer, became worried when
  Myers did not return home.Â  Mrs. Myers drove to the work shop and discovered
Myersâ€™ burned body lying in a pool of blood.Â  
Petitioner
  escaped to Florida, where he was spotted by police on July 21 driving Myersâ€™
  truck.Â  Fleeing the police, Petitioner abandoned the truck on foot in
  possession of the assault rifle.Â  When cornered by police, Petitioner abandoned
the rifle and was eventually taken into custody.Â  
I
  recite these facts to emphasize the egregious nature of Petitionerâ€™s crimes.Â 
  In my time on this Court, I have seen few cases where the extraordinary penalty
  of death was so deserved.Â  I therefore concur with the majority and vote to
affirm Petitionerâ€™s conviction and sentence.Â  



[1] The Court agreed to issue a writ of certiorari to consider this case since no
  timely notice of appeal was served.Â  See Ray v. State, 330 S.C.
184, 498 S.E.2d 640 (1998).
[2] Murder in the commission of a burglary, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C)(a)(1)(c)
  (Supp. 2008) and in the commission of larceny involving the use of a deadly
weapon, Â§ 16-3-20(C)(a)(1)(e).
[3] Captain Myers was a captain with the Orangeburg Department of Public Safety.

				Chief
  Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent
  Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this case, Arthur
  Franklin Smith (Respondent) was convicted of first-degree criminal sexual
  conduct (CSC) with a minor and sentenced to twenty years in prison.Â  The trial
  judge granted Respondent a new trial on the ground the minor victimâ€™s aunt
  â€œcoachedâ€ him while he was testifying at trial.Â  The State appealed this
  decision to the South Carolina Court of Appeals.Â  
In a
  divided opinion, the Court of Appeals affirmed the order of the trial judge.Â  State
    v. Smith, 372 S.C. 404, 642 S.E.2d 627 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  The State
  petitioned for and was granted a writ of certiorari for this Court to review
  the decision of the Court of Appeals.Â  We find the State did not have a right
  to appeal the trial judgeâ€™s order.Â  Accordingly, we vacate the opinion of the
  Court of Appeals.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In
  the summer of 1998, Respondent, his two minor sons (John Doe and Richard Roe),
  his wife, and his daughter moved to Bluffton, South Carolina from New York.Â  Shortly after the move, Respondent and his wife were divorced.Â  Doe was removed
  from his motherâ€™s custody after his brother, Richard Roe, discovered him
  engaging in sexual behavior with the son of his motherâ€™s boyfriend.Â  Doe, Roe,
  and their sister were ultimately placed in the custody of their uncle and aunt,
  Cynthia Solak, who lived in West Virginia. 
Following Doeâ€™s
  exhibition of sexual preoccupation, sexual acting out, and destructive
  behavior, he underwent counseling and eventually revealed Respondentâ€™s
  molestation of him during one of the counseling sessions. 
As a
  result, Respondent was indicted for first-degree CSC with a minor.Â  At trial,
  Doe described in detail the sexual abuse.Â  On cross-examination, Doe
  acknowledged that prior to trial, he and his aunt (Solak), had reviewed the
  questions that would likely be asked and discussed his testimony.Â  Doe also
  admitted that he had looked over to Solak while testifying.Â  However, Doe
  maintained on re-direct examination that â€œ[t]hese are my answers.â€Â  Doe also
  acknowledged that he revealed the sexual abuse while living with Solak because
  he felt â€œsafe.â€ 
After Doeâ€™s
  testimony, Respondentâ€™s counsel asked the trial judge to remove Solak from the
  courtroom while Doeâ€™s older brother, Richard Roe, testified during an in
    camera hearing on a Lyle[1] issue.Â  In making this request, counsel stated:

	I didnâ€™t
  object after [Solak] testified to [her] be[ing] in the courtroom.Â  But it was
  apparent during [Doeâ€™s] testimony that there were motions and mouth movement[s]
  and things going back and forth between the witness and Miss Solak and that was
  reported to me by individuals in the courtroom. 

Subsequently,
  Solak voluntarily left the courtroom. 
Following
  Roeâ€™s in camera testimony, Respondentâ€™s counsel moved for a mistrial on
  the ground that Solak improperly coached and influenced Doe during his
  testimony.Â  In the alternative, counsel moved to strike Doeâ€™s testimony.Â  Counsel
  contended that Solakâ€™s misconduct compromised the validity and credibility of
  Doeâ€™s testimony.Â  The trial judge denied counselâ€™s motions, stating:

	You did
  not, as an officer of the court, call it to my attention so that I could take
  appropriate action so you knew it was going on . . . and took no action.
	And so I
  think that is a waiver and I do find - - And I watched [this] young man testify
  - - that I do not believe that this caused any - - influenced his answers because
  he was basically going over the same things so Iâ€™m not going to declare a
  mistrial . . . .

In response,
  Respondentâ€™s counsel claimed that she was not aware of the â€œmagnitude of what
  was taking placeâ€ until she finished her cross-examination of Doe and sat down
  with her co-counsel who informed her of what he saw between Doe and Solak
  during the testimony. 
The
  judge then reiterated his denial of the mistrial motion and the motion to
  strike Doeâ€™s testimony, explaining:Â  

	[I]f
  co[-]counsel knew it, youâ€™re charged with knowing it too, because heâ€™s sitting
  at the table with you.Â  
	Having
  failed to bring the matter to the courtâ€™s attention, you know, if itâ€™s a
  strategic matter, you decided to ask him about it and knowing- - you did not
  make - - ask for a sidebar or anything, which you could have.Â  
	I
  frankly think what you did was probably the best way because I think the juryâ€™s
  much more influenced in determining the credibility of testimony as to whether
  or not the will of the young man was overridden by the people in authority . .
  . .
	I have
  the utmost confidence in the jury to render a just verdict in this case.Â  I
  believe it certainly is made more difficult by that unfortunate thing
  happening. 

At
  the conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case, Respondentâ€™s counsel renewed the mistrial
  motion. Â The trial judge again summarily denied the motion. 
After
  the jury found Respondent guilty of first-degree CSC with a minor, the trial
  judge sentenced him to twenty years in prison.Â  The next day, the trial judge
  heard testimony regarding Respondentâ€™s motion for a new trial specifically with
  respect to the issue of Solakâ€™s coaching of Doe during his testimony. 
At
  the hearing, Respondentâ€™s counsel offered the testimony of three individuals
  who were present in the courtroom during Doeâ€™s testimony.[2]Â  
The
  first witness testified â€œI couldnâ€™t see [Doe] from where I was so I donâ€™t know
  what he was doing but I could see her sitting over there and she was nodding
  her head back and forth, up and down and verbally saying stuff.â€ Â When asked by
  the trial judge whether it appeared that Solak was trying to assist Doe in
  answering the questions, the witness responded, â€œThatâ€™s what it appeared to be;
  however, I couldnâ€™t see him so I donâ€™t know, you know, if he was looking at her
  but I assumed he was . . . .â€ 
The
  second witness also testified that she observed Solak making motions with her head
  during Doeâ€™s testimony.Â  She believed Solak was â€œtrying to give the minor,
  twelve-year old answers to the questions that were being asked.â€ 
The
  third and final witness testified she observed Solak make head gestures toward
  Doe. Â She stated she thought Respondentâ€™s counsel had observed the motions stating,
  â€œwhen you were questioning him you asked him a question and, and I think you
  noticed his eyes going towards her.Â  And thatâ€™s when you moved over in front of
  her.â€ 
After
  the post-trial hearing, the trial judge granted Respondentâ€™s motion for a new
  trial.Â  In so ruling, the judge found:Â  1) Solak â€œused body language and other
  non-verbal signals in the courtroom during [Doeâ€™s] testimony and such
  communications were directed at [Doe] during his testimonyâ€; 2) â€œ[s]uch
  behavior on the part of [Solak] may have overridden [Doeâ€™s] free willâ€; and 3)
  â€œ[Solakâ€™s] behavior and the potential for corruption of [Doeâ€™s] testimony
  clearly denied [Respondent] a fair trial.â€ 
The
  State appealed the trial judgeâ€™s order to the Court of Appeals.Â  In a divided
  opinion, the Court of Appeals affirmed the grant of a new trial.Â  State v.
    Smith, 372 S.C. 404, 642 S.E.2d 627 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  The majority prefaced
  its analysis by implicitly finding that the State could appeal the decision on
  the ground it was based on an error of law.Â  Id. at 408, 642 S.E.2d at 629-30.Â 
  The majority also concluded that Respondentâ€™s counselâ€™s failure to
  contemporaneously object to the coaching did not waive Respondentâ€™s right to
  request a mistrial given the record did not clearly show the coaching was
  apparent to Respondentâ€™s counsel during Doeâ€™s cross-examination.Â  Id. at 409-10, 642 S.E.2d at 630-31.Â  Additionally, the majority believed the trial
  judge did not have all of the relevant information or much time to consider the
  issue when he initially denied the mistrial motions.Â  Having determined the
  issue to be preserved, the majority found evidence in the record to support the
  trial judgeâ€™s decision to grant a new trial.Â  Id. at 409, 642 S.E.2d at 630.Â  
The
  dissent advocated reversing the order of the trial judge and reinstating
  Respondentâ€™s sentence.Â  Id. at 410, 642 S.E.2d at 631.Â  The dissent
  believed Respondent received the relief sought in his request to remove Solak
  from the courtroom after Doeâ€™s testimony.Â  Because Solak voluntarily left the
  courtroom, the dissent found counselâ€™s request did not preserve the coaching
  issue for appellate review.Â  Id. at 411, 642 S.E.2d at 631.Â  Moreover, the
  dissent determined Respondent waived the issue because his counsel was apprised
  of Solakâ€™s conduct during Doeâ€™s testimony but did not object or request a
  mistrial until after Doeâ€™s brother, Roe, testified.Â  Because there was no
  contemporaneous objection by Respondentâ€™s counsel, the dissent found the trial
  judge erred by granting Respondentâ€™s motion for a new trial on this issue after
  the judge had initially concluded that Respondent waived the coaching issue.Â  Id. at 412, 642 S.E.2d at 632.Â  
This
  Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the decision
  of the Court of Appeals.

DISCUSSION
The
  State contends the trial judge erred in granting Respondent a new trial.Â  In
  support of this contention, the State avers:Â  1) the issue was not properly
  preserved at trial, and 2) the judge erroneously substituted his judgment for
  that of the jury. 
In response, Respondent asserts this Court should
  dismiss the Stateâ€™s appeal because the State had no right to appeal the order
  granting Respondent a new trial.Â  In the alternative, Respondent claims the
  trial judge properly granted him a new trial when it became apparent that Solak
  improperly coached Doe during his trial testimony.Â  
As a
  threshold issue, we must resolve whether the State had the right to appeal the
  trial judgeâ€™s order.Â  â€œThe State may only appeal a new trial order if, in
  granting it, the trial judge committed an error of law.â€Â  State v. Johnson,
  376 S.C. 8, 10, 654 S.E.2d 835, 836 (2007).Â  â€œWhen determining whether an error
  of law exists, and therefore whether the State has the right to an appeal, it
  is necessary to consider the merits of the case.â€Â  Id. at 11, 654 S.E.2d
  at 836.
In
  order to review the merits of this case, we must initially determine whether Respondent
  was procedurally barred from making a new trial motion challenging Solakâ€™s
  â€œcoachingâ€ of Doe.
Although
  counsel failed to object to Solakâ€™s coaching during Doeâ€™s cross-examination, we
  find the issue was properly preserved in that counsel timely raised the issue
  to the trial judge and obtained a ruling.Â  After Doeâ€™s cross-examination,
  counsel became aware of the extent of Solakâ€™s coaching once she conferred with
  her co-counsel and other individuals in the courtroom who observed Solakâ€™s
  conduct.Â  At that point, she informed the trial judge of the situation and
  moved for a mistrial.Â  In view of this procedural posture, we conclude counselâ€™s
  objection was sufficiently contemporaneous and provided the trial judge an
  opportunity to rule on the mistrial motion.Â  See State v. McIntosh,
  358 S.C 432, 445 n.7, 595 S.E.2d 484, 491 n.7 (2004) (finding objection was
  sufficiently contemporaneous where defendantâ€™s attorney objected after second
  improper question); cf. State v. Pauling, 322 S.C. 95, 100, 470
  S.E.2d 106, 109 (1996) (stating that â€œ[h]aving denied the trial judge an
  opportunity to cure any alleged error by failing to contemporaneously object . . ., Appellant is
  procedurally barred from raising these issues for the first time on appealâ€).
Because
  counsel posited a timely objection and received a ruling, we find the grounds
  for the mistrial motion and, in turn, the new trial motion were not waived.Â  See State v. Nelson, 331 S.C. 1, 6 n.6, 501 S.E.2d 716, 718 n.6 (1998)
  (stating â€œthe ultimate goal behind preservation of error rules is to insure
  that an issue raised on appeal has first been addressed to and ruled on by the
  trial courtâ€).
Furthermore,
  at the time the trial judge ruled on the motion for a mistrial, he was not
  aware of the magnitude of Solakâ€™s misconduct.Â  In fact, after Respondentâ€™s
  counsel requested to have Solak removed from the courtroom, the judge indicated
  that he did not notice Solakâ€™s alleged coaching. Â However, at the hearing on
  the new trial motion, the trial judge was more fully apprised of Solakâ€™s
  â€œcoachingâ€ of Doe.Â  Based on this additional evidence, the trial judge was able
  to thoroughly consider the mistrial motion and conclude that his prior ruling
  regarding waiver was not proper under these circumstances.Â  Thus, not until the
  new trial hearing was the trial judge able to make an informed decision based
  upon all the relevant facts, law, and arguments.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v.
    Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000) (â€œImposing
  this preservation requirement on the appellant is meant to enable the lower
  court to rule properly after it has considered all relevant facts, law, and
  arguments.â€); Rhoad v. State, 372 S.C. 100, 108 n.3, 641 S.E.2d 35, 39
  n.3 (Ct. App. 2007) (â€œUntil an order is written and entered, the judge is free
  to change his mind and amend prior rulings.â€); cf. State
    v. Floyd, 295 S.C. 518, 520, 369 S.E.2d 842, 843 (1988) (stating a ruling
  on a motion in limine is subject to change based on events at trial).Â  Consequently,
  we find the mistrial issue was not waived and the trial judge properly
  considered it as a ground for granting Respondent a new trial.
Having
  found Respondent did not waive the mistrial issue, we now address the merits of
  this issue in conjunction with determining the Stateâ€™s right to appeal.Â  Thus,
  the question becomes whether the trial judgeâ€™s grant of a new trial constituted
  an error of law.Â  
This
  Court is confined by an extremely limited â€œabuse of discretionâ€ standard of
  review regarding the grant of a new trial in the circumstances presented in
  this case.Â  See State v. Simmons, 279 S.C. 165, 166, 303 S.E.2d
  857, 858 (1983) (stating the grant or denial of a new trial is within the trial
  judgeâ€™s discretion and will not be overturned on appeal absent a clear abuse of
  discretion); 23A C.J.S. Criminal Law Â§ 1605 (2008) (â€œExcept in certain
  circumstances, it is reprehensible for a spectator to try to influence a
  witness while the witness is testifying, or to try to convey directions to the
  witness as to the answers that should be given.Â  It is largely within the
  discretion of the trial judge as to what should be done when such conduct
  occurs.â€). 
Based
  on our review of the record, there is evidence to support the judgeâ€™s
  decision.Â  All parties admitted that Solak acted inappropriately in mouthing
  words and making nonverbal signals to Doe during his testimony.Â  Clearly, the
  trial judge was in the best position to assess the credibility of the witnesses
  that testified at the hearing on the motion for a new trial. Â State v.
    Tutton, 354 S.C. 319, 325, 580 S.E.2d 186, 190 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œThe determination
  of a witnessâ€™s credibility must be left to the trial judge who saw and heard
  the witness and is therefore in a better position to evaluate
  his or her veracity.â€).Â  
Because
  Doe was the key witness in the prosecutionâ€™s case, we cannot disregard the
  trial judgeâ€™s conclusion concerning the prejudicial impact on Respondentâ€™s
  right to a fair trial.Â  Cf. Sharp v. Commonwealth, 849 S.W.2d
  542, 546-47 (Ky. 1993) (reversing trial judgeâ€™s denial of defendantâ€™s motion
  for a mistrial where child witness was coached by a family friend and finding
  â€œthe violations here as so egregious and inimical to the concept of a fair
  trial that they cannot be disregarded in the name of trial court discretionâ€); State
    v. Dayhuff, 158 P.3d 330, 342 (Kan. Ct. App. 2007) (holding trial courtâ€™s
  refusal to allow defendant, at the time of trial, to develop a factual basis
  for his motion for a mistrial that was based on the allegation that the child
  advocateâ€™s gestures during child witnessâ€™s testimony served to coach or vouch
  for the child warranted a new trial).
Although
  we are aware of the trauma a trial may bring to minor victims, we reach our
  decision constrained by our standard of review and the necessity to uphold the
  integrity of the judicial system.Â  In view of the clearly improper â€œcoachingâ€
  by Solak of the minor victim, we find the judge did not abuse his discretion or
  commit an error of law in granting Respondent a new trial.Â  In so holding, we are
  guided by the following principle:

	When it
  is made to appear that anything has occurred which may have improperly
  influenced the action of the jury, the accused should be granted a new trial,
  although he may appear to be ever so guilty, because it may be said that his
  guilt has not been ascertained in the manner prescribed by law.

State v. Britt, 235 S.C. 395, 425, 111 S.E.2d 669, 685 (1959)
  (emphasis added), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence,
  305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).
Because we find the
  trial judge properly exercised his authority to grant a new trial upon the
  facts, we conclude the judgeâ€™s decision was not predicated â€œwholly upon error
  of law.â€Â  See State v. Dasher, 278 S.C. 395, 399-400, 297 S.E.2d
  414, 416 (1982) (recognizing trial judgeâ€™s power to grant a new trial upon the
  facts)[3]; cf. State v. Des Champs, 126 S.C. 416, 418, 120 S.E. 491, 492
  (1923) (â€œ[W]here the grant of a new trial in a criminal cause is predicated
  wholly upon error of law, we think an appeal by the [S]tate will lie.â€).Â  Accordingly,
  we hold the State did not have the right to appeal the trial judgeâ€™s order.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we hold the State did not have
  the right to appeal the trial judgeâ€™s decision to grant Respondent a new
  trial.Â  As a result, we vacate the opinion of the Court of Appeals.
VACATED.
WALLER,
  PLEICONES and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate
  opinion.

Chief Justice Toal:Â  I
  respectfully dissent.Â  In my view, the State had a right to appeal the trial
  judgeâ€™s granting of a new trial because the order was based upon an error of
  law.Â  
In
  reviewing the trial courtâ€™s order granting a new trial, the majority is correct
  to observe that we review the trial court according to an abuse of discretion
  standard.Â  However, we must apply this standard in the context with which a
  trial court may exercise its discretion to grant a new trial.Â  We have said
  many times that the granting of a mistrial is an extreme measure that should
  only be taken where an incident is so grievous that prejudicial effect can be
  removed in no other way.Â  State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 310, 513
  S.E.2d 606, 610 (1999) (citing State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50,
  502 S.E.2d 63 (1998)). Â Furthermore, we must consider the entire
  trial record when considering whether the trial court abused its discretion in
  ordering a new trial.Â  See State v. Johnson, 334 S.C. 78, 91, 512 S.E.2d
  795, 803 (1999) (â€œThe prejudicial character of the error must be determined
  from its relationship to the entire case.â€)
My
  review of the record reveals no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s finding
  that Respondent was â€œclearly deniedâ€ a right to a fair trial.Â  In my view, the
  trial courtâ€™s own factual finding that Solakâ€™s behavior â€œmay have over-ridden
  the victimâ€™s free willâ€ does not support such a conclusion.Â  Doe confirmed that
  his testimony was his own, and Solak left the courtroom once it was alleged
  that she was coaching Doeâ€™s testimony.Â  Even if Solakâ€™s behavior did result in
  some degree of prejudice to Respondent, I believe this prejudice was outweighed
  by the ample evidence in the record to support the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  I find no
  foundation for the trial courtâ€™s order and believe that the trial court abused
  its discretion in granting Respondent a new trial.Â  I would therefore reverse
  the opinion of the court of appeals, reverse the order of the trial court, and
  reinstate Respondentâ€™s conviction and sentence.Â  


[1]Â Â  State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803
  (1923).
[2]Â  Neither Doe nor Solak testified at this hearing as
  they had already returned to their home in West Virginia. 
[3]Â  In Dasher, a jury found the defendant guilty
  of conspiracy to violate the South Carolina Controlled Substance Act.Â  After
  the verdict, the defendant filed a post-trial motion for judgment in his favor
  notwithstanding the verdict.Â  Prior to sentencing, the trial judge, without the
  assignment of any grounds, â€œsupplanted the jury verdict of guilty and entered a
  verdict of his own of not guilty.â€Â  Dasher, 278 S.C. at 395, 297 S.E.2d
  at 414.Â  The State appealed the trial judgeâ€™s decision.Â  Finding no precedent
  in this state to support the trial judgeâ€™s decision, this Court reversed.Â  Id. at 400, 297 S.E.2d at 416.Â  In so ruling, this Court reasoned that â€œ[t]his is
  not a case in which a trial judge has granted a new trial upon the facts
  (a power which he admittedly has), but rather one in which a trial judge has
  entered a verdict of not guilty in the face of conflicting evidence (a
  power he has never had in this jurisdiction).â€Â  Id. Â Because the trial
  judge set aside the verdict of the jury in the face of conflicting facts and
  substituted his judgment for that of the jury, this Court concluded that the
  judge committed an error of law.Â  Id. at 400, 297 S.E.2d at 417.
The instant case is
  distinguishable from Dasher.Â  Here, the trial judge did not set aside
  the verdict of the jury.Â  Instead, the trial judge properly exercised his
  authority to grant a new trial upon the facts given â€œan injustice had been
  doneâ€ during the trial.Â  Id. at 400, 297 S.E.2d at 416.Â  Thus, unlike
  the trial judge in Dasher, the judge did not invade the province of the
  jury or substitute his verdict for that of the jury.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Shawn Wiles, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Saluda County
Â William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26674
Heard May 13, 2009 - Filed June 22, 2009Â Â  
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				Appellate
  Defender M. Celia Robinson, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
  of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General
  Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of
  Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER: Petitioner Shawn
  Wiles was indicted for assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK), failure
  to stop for a blue light, and possession of a stolen vehicle.Â  A jury convicted
  him of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN) and failure
  to stop for a blue light.[1]Â 
  Pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, the Court of Appeals affirmed in an unpublished
  opinion.Â  See State v. Wiles, Op. No. 2007-UP-318 (S.C. Ct. App. filed June 14, 2007).Â  We granted petitionerâ€™s request for a writ of certiorari to
  review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
On December 26, 2003, a state trooper
  clocked two vehicles traveling 101 mph on Highway 25 in Edgefield County.Â  The first vehicle was a pickup truck, and the second was a stolen 1997 Ford Crown Victoria driven by petitioner.Â  Putting on his blue light and siren, the trooper gave
  chase.Â  The truck lost control and veered off the road.Â  The Ford then pulled
  over, but as the trooper approached it, the car turned around and headed back
  on the highway.Â  
The high-speed chase again ensued with the trooper and another
  highway patrol vehicle pursuing petitioner.Â  The trooper testified that
  petitioner turned onto Route 378 toward Saluda and drove at speeds over 120 mph
  while passing other cars on the road in an unsafe manner.Â  A few miles outside
  the city of Saluda, the trooperâ€™s supervisor directed him to terminate the
  chase because of safety concerns.Â  
However, Saluda County Sheriffâ€™s deputy Frank Daniel was at that
  same time responding to the call about the chase.Â  Deputy Daniel was in an
  intersection waiting to make a left turn onto Route 378 when petitioner ran a
  red light and crashed into Deputy Danielâ€™s car.[2]
The force of the collision with the deputyâ€™s car propelled the
  Ford into a nearby building.Â  Petitioner and his female passenger exited the
  car, and went into the building.Â  A SWAT team responded to the scene, and
  eventually petitioner was located in the building hiding above the ceiling
  tiles.Â  Petitioner was unarmed, and the SWAT team apprehended him without
  further incident.
At trial, evidence was admitted that approximately one week before
  the chase petitioner had escaped from a South Carolina prison.[3]Â  A Department of Corrections (DOC)
  investigator interviewed petitioner when he was re-incarcerated.Â  According to
  the investigator, petitionerâ€™s thoughts while driving 140 mph were that â€œhe was
  about to be killed or would end up killing someone in the process of trying to
  get away from the police.â€Â  On cross-examination, the DOC investigator
  acknowledged petitioner had told him that he panicked when he saw the trooper
  and he did not intentionally try to ram into the deputyâ€™s car.
The jury convicted petitioner of the lesser included offense of
  ABHAN and failure to stop for a blue light.Â  The trial court sentenced
  petitioner to consecutive sentences of 10 years for ABHAN, and three years for
  the failure to stop.
On appeal, petitioner argued the trial court erred in allowing
  evidence of petitionerâ€™s escape.Â  Finding the issue unpreserved, the Court of
  Appeals affirmed.Â  

ISSUES

	1.  Did the Court of
  Appeals err in finding petitionerâ€™s issue on appeal unpreserved?
	2.  Did the trial court
  err in admitting evidence of petitionerâ€™s escape?

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Issue Preservation
Prior to jury
  selection, petitioner made a motion in limine to exclude evidence of his
  escape.Â  The trial court ruled the evidence admissible to show res gestae,
  motive and intent.Â  Petitioner appealed the trial courtâ€™s ruling, but the Court
  of Appeals found the issue unpreserved for appellate review.Â  See State v. Wiles, supra (citing State v. Forrester,
  343 S.C. 637, 642, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001)). Â Petitioner argues the Court of
  Appeals erred because the trial judgeâ€™s ruling was final. Â Furthermore,
  petitioner contends that counsel renewed his objection when the escape evidence
  was admitted.Â  We agree with petitioner that this issue is preserved.
Generally,
  a motion in limine is not a final determination; a contemporaneous
  objection must be made when the evidence is introduced.Â  State v. Forrester,
  343 S.C. at 642, 541 S.E.2d at 840.Â  There is an exception to this general rule
  when a ruling on the motion in limine is made â€œimmediately prior to the
  introduction of the evidence in question.â€Â  Id.Â  This exception is based
  on the fact that when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is not preliminary, but instead
  is clearly a final ruling, there is no need to renew the objection.Â  Id. (citing State v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 266, 268-69, 460 S.E.2d 409, 410
  (Ct.App.1995)).[4]
In the instant case, the
  evidence was not immediately introduced after the motion in limine.Â 
  Nonetheless, by his actions, the trial judge clearly indicated that his ruling
  was a final, rather than preliminary, one because he commented to the jury about petitionerâ€™s escape before any evidence was admitted.Â  Specifically, the
  trial judge told the jury the following:

	The State is gonna attempt to
  introduce evidence related to the fact, in their view, that [petitioner] was an
  escapee from another institution â€¦.Â  The evidence â€¦ related to an escape is
  only allowed to be used for you to evaluate what his motives were, what his
  intents were, whether there was a mistake or accident, something like that.

Moreover, the escape was then
  referenced by both the State and petitionerâ€™s counsel in their opening
  statements. 
In our opinion,
  the trial courtâ€™s ruling on the admission of evidence regarding petitionerâ€™s escape was a final ruling,
  and therefore, petitionerâ€™s argument that the evidence was improperly admitted
  is preserved for appellate review.[5]Â  See Forrester, supra.Â  
Thus, we
  find the Court of Appeals erred in ruling that the issue raised on appeal was procedurally
  barred.
2.Â  Evidence
  of Escape
Turning
  to the merits, petitioner argues the trial court judge erred in allowing the
  evidence of his escape to be admitted at trial on the ABIK and failure to stop
  charges.Â  Petitioner contends the evidence should have been excluded as
  improper evidence of prior bad acts and because it was more prejudicial than
  probative.Â  We disagree.
Evidence is relevant and admissible if it
  tends to establish or make more or less probable the matter in controversy. Â See Rules 401 & 402, SCRE. Â Evidence of other crimes,
  wrongs, or acts is generally not admissible to prove the character of a person
  in order to show action in conformity therewith; however, such evidence may be
  admissible â€œto show motive, identity, the existence of a common scheme or plan, the absence of mistake or accident,
  or intent.â€ Â Rule 404(b), SCRE.Â  The evidence admitted must logically
  relate to the crime with which the defendant has been charged.Â  E.g., State
    v. Stokes, 381 S.C. 390, 673 S.E.2d 434 (2009); State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 135, 536 S.E.2d 679, 682-83 (2000).Â  
Stated differently, evidence
  which is â€œlogically relevant to establish a material element of the offense
  charged is not to be excluded merely because it incidentally reveals the
  accusedâ€™s guilt of another crime.â€Â  State v. Green, 261 S.C. 366, 371,
  200 S.E.2d 74, 77 (1973); see also State v. Adams,
  322 S.C. 114, 122, 470 S.E.2d 366, 370-71 (1996) (evidence of other crimes which supplies the
  context of the crime, or is intimately connected with and explanatory of the
  crime charged, is admissible as res
    gestae evidence).
Nonetheless, even where the evidence is shown to be relevant, if
  its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair
  prejudice, the evidence must be excluded.Â  See Rule 403, SCRE.Â  Unfair prejudice means an undue tendency to suggest
  decision on an improper basis. Â State v. Stokes, supra; State v. Beck, supra.
Here, the evidence of petitionerâ€™s escape was logically relevant
  for several reasons. Â First, the evidence of escape shows his motive for
  fleeing from police; thus, it was relevant on the failure to stop for a blue
  light charge. See Rule 404(b), SCRE. Â Second, the evidence that petitioner
  was an escapee was relevant to his alleged intent on the ABIK charge. Â Id.; cf. State v. Green, supra (where the Court held that evidence of appellantsâ€™ escape from prison, and
  their status as fugitives, was admissible on the issues of intent and common
  design in an attempted armed robbery case).Â  Finally,
  this evidence was also admissible under the res gestae theory.Â  See State v. Adams, supra.[6]Â  
Further,
  we find this evidence was not unduly prejudicial. See Rule 403, SCRE; State
    v. Stokes, supra; State v. Beck, supra.
Accordingly,
  the trial court did not err in admitting the evidence of petitionerâ€™s escape,
  and the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion is AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
TOAL,
  C.J., PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Petitioner moved for a directed verdict on the
  possession of a stolen vehicle charge because evidence admitted at trial
  indicated that petitioner himself had stolen the car in Georgia.Â  The trial court granted the motion.Â  See State v. McNeil, 314 S.C.
  473, 445 S.E.2d 461 (Ct. App. 1994) (the possession of a stolen vehicle
  statute requires that the defendant receive the goods from someone who actually
  stole them; he cannot receive the vehicle from himself).
[2] The deputy was taken to the
  hospital and missed 5 days of work, but he was not seriously injured.
[3] The record reflects that in a separate proceeding
  prior to the instant trial, petitioner pled guilty to, and was sentenced for,
  the escape.
[4] See also Staubes v. City of Folly
  Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 415, 529 S.E.2d 543, 547 (2000) (â€œThis Court
  does not require parties to engage in futile actions in order to preserve issues for appellate review.â€).
[5] In any event, we note counsel did specifically renew
  his objection on the record when this evidence was first admitted.
[6] We agree with the State
  that the evidence of petitionerâ€™s escape was â€œthe first link in a chain
  of circumstancesâ€ which led to the criminal charges in the instant case. State
    v. Green, 261 S.C. at 372, 200 S.E.2d at 77.Â

title: Brayboy v. WorkForce
description: In this workersâ€™ compensation case, claimant Lawrence Brayboy made material misrepresentations on his employment application. THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Lawrence Brayboy, Employee, Respondent,
        v.
        WorkForce,
          Employer and American Home Assurance, Carrier, Defendants,
        Of Whom
          WorkForce, Employer, is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No.  26675
Heard April 9, 2009 - Filed June 22, 2009  

REVERSED 


  
    
      
        Kirsten
          L. Barr, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
        John S.
          Nichols, of Columbia and Matthew Jackson, of North Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  KITTREDGE: In this workersâ€™
  compensation case, claimant Lawrence Brayboy made material misrepresentations
  on his employment application.Â  Subsequently, Brayboy claimed workersâ€™
  compensation benefits, which the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission awarded.Â  The
  circuit court upheld the award on the basis of the substantial evidence
  standard of review.Â  Because the issue of Brayboyâ€™s employment status is
  jurisdictional, the Court makes findings based on its view of the preponderance
  of the evidence.Â  We find the employer, WorkForce, established the three-factor
  test in Cooper v. McDevitt & Street Co., 260 S.C. 463, 468, 196
S.E.2d 833, 835 (1973), and reverse.
I.
On April 18, 2003,
  Brayboy sustained a back injury, which required lumbar fusion surgery.Â  On the
  day of the injury, Brayboy moved a lot of lumber and while removing a chain
  link fence, he felt a terrible pull in his back.Â  Brayboy worked the entire
  day, which was a Friday, and reported the injury on Monday.Â  Subsequently,
Brayboy filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim against his putative employer, WorkForce.
Brayboyâ€™s
  employment application included the following disclaimers:

  If
    I do not give accurate and truthful information on this Medical History
    Questionnaire, which forms the second and final part of my employment
    agreement, the entire employment agreement shall be considered null and void.
  MISREPRESENTATIONS
    AS TO PREEXISTING PHYSICAL OR MENTAL CONDITIONS MAY CAUSE FORFEITURE OF YOUR
    WORKERSâ€™ COMPENSATION BENEFITS.

(emphasis in original).Â  Notably,
  Brayboy signed his name under these cautionary statements.Â  Despite these
  warnings, Brayboy responded in the negative to all questions inquiring if
  Brayboy had prior back injuries, physical defects, medical conditions, or
  previous workersâ€™ compensation claims.Â  However, at the workersâ€™ compensation
  hearing, Brayboy testified about multiple prior physical problems.Â  These
  conditions included a back injury while in the Navy, a back injury in 1996
  resulting in a workersâ€™ compensation claim, and a pinched nerve in 1996.
Specifically,
  during his service in the Navy in the early 1970s, Brayboy fell, slid on the
  shipâ€™s deck, and hit a rail.Â  According to Brayboy, the Navy x-rayed his back
  and gave him medicine for treatment.Â  The Navy also diagnosed Brayboy with a
  back deformity he had since birth â€” a missing piece of bone.Â  Brayboy further
  stated he was honorably discharged in 1973 due to his back defect.
Notably,
  since the 1970s, Brayboy has received benefits from the Department of Veteransâ€™
  Administration (VA).Â  The impairment rating increased from ten to twenty
  percent due to a pinched nerve.Â  Following the 2003 injury, the VA raised
  Brayboyâ€™s disability rating from twenty to forty percent as the â€œservice
  connected condition(s) has/have worsened.â€
Brayboy further
  testified he filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim in 1996 while working for
  McCrory Construction.Â  The claim arose from an accident when Brayboy was in a
  hole thirty to forty feet deep taking measurements while other workers poured
  concrete for a parking garage.Â  Brayboy stated a backhoe was too close to the
  edge of the hole, and â€œ[the hole] collapsed, and I was pulled out by several of
  my workers.â€Â  This accident injured Brayboyâ€™s middle to low back and right
  ankle.
Brayboy
  filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim for this injury, received a settlement for
  this claim, and was given a five percent impairment rating for his back as well
  as five percent for his ankle.Â  Brayboy testified in deposition that his
  current back pain was â€œprimarily in the same areaâ€ as the cave-in injury; however,
  at the hearing, he disputed the similarity of the injuries.Â  Additionally,
  Brayboy testified he suffered a pinched nerve in his right hip in 1996.Â  This
  was unrelated to the cave-in and was due to wearing a heavy tool belt.
Brayboy testified
  he did not report any of his prior injuries to WorkForce as he did not feel the
  injuries were relevant to a construction job.Â  Also, Brayboy stated he did not
  include the cave-in injury as it had â€œcleared up very quickly.â€
The single
  commissioner found a compensable injury and Brayboy credible when testifying he
  filled out the employment application in adherence to his belief he was neither
  permanently impaired nor disabled.Â  The Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission upheld
  the award of the single commissioner.Â  The circuit court affirmed.
WorkForce appealed and
  the court of appeals issued an unpublished opinion reversing.Â  Following a
  petition for rehearing, the court of appeals withdrew its opinion and requested
  certification under Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â 
  We granted certification. 
II.
The existence of an employment relationship is a
  jurisdictional issue for purposes of workersâ€™ compensation benefits reviewable
  under the preponderance of the evidence standard of review.Â  Glass v. Dow
    Chem. Co., 325 S.C. 198, 201-02, 482 S.E.2d 49, 51 (1997); Vines v.
      Champion Bldg. Prods., 315 S.C. 13, 16, 431 S.E.2d 585, 586 (1993); Givens
        v. Steel Structures, Inc., 279 S.C. 12, 13, 301 S.E.2d 545, 546 (1983); Cooper
          v. McDevitt & St. Co., 260 S.C. 463, 466, 196 S.E.2d 833, 834 (1973); Chavis v.
            Watkins, 256
            S.C. 30, 32, 180 S.E.2d 648, 649 (1971); Hon. Jean Hoefer Toal et
  al., Appellate Practice in South Carolina 170 (2d ed. 2002).
We
  must determine if Brayboy was an employee at the time of his injury and thus
  eligible for workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  Alewine v. Tobin Quarries,
    Inc., 206 S.C. 103, 109, 33 S.E.2d 81, 83 (1945) (â€œNo award under the
  [Workersâ€™ Compensation] Act is authorized unless the employer-employee
  relationship existed at the time of the alleged injury for which claim is made.
  Â This relation is contractual in character . . . .â€).Â  An employee is
  statutorily defined in section 42-1-130 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2008)
  as â€œevery person engaged in an employment under any appointment,
  contract of hire, or apprenticeship, expressed or implied, oral or written . .
  . .â€Â  Brayboy asserts his status as an employee as a result of the contract for
  hire with WorkForce.Â  WorkForce relies on the principle that an employment
  relationship may be vitiated when there is a material misrepresentation in the
  employment contract.Â  Givens, 279 S.C. at 13, 301 S.E.2d
  at 546.

  In Cooper,
    this Court set forth three necessary factors for a material misrepresentation
    in the employment application to vitiate the employment relationship:
  (1) The
    employee must have knowingly and wilfully made a false representation as to his
    physical condition.
    (2) The
    employer must have relied upon the false representation and this reliance must
    have been a substantial factor in the hiring.
    [and]
    (3)
    There must have been a causal connection between the false representation and
    the injury.

260 S.C. at 468, 196 S.E.2d
  at 835.
We
  are firmly convinced that WorkForce has established all three factors.Â  First,
  Brayboy failed to report a host of prior back problems, as well as a prior
  workersâ€™ compensation claim for an injury to his back.Â  The willful nature of
  Brayboyâ€™s false responses pervades the record.Â  Brayboy admits he provided
  false information on the employment application.Â  The suggestion that Brayboy could
  make material misrepresentations on his employment application because he
  believed he was fit for construction work is a specious position.
Turning
  to part two of the test, WorkForce presented credible evidence it relies
  heavily on the employment application.Â  In this regard, WorkForceâ€™s reliance is
  twofold: the employment application is important in the hiring and placement
  decisions. Â Clearly, the questionnaire portion of the application protects the
  employer and employee.Â  Had Brayboy given truthful information, WorkForce would
  have been able to give him suitable job assignments, which would not have
  included heavy lifting.Â  Even Brayboy at one point conceded the importance of
  providing truthful information on the employment application when he stated,
  â€œ[WorkForce] wouldnâ€™t want to put a person with impairments or disabilities on
  a construction job that [he] couldnâ€™t handle.â€Â  We find WorkForce detrimentally
  relied on Brayboyâ€™s fraudulent application.[1]Â  Small v. Oneita Indus., 318 S.C. 553,
    554-55, 459 S.E.2d 306, 306-07 (1995) (noting an agent of the
  employer testified Smallâ€™s prior injury would affect job placement decisions, not
  hiring decisions, and affirming the denial of workersâ€™ compensation benefits
  due to a false representation on an employment application).
Concerning
  the third factor, we find irrefutable evidence of a causal connection between
  the false information and the aggravation of his pre-existing back injury.Â  Brayboy
  conceded that the April 2003 injury was in â€œprimarily in the same areaâ€ as the 1996
  cave-in injury.Â  The April 2003 injury is also directly linked to his military
  disability, as evidenced by the VA raising Brayboyâ€™s disability rating from
  twenty to forty percent as the â€œservice connected condition(s) has/have
  worsened.â€
Pursuant
  to Cooper, we hold Brayboyâ€™s fraudulent responses on his employment
  application vitiated his employment relationship and barred his recovery of
  workersâ€™ compensation benefits.
REVERSED.


[1] WorkForce provides temporary employment and,
  therefore, a WorkForce employee may be assigned to various jobs during their
  employment.Â  On the day of his alleged injury, Brayboy was assigned to heavy
  labor, the very type of assignment WorkForce claims it would not have given Brayboy
  had he been truthful in his employment application.

description: We affirm Appellant's conviction for "Taking of Hostages by an Inmate," finding the applicable code section, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-450, is not unconstitutionally vague.
