THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Vincent Neuman,
      Sr., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From McCormick County
William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26676
Heard March 17, 2009 - Filed June 29, 2009Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate
  Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General
  Norman Mark Rapoport, Assistant Attorney General Michelle J. Parsons, all of
  Columbia, and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  Vincent Neuman appeals from
  his conviction for â€œTaking of Hostages By an Inmate.â€[1]Â 
  His sole contention is that the trial judge erred in not dismissing this charge
  on the ground the applicable statute, section 24-13-450[2] of the South Carolina Code, is unconstitutionally vague.Â  Pursuant to Rule
  204(b), SCACR, this Court certified the case from the Court of Appeals.Â  We
  affirm.
FACTS
A McCormick County grand jury indicted Neuman for â€œTaking of Hostages by an Inmateâ€ and
  attempted escape following an incident at the McCormick Correctional
  Institution where Neuman was incarcerated. 
At trial, Cornell
  Lyons, a correctional officer at the McCormick Correctional Institution, testified
  that during the early morning hours of February 17, 2001, Neuman â€œattackedâ€ him
  when he turned his back to use a microwave. Â As Lyons confronted Neuman, he was
  grabbed from behind by Andre Waters, another inmate.Â  During the struggle,
  Neuman and Waters attempted to handcuff Lyons.Â  When Lyons asked the inmates
  what they were doing, they responded â€œweâ€™re tryinâ€™ to get outta here.â€Â  
Once
  the inmates successfully handcuffed Lyons, they took his keys and locked him in
  a storage closet.Â  Approximately five minutes later, the inmates brought Tammy
  Mason, another correctional officer, to the storage closet.Â  Mason testified
  that during her count of the inmates around 1:30 a.m., she was accosted by
  Neuman and Waters and then handcuffed before she was brought to the storage
  closet.Â  Shortly thereafter, Neuman and Waters brought inmate Franklin Mackey,
  who was visibly injured, to the storage closet. Â According to Mason, Mackey
  made the comment that he was beaten up by Neuman and Waters. 
After approximately
  thirty minutes, Neuman and Waters returned to the closet, opened the door, and
  asked for medical assistance as they were severely injured as a result of their
  attempted escape over razor wire surrounding the correctional facility.Â  Neuman
  then took Lyons to a telephone where a call was made alerting other correctional
  officers about the physical condition of Neuman and Waters.Â  The responding
  officers then apprehended Neuman and Waters.
After the incident, Neuman provided a statement to Investigator Jeff Bentley in which Neuman
  admitted to his involvement in the incident with Waters. Â As part of the
  investigation, it was discovered that Neumanâ€™s wife and a childhood friend of
  Neumanâ€™s had attempted to aid Neuman in his escape.
Waters testified
  for the defense.Â  Prior to Neumanâ€™s trial, Waters had pled guilty to the
  charges arising from the escape attempt.Â  According to Waters, it was his idea
  to escape and that Neuman â€œdecided to come alongâ€ after helping Waters restrain
  Lyons. Â Waters claimed he was the one who handcuffed Lyons and Mason and put
  them in the storage closet before attempting to escape. 
During reply,
  Investigator Bentley discounted Watersâ€™s testimony.Â  When Bentley interviewed
  Waters the day of the incident, Waters claimed the escape was Neumanâ€™s idea and
  they were both involved in restraining Lyons, Mason, and Mackey and locking
  them in the storage closet. 
After the Stateâ€™s
  case, Neumanâ€™s counsel moved for a directed verdict and made a motion to
  dismiss the indictment for the taking of hostages by an inmate on
  constitutional grounds.Â  At the close of the testimony, Neumanâ€™s counsel
  renewed his motion.Â  The judge denied both of these motions. 
The jury convicted Neuman of attempted escape and taking of hostages by an inmate.Â  Pursuant to
  the recidivist statute,[3] the trial judge sentenced Neuman to life without parole for the hostage-taking
  charge and a consecutive five-year sentence on the escape charge. 
Neuman appeals his
  conviction for taking of hostages by an inmate.
DISCUSSION
Neuman asserts the
  trial judge erred in refusing to dismiss the taking of hostages by an inmate
  charge on the ground section 24-13-450 is unconstitutionally vague.Â  Because
  the statute does not include the word â€œunlawfully,â€ Neuman claims the statute
  effectively criminalizes lawful activity.Â  Without the word â€œunlawfully,â€
  Neuman contends the statute does not contain the â€œlanguage necessary to
  narrowly tailor the statute to apply only to unlawful activity.â€ 
A.
As a threshold
  issue, the State asserts Neumanâ€™s argument is not preserved for appellate
  review because Neuman did not specifically rely on the void for vagueness
  doctrine when he challenged section 24-13-450 at trial.Â  Because Neuman only
  referenced the overbreadth doctrine in his trial argument, the State claims
  Neuman did not preserve his argument for this Courtâ€™s review.Â  
At
  trial, Neumanâ€™s counsel moved to dismiss the indictment for taking of hostages
  by an inmate.Â  In making this motion, counsel argued:

	[W]e
  move to dismiss the prosecution based on this indictment of hostage taking as
  the statute is overbroad (inaudible) objection the constitution is defective in
  that it encompasses about 5 to 10 elements of other crimes making it almost
  impossible to defend against constitutionally and we would move to dismiss the
  indictment at this time based on its constitutional defect under the - - 4th,
  5th, 6th, 8th and 14th amendments
  of the United States Constitution and the applicable South Carolina statutes.Â  
	

The trial judge
  denied Neumanâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  In his ruling, however, the judge recognized
  that the statute â€œis unusual and it is very broad.â€Â  The judge also expressed
  his concern that the statute did not include â€œan unlawful purpose of criminal
  intent.â€Â  Based on this concern, the judge indicated that he would include in
  his charge that there â€œhas to be an unlawful purpose.â€ Â Applying a â€œreasonable
  construction,â€ the judge ultimately concluded that the statute was sufficient
  for the State to prosecute Neuman. 
Although the State
  is technically correct that Neuman did not specifically raise the vagueness
  doctrine in his trial argument, we find this issue was sufficiently preserved
  for this Courtâ€™s review.
First, Neumanâ€™s
  counselâ€™s use of the term â€œoverbroadâ€ is not necessarily dispositive.Â  Clearly,
  a challenge to section 24-13-450 would not have been based on the overbreadth
  doctrine. Â This statute could not conceivably suppress protected speech or
  conduct.Â  Without such a First Amendment concern, the overbreadth doctrine
  would not have been an appropriate ground to challenge the statute. Â See In re Amir X.S., 371 S.C. 380, 384, 639 S.E.2d 144, 146 (2006) (noting a
  person raising a First Amendment overbreadth doctrine challenge to a statute
  must demonstrate that the statute could cause someone to refrain from
  constitutionally-protected expression); State v. Bouye, 325 S.C. 260,
  265, 484 S.E.2d 461, 464 (1997) (â€œThe overbreadth doctrine applies only to
  First Amendment cases where the challenged law would have a â€˜chilling effectâ€™
  on constitutionally protected forms of speech.â€). 
Secondly,
  a review of Neumanâ€™s counselâ€™s argument reveals that he listed multiple
  constitutional amendments in an effort to challenge the statute as
  constitutionally defective.Â  We find counselâ€™s assertions regarding the Fifth and
  Fourteenth amendments, as well as his assertion that the statute was â€œalmost
  impossible to defend,â€ necessarily included a due process challenge. Â In turn, these
  arguments were sufficiently broad to incorporate the vagueness doctrine.Â  See Kurschner v. City of Camden Planning Commâ€™n, 376 S.C. 165, 171, 656
  S.E.2d 346, 350 (2008) (â€œProcedural due process imposes constraints on
  governmental decisions which deprive individuals of liberty or property
  interests within the meaning of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth or Fourteenth Amendment of the United States
  Constitution.â€); Guinyard v. State, 260 S.C. 220, 226, 195 S.E.2d 392,
  394 (1973) (â€œThe concept of vagueness or indefiniteness rests on the
  constitutional principle that procedural due process requires fair notice and
  proper standards for adjudication. Â The primary issues involved are whether the
  provisions of a penal statute are sufficiently definite to give reasonable
  notice of the prohibited conduct to those who wish to avoid its penalties and
  to apprise judge and jury of standards for the determination of guilt. Â If the
  statute is so obscure that men of common intelligence must necessarily guess at
  its meaning and differ as to its applicability, it is unconstitutional.â€
  (citation omitted)).Â  
Finally,
  the trial judge interpreted Neumanâ€™s counselâ€™s argument as one for vagueness.Â 
  In his ruling, the judge recognized the omission of the term â€œunlawfulâ€ in the
  statute.Â  Thus, Neumanâ€™s appellate argument was sufficiently raised to and
  ruled upon to be preserved for this Courtâ€™s review. Â See State v.
    Nelson, 331 S.C. 1, 6 n. 6, 501 S.E.2d 716, 718 n. 6 (1998) (stating â€œthe
  ultimate goal behind preservation of error rules is to insure that an issue raised on appeal has first been addressed to and ruled on by the trial courtâ€).
B.
Having found that Neumanâ€™s argument is proper for appellate review, we now turn to the merits of Neumanâ€™s
  constitutional challenge.
â€œThis Court has a limited scope of review in cases involving a
  constitutional challenge to a statute because all statutes are presumed constitutional
  and, if possible, will be construed to render them valid.â€Â  Curtis v. State,
  345 S.C. 557, 569, 549 S.E.2d 591, 597 (2001).Â  â€œA â€˜legislative act will not be
  declared unconstitutional unless its repugnance to the constitution is clear
  and beyond a reasonable doubt.â€™â€ Â In re Treatment and Care of Luckabaugh,
  351 S.C. 122, 134-35, 568 S.E.2d 338, 344 (2002) (quoting Joytime Distribs.
    & Amusement Co. v. State, 338 S.C. 634, 640, 528 S.E.2d 647, 650
  (1999)).Â  â€œA possible constitutional construction must prevail over an
  unconstitutional interpretation.â€Â  Curtis, 345 S.C. at 569-70, 549
  S.E.2d at 597.
â€œThe void-for-vagueness doctrine rests on the constitutional principle
  that procedural due process requires fair notice and proper standards for
  adjudication.â€ Â State v. Houey, 375 S.C. 106, 113, 651 S.E.2d 314, 318
  (2007).Â  â€œThe constitutional standard for vagueness is whether the law gives
  fair notice to those persons to whom the law applies.â€Â  In re Amir X.S.,
  371 S.C. at 391-92, 639 S.E.2d at 150.Â  â€œA statute is not unconstitutionally
  vague if a person of ordinary intelligence seeking to obey the law will know,
  and is sufficiently warned of, the conduct the statute makes criminal.â€Â  State
    v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 629, 591 S.E.2d 600, 603 (2004).Â  This concept has
  been explained as follows, â€œ[a] law is unconstitutionally vague if it forbids
  or requires the doing of an act in terms so vague that a person of common
  intelligence must necessarily guess as to its meaning and differ as to its
  application.â€ Â Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. at 572, 549 S.E.2d at 598.Â 
  â€œOne to whose conduct the law clearly applies does not have standing to
  challenge it for vagueness.â€Â  Id.
Initially, we note that Neuman does not have standing
  to challenge section 24-13-450 for vagueness.Â  As we view the evidence, Neumanâ€™s
  conduct falls within even the most restrictive application of the statute.Â 
  Neuman, an inmate, admitted his culpability in acting in concert with Waters,
  another inmate.Â  Both Correctional Officers Lyons and Mason testified that
  Neuman physically assaulted them, handcuffed them, forced them into the
  dayroom, and ultimately locked them inside a closet in an effort to escape from
  prison.Â  In view of this evidence, we believe Neuman lacks standing to
  challenge the constitutionality of the statute.Â  See State v. Michau,
  355 S.C. 73, 77, 583 S.E.2d 756, 759 (2003) (concluding appellant lacked
  standing to challenge statute as unconstitutionally vague given the statute
  clearly applied to his conduct); In re Amir X.S., 371 S.C. at 392, 639
  S.E.2d at 150 (finding appellant did not have standing to challenge statute on
  grounds of vagueness where appellantâ€™s conduct fell within the most narrow
  application of the statute).
At
  oral argument, however, Neuman claimed that section 24-13-450 did not apply to
  his conduct in that he did not hold the correctional officers as â€œhostagesâ€ as
  that term is usually defined.[4]Â 
  Specifically, Neuman disputed that the incident at the McCormick Correctional
  Institution constituted a hostage-taking situation. Â Given the confinement of
  the correctional officers was not with intent of using the officers to secure
  demands from a third party, Neuman claimed his conduct was akin to that of
  kidnapping. Â Because the statute did not apply to his conduct, he contended he
  has standing to challenge the constitutionality of section 24-13-450.Â  
Even
  if Neuman correctly interprets the term â€œhostage,â€ his argument does not negate
  the fact that his conduct still fell within the purview of the statute.Â  As
  previously stated, an inmate may be found guilty of taking of hostages by an
  inmate if â€œacting alone or in concert with others, who by threats, coercion,
  intimidation, or physical force takes, holds, decoys, or carries away any
  person as a hostage or for any other reason whatsoever.â€ Â S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-450 (2007) (emphasis added). Â In view of this disjunctive
  language, the correctional officers in the instant case did not necessarily
  have to be hostages[5] for Neuman to be convicted of this offense.Â  Instead, Neuman could have been
  found guilty if he had taken, held, decoyed, or carried away the officers â€œfor
  any other reason whatsoever.â€Â  In this case, Neuman admitted he and Waters
  detained the officers in an effort to escape the correctional facility.Â  Thus,
  we find Neuman does not have standing because the statute at issue clearly
  applied to his conduct.
C.
Even assuming that Neuman has standing, we hold section 24-13-450 is
  not unconstitutionally vague. 
First, we find a person of ordinary intelligence and judgment would be
  sufficiently apprised of conduct that would come within the purview of the
  statute. Â Clearly, one who is incarcerated in a correctional facility is aware
  of his status as an inmate and conduct the statute makes criminal.Â  Because an
  inmate is undoubtedly cognizant of conduct that constitutes even minor
  infractions in a correctional facility, it would be difficult to conceive that
  an inmate would have to guess that taking someone by physical force, threats,
  coercion or intimidation and holding them as a hostage or for any other reason would
  not be conduct proscribed by section 24-13-450.
Secondly,
  the fact that the term â€œunlawfulâ€ is not referenced in section 24-13-450 does
  not deem the statute unconstitutionally vague.Â  In support of his argument, Neuman compares section 24-13-450 with the kidnapping statute.[6]Â 
  Because the kidnapping statute includes the terms â€œunlawfullyâ€ and â€œwithout
  authority of law,â€ Neuman avers the specific language of the kidnapping
  statute, unlike section 24-13-450, excludes lawful activity.Â  Â Â 
In support of this contention, Neuman relies on this Courtâ€™s decision
  in State v. Smith, 275 S.C. 164, 268 S.E.2d 276 (1980).Â  In Smith,
  this Court held the kidnapping statute was not unconstitutionally vague.Â  In so
  holding, this Court stated, â€œ[t]he terms of [the kidnapping] statute are clear
  and unambiguous.Â  It proscribes the forceful seizure, confinement or carrying
  away of another against his will without authority of law.â€Â  Id. at 166,
  268 S.E.2d at 277.
Comparing section
  24-13-450 with the kidnapping statute, we find section 24-13-450 supersedes as
  a specific statute the general criminal offense statute of kidnapping. Â See State v. Davis, 294 P.2d 934, 936 (Wash. 1956) (analyzing statutes
  designated to define offenses chargeable to prisoners of penal institutions
  with other offenses chargeable to â€œany person,â€ and concluding specific statute
  relating to prisoners would â€œsupersede the kidnapping statute, if ever
  applicable, in the situation where an inmate of a state penal institution holds
  or participates in holding an officer of that institution as a hostage by force
  or violence or the threat thereofâ€); see also Rainey v. State,
  307 S.C. 150, 414 S.E.2d 131 (1992) (recognizing general principle that more
  recent and specific legislation supersedes
  prior general law); State v. Brown, 289 S.C. 581, 347 S.E.2d 882 (1986) (noting
  laws giving specific treatment to a given situation take
  precedence over general laws on same subject, and later legislation takes
  precedence over earlier laws).
Moreover,
  a review of both statutes reveals that section 24-13-450 essentially
  incorporates all of the elements of kidnapping but confines the proscribed
  conduct to the limited environment of a correctional facility.Â  See State
    v. East, 353 S.C. 634, 637, 578 S.E.2d 748, 750 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œSouth
  Carolinaâ€™s kidnapping statute requires proof of an unlawful act taking one of
  several alternative forms, including seizure, confinement, inveiglement, decoy,
  kidnapping, abduction, or carrying away.â€); see generally Don F. Vaccaro, Annotation, Seizure of Prison Official
    By Inmates as Kidnapping, 59 A.L.R.3d 1306 (1974 & Supp. 2008)
  (discussing cases in which courts have consider the issue of whether and under what
  circumstances the seizure of a prison official by the inmates of a penal
  institution constitutes the offense of kidnapping).
Because section 24-13-450, which is part of Title 24 of the South
  Carolina Code regulating â€œCorrections, Jails, Probations, Paroles and Pardons,â€
  was intended to define offenses specific to prisoners of penal institutions,
  the conduct proscribed in the statute is by implication unlawful. Â Davis, 294 P.2d at 937 (recognizing that â€œ[u]nless the intended victims of a
  defendant who is an inmate of a state penal institution, and of his
  co-conspirators, are officers of a state penal institution, [the statute] would
  have no applicationâ€).
Notably, statutes
  from other jurisdictions which regulate the taking of a hostage by an inmate
  also do not include the â€œunlawfulâ€ element.Â  See, e.g., Â Mass. Gen. Laws
  Ann. ch. 127, Â§ 38A (2002) (â€œAny prisoner in any penal or reformatory
  institution who holds any officer or employee of such institution or any other
  person as a hostage shall be punished by imprisonment in the state prison for
  not more than twenty years.â€); Mich. Comp. Laws Ann. Â§ 750.349a (2004) (â€œA
  person imprisoned in any penal or correctional institution located in this
  state who takes, holds, carries away, decoys, entices away or secretes another
  person as a hostage by means of threats, coercion, intimidation or physical
  force is guilty of a felony and shall be imprisoned in the state prison for
  life, or any term of years, which shall be served as a consecutive sentence.â€);
  Wash. Rev. Code Ann. Â§ 9.94.030 (2003 & Supp. 2008) (â€œWhenever any inmate
  of a correctional institution shall hold, or participate in holding, any person
  as a hostage, by force or violence, or the threat thereof, or shall prevent, or
  participate in preventing an officer of such institution from carrying out his
  or her duties, by force or violence, or the threat thereof, he or she shall be
  guilty of a class B felony and upon conviction shall be punished by
  imprisonment in a state correctional institution for not less than one year nor
  more than ten years.â€). 
Finally,
  we believe a conclusion that section 24-13-450 is constitutional comports with
  the legislative purpose underlying this statute.Â  The General Assembly properly
  exercised its police power with the intention of protecting correctional officers
  by promulgating a distinct offense applicable solely to inmates.Â  Cf. Guinyard,
  260 S.C. at 226-228, 195 S.E.2d at 396 (finding statute prohibiting sexual
  intercourse with a patient or trainee of mental health facility was neither
  constitutionally vague nor defective despite Legislatureâ€™s failure to make
  knowledge of the institutional status of the person molested an element of the
  offense). 
Additional support for this analysis may be seen in this Courtâ€™s
  finding that the prison riot statute,[7] which is also included in Title 24 of the South Carolina Code and omits the
  term â€œunlawful,â€ is not unconstitutionally vague.Â  See State v.
    Greene, 255 S.C. 548, 560, 180 S.E.2d 179, 185 (1971) (holding â€œprison riot
  statute,â€ the pre-cursor to section 24-13-430, was not unconstitutionally vague
  in that it did not define the crime of â€œriotâ€ given the statute in question was
  directed at prisoners and the common law offense of riot was well established
  by judicial definition and, therefore, â€œunderstood by the ordinary manâ€). 
CONCLUSION
We hold that section 24-13-450, proscribing conduct
  for the offense of taking of hostages by an inmate, is not unconstitutionally
  vague.Â  Accordingly, we affirm Neumanâ€™s conviction and sentence.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in a
  separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree that the issue whether the statute is void
  for vagueness is preserved for our review since that is what the trial judge
  believed was being argued, and that is what he ruled upon.Â  Moreover, I agree
  that appellant lacks standing to challenge the statute because his conduct
  clearly falls within its terms.Â  In re Amir X.S., 371 S.C. 380, 639
  S.E.2d 144 (2006).Â  I would end the analysis here.Â  Id.Â  Finally, it is
  well-settled that an issue, unless a claim of lack of subject matter
  jurisdiction, cannot be raised for the first time at oral argument.Â  S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Soc. Serv. v. Basnight, 346 S.C. 241, 551 S.E.2d 274 (Ct. App.
  2001).Â  I therefore do not join the remainder of the majorityâ€™s discussion.
I concur in the
  decision to affirm appellantâ€™s appeal. 


[1]Â  Neuman was also convicted of attempted escape.Â  He
  has not appealed this conviction or the consecutive five-year sentence.
[2]Â Â  This section provides:

	An
  inmate of a state, county, or city correctional facility or a private entity
  that contracts with a state, county, or city to provide care and custody of
  inmates, including persons in safekeeper status, acting alone or in concert
  with others, who by threats, coercion, intimidation, or physical force takes,
  holds, decoys, or carries away any person as a hostage or for any other reason
  whatsoever shall be deemed guilty of a felony and, upon conviction, shall be
  imprisoned for a term of not less than five years nor more than thirty years.
  This sentence shall not be served concurrently with any sentence being served
  at the time the offense is committed.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  24-13-450 (2007).Â  
[3]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 (2003 & Supp. 2008).
[4]Â  Although the trial judge in his ruling expressed
  concern that the term â€œhostageâ€ was not defined in the statute, we note that
  Neuman did not raise any argument at trial or in his brief challenging this
  term.
[5]Â  We note the term â€œhostageâ€ is not defined in section
  24-13-450 or in any other statute within the South Carolina Code.Â  During oral
  argument, Neuman asserted that â€œhostageâ€ should be narrowly defined as it has
  been in other jurisdictions.Â  See, e.g., Ingle v. State, 746
  N.E.2d 927, 937 (Ind. 2001) (holding â€œa consistent definition of hostage would
  refer to one who is taken to secure some separate demand from another partyâ€); Jenkins
    v. State, 248 S.W.3d 291, 297 (Tex. Crim. App. 2007) (concluding the term
  â€œhostageâ€ within the aggravated kidnapping statute means â€œthe unlawful taking,
  restraining or confining of a person with the intent that the person, or
  victim, be held as security for the performance, or forbearance, of some act by
  a third personâ€).Â  In contrast, the State argued that the term should be
  broadly defined as it is generally understood.Â  Specifically, the State asserted â€œhostageâ€ should be defined as â€œone that is involuntarily controlled by an outside
  influence.â€  This definition may be found at http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/hostage.
Because Neuman has
  not claimed the evidence was insufficient to support his conviction,
  particularly with respect to the hostage element, we decline at this juncture
  to adopt a definition of â€œhostageâ€ within the context of section 24-13-450. 
[6]Â Â  Section 16-3-910 provides:

	Whoever
  shall unlawfully seize, confine, inveigle, decoy, kidnap, abduct or carry away
  any other person by any means whatsoever without authority of law, except when
  a minor is seized or taken by his parent, is guilty of a felony and, upon
  conviction, must be imprisoned for a period not to exceed thirty years unless
  sentenced for murder as provided in Section 16-3-20.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-3-910 (2003). 
[7]Â Â  Section 24-13-430 provides in relevant part:

	Any
  inmate of the Department of Corrections, city or county jail, or public works
  of any county that participates in a riot or any other acts or violence shall
  be deemed guilty of a felony and upon conviction shall be imprisoned for not
  less than five years nor more than ten years.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  24-13-430(2) (2007).

title: In the Matter of County Magistrate Patrick D. Sullivan
description: In this judicial disciplinary case, respondent Magistrate Judge Patrick Sullivan admits altering a court order and a letter from the Commission on Continuing Legal Education and Specialization.  The record supports the recommendation of the Commission on Judicial Conduct, and we retroactively suspend respondent.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court
In the Matter of County Magistrate Patrick D. Sullivan, Respondent.

Opinion No. 26677
Heard May 27, 2009 - Filed June 29, 2009
DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Senior
  Assistant Attorney General James G. Bogle, Jr., of Columbia, for Office of
  Disciplinary Counsel.
				Gregory
  Poole Harris, of Harris & Gasser, of Columbia, and Sherri A. Lydon, of Law
  Offices of Sherri A. Lydon, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  In this judicial
  disciplinary case, respondent Magistrate Judge Patrick Sullivan admits altering
  a court order and a letter from the Commission on Continuing Legal Education
  and Specialization (hereinafter â€œCLE Commissionâ€).Â  The record supports the recommendation
  of the Commission on Judicial Conduct (hereinafter â€œthe panelâ€), and we
  retroactively suspend respondent.
I.
Respondent failed
  to comply with Rule 510, SCACR and report his CLE hours for 2006-07 timely.Â  Therefore,
  this Court suspended respondent.Â  Subsequently, respondent complied with Rule
  510.Â  Thus, the CLE Commission issued respondent a letter finding him in
  compliance and instructing him to contact this Court to be reinstated.Â  This
  Court then reinstated respondent by court order, and the court order
  specifically stated the reinstatement was not retroactive.
Respondent then
  retook the bench.Â  While conducting bond court, respondent was asked to submit
  evidence of his reinstatement to the county administrator.Â  Respondent faxed
  copies of the CLE Commissionâ€™s letter finding him in compliance and this
  Courtâ€™s order reinstating respondent.Â  The version of the letter and this
  Courtâ€™s order sent by respondent were altered.Â  Specifically, respondent
  removed the references that his reinstatement was not retroactive.Â  Respondent
  explains the alterations of these documents as an innocent attempt to obscure
  notes he made on the documents as he did not have time to obtain the originals.Â 
  Respondent admits he failed to notify the county administrator of the papersâ€™
  alterations.
This
  Court placed respondent on interim suspension on October 12, 2007, due to this
  matter.Â  The panel reviewed this case, heard testimony, and recommended retroactive
  suspension for a period not to exceed respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  Neither
  the Office of Disciplinary Council (ODC) nor respondent filed any exceptions to
  the panelâ€™s report.
II.
ODC concedes it
  found no evidence respondent acted with fraudulent intent.Â  However, as the
  panel found, regardless of motive, respondent deleted material information from
  an order from this Court and a letter from the CLE Commission.Â  We find, as the
  panel did, respondent committed misconduct as defined by Rule 7(a), Rules for Judicial
    Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  Specifically, respondent
  violated the following judicial cannons contained in the Code of Judicial
  Conduct in Rule 501, SCACR: Cannon 1 and 1A in
  failing to uphold the integrity of the judiciary and maintain a high standard
  of conduct; Cannon 2 and 2A in
  failing to avoid impropriety or the appearance of impropriety and act in a
  manner promoting public confidence in the judiciary; and Cannon 3B(2) in
  failing to be faithful to the law.

III.
We hold a
  suspension is a warranted sanction in this case under Rule 7(b), Rules for Judicial
  Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  Respondent has been on interim
  suspension since October 12, 2007.Â  We find this time period sufficient.Â  Thus,
  respondentâ€™s suspension is retroactively applied to October 12, 2007, and respondentâ€™s
  suspension is dissolved as of the filing of this opinion.Â  Lastly, under Rule
  7(b), Rules of Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR, respondent
  shall pay the costs associated with the disciplinary proceeding within ninety
  days of the date of the filing of this opinion.Â  Failure to pay the costs may
  result in the imposition of civil or criminal contempt by this Court.
DEFINITE
  SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Craig S. Rolen, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Greenville County
James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26678
Submitted December 4, 2008 - Filed June
  29, 2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Deputy
  Chief Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Karen
  Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Petitioner Craig Rolen
  pled guilty to voluntary manslaughter and was sentenced to twenty-five years
  imprisonment.Â  Petitioner filed an application for post-conviction relief (PCR)
  alleging that counsel was ineffective for failing to move to withdraw his
  guilty plea.Â  The PCR court denied relief.Â  This Court granted a writ of
  certiorari to review that decision. 
Factual/Procedural
  Background
On October 4, 2001, Kedrick Mahonâ€™s (Victim)
  decomposed body was found in Petitionerâ€™s car at the bottom of a ravine.Â 
  Petitioner was arrested for Victimâ€™s murder on July 16, 2003.[1]Â 
  In September 2004, Petitioner contacted police and confessed to the murder and
  was subsequently charged.
Petitioner
  requested a trial and a jury was selected.Â  However, immediately before trial,
  Petitioner decided to plead guilty.Â  At the plea hearing, the solicitor told
  the plea judge that Petitioner confessed to stabbing the victim and driving the
  car into the ravine.Â  Petitioner told the plea judge that he voluntarily made
  the confession and admitted to committing the murder.Â  The plea judge formally accepted
  Petitionerâ€™s plea as voluntary and having a substantial factual basis.Â  After
  members of Victimâ€™s family addressed the court, Petitioner suddenly exclaimed: 

	All
  right, this has went on far enough, I didnâ€™t kill this man.Â  This has went too
  far, I ainâ€™t doing this.Â  I didnâ€™t kill your brother . . . I didnâ€™t kill this
  man, I canâ€™t do this . . . I donâ€™t know who did, I wish I did . . . I swear to
  God I didnâ€™t do it . . .Â  Should have never pled guilty, I didnâ€™t do this.

Counsel did not move to
  withdraw the plea, and the plea judge sentenced Petitioner to twenty-five years
  imprisonment.Â  
At
  the PCR hearing, Petitioner testified that the State previously offered him a
  deal to plead guilty to accessory after the fact to murder with a ten-year cap,
  but he turned down the offer because he was innocent.Â  He testified he was
  depressed, suicidal, and heavily medicated at the time he gave his confession
  to police and that he confessed in hopes of receiving the death penalty.Â 
  Petitioner stated that he pled guilty because counsel told him that the jury
  that had been impaneled would likely find him guilty.Â  Finally, Petitioner
  testified that counsel did not inform him of his right to appeal his guilty
  plea.
Counsel
  testified that he requested a competency test for Petitioner because he was
  concerned about Petitionerâ€™s mental state and that Petitioner attempted to
  commit suicide following the test.[2]Â 
  Counsel stated that he did not move to withdraw the plea because he believed
  once the plea was accepted, it was final and could not be withdrawn.Â  Counsel
  testified that he did not recall whether he discussed Petitionerâ€™s appellate
  rights with him.Â  
The
  PCR court found that counsel was not ineffective for failing to move to withdraw
  Petitionerâ€™s guilty plea.Â  The PCR court also found that counsel informed
  Petitioner of his right to appeal, but regardless, counsel was under no
  obligation to advise Petitioner of his right to appeal.Â  Accordingly, the PCR
  court denied Petitioner relief.
This Court granted
  Petitionerâ€™s request for a writ of certiorari, and Petitioner presents the
  following issues for review:

	
		
			I.    
			Did the PCR court err in ruling
  that counsel was not ineffective for failing to move to withdraw Petitionerâ€™s
  guilty plea?
 
		
		
			II.    
			Did the PCR court err in ruling Petitioner
  was not entitled to a belated direct appeal?
		
	

Standard of Review
The burden of proof is on the applicant in post-conviction
  proceedings to prove the allegations in his application.Â  Butler v. State, 286
  S.C. 441, 442, 334 S.E.2d 813, 814 (1985).Â  On appeal, the PCR courtâ€™s ruling should be upheld if it
  is supported by any evidence of probative value in the record.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119,
  386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989).
Law/Analysis
I. Withdrawal of Guilty Plea
Petitioner argues that the
  PCR court erred in ruling that counsel was not ineffective for failing to move
  to withdraw Petitionerâ€™s guilty plea.Â  We agree.
In
  order for a defendant to knowingly and voluntarily plead guilty, he must have a
  full understanding of the consequences of his plea. Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238, 241 (1969).Â  A defendant who enters a plea on the advice of
  counsel may only attack the voluntary and intelligent character of a plea by
  showing that counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective standard of
  reasonableness and that there is a reasonable probability that, but for
  counselâ€™s errors, the defendant would not have pled guilty, but would have
  insisted on going to trial. Â Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52 (1985).Â  When determining issues relating to guilty pleas, the Court
  will consider the entire record, including the transcript of the guilty plea,
  and the evidence presented at the PCR hearing.Â  Anderson v. State, 342
  S.C. 54, 57, 535 S.E.2d 649, 657 (2000).Â  
We find that counsel was deficient in failing to move to withdraw
  Petitionerâ€™s guilty plea.Â  Petitioner requested a jury trial and only decided
  to plead guilty after counsel advised him that the impaneled jury would likely
  find him guilty.Â  Petitioner repeatedly asserted his innocence during the plea
  hearing before the plea judge sentenced him.Â  In our view, at this point in the
  hearing, it was clear that Petitioner wanted to withdraw his guilty plea.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  
While
  counsel was deficient in failing to move to withdraw Petitionerâ€™s guilty plea,
  we must determine whether Petitioner was prejudiced by counselâ€™s performance.Â  The
  plea judge had formally accepted the guilty plea prior to Petitionerâ€™s
  protestation of his innocence.Â  Therefore, even if counsel had
  moved to withdraw the guilty plea, the plea judge may have denied this request,
  and Petitioner could not have proceeded to trial.Â  See State v. Riddle, 278
  S.C. 148, 150, 292 S.E.2d 795, 796 (1982) (holding that the withdrawal of a guilty plea is
  generally within the sound discretion of the trial court).Â  In this way, the prejudice analysis
  in this case does not fit squarely within the traditional guilty plea prejudice
  framework as set forth in Hill.Â  Nonetheless, we hold that
  Petitioner was prejudiced by counselâ€™s deficient performance because due
  to counselâ€™s failure to make such a motion, the plea judge was not able to
  exercise his discretion.Â  Even if the plea judge had denied Petitionerâ€™s motion
  to withdraw his plea, Petitioner could have raised this issue on direct appeal.Â 
  Moreover, Petitioner proved he would have insisted on going to trial had the
  plea judge granted the motion to withdraw.Â  
Accordingly,
  we hold that counsel was ineffective for failing to move to withdraw
  Petitionerâ€™s guilty plea.Â  However, we find that granting Petitioner the relief
  of an entire new plea hearing is inappropriate.Â  Once the plea judge found that
  Petitionerâ€™s plea was voluntary and supported by a factual basis and formally
  accepted the plea of guilt, Petitioner forfeited his ability to withdraw the
  plea as a matter of right.Â  State v. Bickham, Op. No. 26581 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Jan. 12, 2009) (Shearouse Adv.Sh. No.2 at 43) (Kittredge, J., concurring).Â  Accordingly,
  we remand the case to the point in the guilty plea proceeding in which counsel
  should have sought to withdraw the plea.Â  Â Â In our view, this tailored relief
  remedies the precise prejudice resulting from plea counselâ€™s deficient
  performance.[3]Â  See United States v. Morrison, 449 U.S. 361, 364 (1981) (recognizing that the remedy for a violation of the Sixth Amendment right to counsel
  â€œshould be tailored to the injury suffered from the constitutional violation and should not unnecessarily infringe on competing interestsâ€).Â  Â 
II. Belated Direct Appeal
Petitioner
  argues that the PCR court erred in
  ruling he was not entitled to a belated direct appeal.Â  We decline to address
  this issue.Â  
Absent extraordinary circumstances, there is no constitutional
  requirement that a defendant be informed of the right to a direct appeal from a
  guilty plea, and the bare assertion that a defendant was not advised of
  appellate rights is insufficient to grant relief.Â  Weathers v.
    State, 319 S.C. 59, 61, 459 S.E.2d 838,
  839 (1995).Â  Instead, there must be
  proof that extraordinary circumstances exist, such as where a defendant
  inquires about an appeal, in order for counsel to be required to advise a
  defendant of the right to appeal.Â  Id.Â  
We
  decline to rule on whether the PCR court erred in finding that Petitioner was
  not entitled to a belated direct appeal.Â  Had Petitioner filed a direct appeal,
  any issues regarding withdrawal of the guilty plea would not have been
  preserved for the appellate courtâ€™s review because counsel never made such a
  motion.Â  Additionally, as stated above, we hold that counsel was ineffective
  for failing to make a motion to withdraw, and thus, the most appropriate relief
  is a new plea hearing.Â  Because we find that a belated direct appeal would not
  afford Petitioner suitable relief, a ruling from the Court on this matter would
  have no practical effect.Â  See Seabrook
    v. Knox, 369
  S.C. 191, 197, 631 S.E.2d 907, 910 (2006)
  (recognizing that this Court will not decide
  questions in which a judgment rendered will have no practical legal effect).Â  

  Conclusion
For the foregoing
  reasons, we reverse the PCR courtâ€™s order denying relief and remand the case to
  the point after formal acceptance of the guilty plea.Â  If the plea court grants
  the motion to withdraw the plea, the case shall be placed on the trial docket
  and proceed in the usual manner; if the court denies the motion to withdraw the
  plea, the prior sentence will stand, and Petitioner may pursue his right to a
  direct appeal.Â Â Â Â  
WALLER, BEATTY
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  We granted certiorari to
  review a post-conviction relief (PCR) order denying petitionerâ€™s claim that his
  trial counsel was ineffective in failing to move to withdraw petitionerâ€™s
  plea.Â  Since the question of â€œineffectivenessâ€ embraces both deficient
  performance and prejudice, we err if we decline to make a finding on both
  prongs.Â  I would find no prejudice, and affirm.
Where an applicant
  claims his guilty plea counsel was ineffective, that applicant bears the burden
  of showing both that counselâ€™s performance was deficient and that the deficient
  performance resulted in prejudice, that is, it affected the outcome of the plea
  process.Â  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52 (1985).Â  Ordinarily â€œprejudiceâ€
  is established by evidence that had counsel not been deficient, there is a
  reasonable probability that the applicant would not have pled guilty but would
  instead have insisted on going to trial.[4]Â  Id.Â  As the Hill Court recognized, a determination of prejudice
  in this context will depend on the likelihood that had counsel done that which
  the applicant asserts he should have, counselâ€™s act would have been successful,
  i.e., had counsel investigated, he would have found evidence causing him to
  change his advice to plead guilty.Â  The Court acknowledged that in judging
  prejudice, it was necessary to make objective â€œpredictions of the outcome at a
  possible trial.â€Â  Id. at 59-60.
Speculation is a
  necessary component of most PCR cases since prejudice is judged by the
  â€œreasonable probabilityâ€ standard: would the jury have acquitted had it not
  heard the improper evidence?Â  Would the trial judge have suppressed the
  evidence had a suppression motion been made?Â  Where, as here, counselâ€™s
  deficiency is the failure to request some form of relief committed to the trial
  judgeâ€™s discretion, the PCR applicant establishes prejudice by demonstrating
  that had the request been made, it would have been an abuse of discretion to
  have denied it.Â  E.g., Wolfe v. State, 326 S.C. 158, 485 S.E.2d
  367 (1997) (continuance).
Here, the majority
  holds counsel was deficient in failing to make a motion to withdraw
  petitionerâ€™s plea.Â  It acknowledges that whether to grant such a request lies
  in the plea judgeâ€™s discretion.Â  The Court then declines to decide whether
  petitioner has shown the requisite prejudice - i.e., whether it would have been
  an abuse of discretion to have denied the motion if made.Â  Instead, the
  majority appears to create a new standard of prejudice: counsel renders
  ineffective assistance when she neglects to preserve an issue, whether or not
  that issue has merit, for direct appeal.Â  Under this standard, the remedy is
  not a new proceeding, but instead a rewind,[5] returning all characters to the point in the guilty plea when petitioner
  maintains the motion to withdraw should have been made.Â  Among the unanswered
  questions raised by this extraordinary remedy,[6] is whether, henceforth, a PCR judge who finds deficient performance will be
  able to avoid the prejudice issue by remanding the matter to criminal court.
The majority goes
  on to hold that if the motion is made and then denied, petitioner may appeal
  from this ruling made in the new proceeding.Â  While ordinarily the State would
  not be able to appeal the granting of a motion to withdraw a guilty plea made
  in the plea proceeding, I question whether such an appeal would lie from a
  ruling on remand. 
On the merits, I
  agree that counsel was deficient when she failed to move to withdraw
  petitionerâ€™s guilty plea.Â  I do not find the requisite prejudice, however,
  since I do not find a reasonable probability that had such a motion been made
  it would have been granted.Â  First, had the plea judge believed the integrity
  of the plea was in question, he should have sua sponte refused to
  continue.Â  In my view, it is more likely that he viewed petitionerâ€™s outburst
  as unfortunate but not unusual.Â  Since I find no prejudice from counselâ€™s
  deficient performance, I would affirm the order denying petitionerâ€™s PCR
  application.


[1] Petitioner testified at the PCR hearing that after he was arrested on the
  murder charges, he was released on bond and placed on house arrest.
[2] Petitioner was found competent to stand trial.
[3] We disagree with the dissentâ€™s assertion that we are creating a new standard of
  prejudice or that this tailored relief is an extraordinary remedy.Â  Rather, we
  have merely provided a remedy for what we find, under the specific facts of
  this case, to be ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  See Morrison, at
  365 (noting that the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s â€œapproach has thus been to
  identify and then neutralize the taint by tailoring relief appropriate in the
  circumstances to assure the defendant the effective assistance of counselâ€); see
    also Davie v. State (holding plea counsel was ineffective for failing
  to communicate a plea offer and crafting specific relief to remedy the
  violation).
[4] A different prejudice analysis is appropriate where, for example, the
  ineffective assistance claim is that plea counsel failed to communicate a plea
  offer.Â  Davie v. State, 381 S.C. 601, 675 S.E.2d 416 (2009).Â  
[5] Although characterized as a remand, such a remand is not possible since the
  matter before us is a civil action brought in the Court of Common Pleas, and
  the â€œremandâ€ would be to a long-concluded proceeding in the Court of General
  Sessions.
[6] While the United States Supreme Court has held that in a direct appeal raising
  a claim of a 6th amendment violationÂ  the relief must be tailored
  based upon the violation, the Court still required the defendant demonstrate prejudice
  in order to receive relief in her criminal proceeding.Â  United States v. Morrison, 449 U.S. 361, 366-367.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Andre Kevin
          Rosemond, Petitioner,
        v.
        William D.
          Catoe, Commissioner, South Carolina Department of Corrections and Charles M.
          Condon, South Carolina Attorney General, Respondents.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Spartanburg County
Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â 26679
Heard April 22, 2009 - Filed June 29, 2009 

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        David I. Bruck and Robert E Lominack, both of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy
          Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J.
          Zelenka, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  KITTREDGE:Â Â Â Â Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the denial of
  Andre Rosemondâ€™s application for capital
  post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  Rosemond argues the PCR court erred in denying relief
  primarily due to a complete lack of mitigation evidence in the sentencing phase.Â 
  We agree and affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand for a new sentencing
  hearing.
I.
Rosemond was
  convicted of murdering his live-in girlfriend, Christine Norton, and Nortonâ€™s
  ten-year-old daughter.Â  Rosemond confessed to killing Norton and her daughter and cooperated with law enforcement.Â  There is no dispute
  regarding guilt.Â  After a sentencing hearing, the jury recommended a sentence
  of death which the trial court imposed.
This
  Court affirmed Rosemondâ€™s conviction on direct appeal.Â  State v. Rosemond, 335 S.C. 593,
    598, 518 S.E.2d 588, 590 (1999). Â Rosemond then filed a PCR
  application.Â  The PCR court ordered Dr. Pamela Crawford to evaluate Rosemond,
  and Dr. Crawford diagnosed Rosemond with schizophrenia, paranoid type.Â 
  Subsequently, the PCR court stayed the PCR proceedings due to Rosemondâ€™s
  incompetence.Â  Currently, Rosemond remains incompetent.
Despite Rosemondâ€™s incompetency,
  the PCR proceeding continued in response to this Courtâ€™s ruling in Council v. Catoe, 359 S.C. 120,
    129, 597 S.E.2d 782, 787 (2004) (â€œ[W]e hold that a petitioner
  cannot delay his collateral review of his trial proceedings due to his
  incompetency. Â If, at a future date, the petitioner regains his competency and
  discovers that at his original PCR hearing, his incompetency prevented his
  ability to assist his counsel on a fact-based claim of ineffective assistance
  of counsel, he may then raise that claim in a subsequent proceeding.â€).
The PCR court
  denied relief on all grounds and further acknowledged Rosemondâ€™s continued
  incompetency.Â  This Court granted certiorari to review the PCR courtâ€™s denial
  of relief.
II.
Rosemond argues the denial of PCR relief was improper
  for a multitude of reasons.Â  We first address trial
  counselâ€™s opening statement and the alleged ex parte contact as these
  arguments affect the guilt phase as well as the sentencing phase.
A. Opening Statement
Rosemond
  alleges the PCR court erred in finding no prejudice resulted from inappropriate
  comments in counselâ€™s opening statement.Â  We disagree.
During
  trial counselâ€™s opening statement, counsel told the jury that some of the jury
  members were selected because they â€œwere whatever was left.â€Â  At the PCR
  hearing, trial counsel acknowledged the comments were inappropriate and explained
  the statements were made out of frustration over the racial composition of the
  jury.Â  Counselâ€™s remarks constituted deficient representation.Â  Therefore, we
  transition to the second prong of the Strickland test to
  determine whether prejudice occurred.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668,
    687 (1984).Â  No prejudice occurred in
  the guilt phase as the State presented overwhelming evidence of guilt:
  Rosemondâ€™s confession and the murder weapon, which Rosemond helped the police
  locate.Â  Further, in his confession, Rosemond admitted to planning the murder
  of his girlfriend.
Similarly,
  Rosemond was not prejudiced by trial counselâ€™s opening statement during the
  sentencing phase of his trial.Â  First, the opening argument was made on March
  23, 1996, and the jury made its sentencing recommendation on March 30, 1996.Â 
  Additionally, following the sentencing phase, the jury deliberated
  approximately eleven hours over two days before recommending a sentence of
  death.Â  Significantly, the jury notified the trial court of its difficulty
  reaching a decision, which resulted in an Allen charge.Â  It is apparent the jury
  discharged its duties in good faith and did not penalize Rosemond for his counselâ€™s
  improper comments at the beginning of the guilt phase.Â  Rosemond suffered no
  prejudice.Â  We find evidence supports the PCR courtâ€™s determination that
  Rosemond is not entitled to relief on this ground.
B. Ex Parte Communication
Rosemond
  next argues he is entitled to PCR because the Solicitor â€œchoseâ€ the judge to
  preside over Rosemondâ€™s trial and met with the judge to confirm his willingness
  to serve.Â  We disagree.Â  Former Chief Justice Finney assigned the trial judge
  to this case in February 1996.[1]Â 
  We reviewed the record and find the able trial judge presided over this case in
  a fair and impartial manner.
III.
Next, Rosemond
  argues the PCR court erred in denying relief due to the complete lack of mitigation
  evidence in the sentencing phase.Â  We agree.
During the PCR hearing, trial counsel testified he did not present
  evidence of Rosemondâ€™s alleged mental illness as a mitigating factor because
  the trial court found Rosemond competent to stand trial.Â  Trial counsel mistakenly
  believed the ruling precluded him from presenting Rosemondâ€™s mental health
  mitigation evidence in the sentencing phase.Â  Counselâ€™s erroneous belief
  clearly constituted deficient representation.Â  We turn to the prejudice prong
  of Strickland.
When
  determining if want of mitigation evidence resulted in prejudice, we must
  determine whether the â€œmitigating
  evidence, taken as a whole, â€˜might well have influenced the juryâ€™s appraisalâ€™
  of [the defendantâ€™s] culpability.â€Â  Wiggins v. Smith, 539 U.S. 510,
    538 (2003) (quoting Williams v. Taylor, 529 U.S. 362, 398 (2000)); see also Rompilla v. Beard, 545 U.S. 374, 393 (2005).Â  In this
  regard, the United States Supreme Court held, â€œthe likelihood of a different
  result if the [mitigation] evidence had gone in is â€˜sufficient to undermine
  confidence in the outcomeâ€™ actually reached at sentencing.â€Â  Rompilla, 545 U.S. at
    393 (quoting Strickland, 466 U.S. at
      694).Â  Accordingly, if trial counselâ€™s complete failure to
  present mitigation evidence undermines confidence in the outcome, then Rosemond
  suffered prejudice.
We find
  this case analogous to our recent holding in Council v. State, 380 S.C. 159,
    181, 670 S.E.2d 356, 368 (2008), in which this Court upheld the PCR courtâ€™s grant of a new sentencing
  trial.Â  In Council, only very
  limited mitigation testimony was presented and no medical evidence was
  presented.Â  Id. at 177, 670 S.E.2d at 365.Â 
  Thus, this Court held, â€œthere was very strong mitigating evidence to be weighed
  against the [six] aggravating circumstances presented by the State.Â  We
  believe, as did the PCR judge, this evidence may well have influenced the
  juryâ€™s assessment of [Councilâ€™s] culpability.â€Â  Id. at 176, 670 S.E.2d
  at 365.Â  Similarly, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
  concluded, â€œâ€˜had the jury been able to place [mental disturbance] on the
  mitigating side of the scale, there is a reasonable probability that at least
  one juror would have struck a different balance.â€™â€Â  Gray v. Branker, 529
  F.3d 220, 238 (4th Cir. 2008) (quoting Wiggins, 539 U.S. at 537).
In the case before us, we need not speculate about the mitigation evidence
  known by trial counsel as the evidence was presented during pretrial competency
  hearings.Â  At one competency hearing,[2] Dr. Harold Morgan testified Rosemond was â€œclearly paranoid.â€Â  Dr. Morgan
  described Rosemondâ€™s behavior during the interview as â€œvery evasive from the
  beginning, very guarded, very distant, very aloof, sort of exuding tension and
  fear and hostility.â€Â  Rosemond eventually terminated the interview with Dr.
  Morgan.
At the
  same competency hearing, Dr. Shea testified he learned Rosemondâ€™s brother was a
  paranoid schizophrenic and Rosemond scored an 84 on his I.Q. test, which is in the
  low average range.Â  Dr. Shea, after many tests and interviews, testified,
  â€œ[i]tâ€™s my belief that Mr. Rosemond has some sort of a paranoid process going
  on.Â  Iâ€™m having a very difficult time making an exact diagnosis, because, quite
  frankly, he wonâ€™t -- he wonâ€™t discuss things with me to the extent that I need
  to make an accurate diagnosis.â€Â  Dr. Shea described Rosemondâ€™s behavior as
  â€œeven more oddâ€ and progressively worsening.Â  Dr. Sheaâ€™s working diagnosis of
  Rosemond was he suffered from a delusional disorder or schizophrenia.
In a
  subsequent competency hearing, Dr. Schwartz-Watts of the Department of Mental Health
  testified she, Dr. Donald Morgan, and Dr. Geoffrey McKee evaluated Rosemond,
  and Dr. Schwartz-Watts believed him competent to stand trial.Â  Dr. Shea agreed
  at this second competency hearing that Rosemond was competent to stand trial
  but reiterated Rosemond suffers from paranoia.
During
  the PCR hearing, Dr. Shea testified about a conversation with Dr.
  Schwartz-Watts, in which Dr. Schwartz-Watts stated Rosemond may have pulled
  himself together to appear competent.Â  Further, according to Dr. Shea, Dr. Schwartz-Watts
  believed Rosemond may have been exhibiting the early stages of schizophrenia.Â 
  Dr. Schwartz-Watts agreed to testify to her belief, and Dr. Shea passed this
  information on to trial counsel.
Evidence
  of Rosemondâ€™s purported mental illness was, therefore, available for the
  sentencing phase.Â  However, trial counsel only called five witnesses, none of
  whom made any reference to Rosemondâ€™s mental health issues: Rosemondâ€™s father,
  Rosemondâ€™s pastor, two family friends, and Dr. Shea.
Rosemondâ€™s father testified Rosemond was a â€œgood
  boy.â€Â  Rosemondâ€™s pastor stated Rosemond belongs to a â€œwholesome, functional
  family.â€Â  The family friends described Rosemond as obedient, intelligent, and
  respected and asked the jury to have mercy.Â  Lastly, Dr. Shea testified in a
  conclusory manner that Rosemond could adjust to prison.Â  On cross-examination,
  Dr. Shea agreed he had not diagnosed Rosemond with a mental illness.Â  In sum, no evidence was presented to the jury
  concerning Rosemondâ€™s troubling mental health issues.Â  In fact, the theme of
  the evidence was the absence of any mental health concerns, for the evidence
consistently portrayed Rosemond as a â€œgood boy.â€
Rosemondâ€™s
  competence to stand trial in no manner precluded his counsel from presenting
  the mental illness information that was known.Â  As no evidence of Rosemondâ€™s known
  mental health issues was presented, we reject the Stateâ€™s efforts to portray
  Rosemondâ€™s position as merely wanting to present a â€œfancier mitigationâ€ case.Â  Jones
    v. State, 332 S.C. 329, 339, 504 S.E.2d 822, 827 (1998) (affirming the
  denial of PCR finding Jones merely sought
  a â€œfancierâ€ presentation of mitigation evidence).
Given
  the juryâ€™s struggle during the sentencing phase and the want of any mental
  health mitigation evidence, we hold the known evidence of Rosemondâ€™s mental
  health issues â€œâ€˜might well have influenced the juryâ€™s appraisalâ€™ of
  culpability.â€Â  Rompilla, 545 U.S. at
    393.Â  As a result, Rosemond was prejudiced, as we find
  confidence in the outcome is substantially undermined.Â  Thus, we reverse the
  denial of PCR on this issue and remand the case for a new sentencing hearing.
IV.
In
  light of Rosemondâ€™s entitlement to a new sentencing hearing, we need not
  address the remaining assignment of errors concerning the sentencing phase.Â  Hughes v. State, 367 S.C. 389, 409, 626 S.E.2d 805, 815 (2006) (holding appellate
  court need not reach remaining issues when addressed issues are dispositive).Â  We nevertheless elect to address Rosemondâ€™s challenge to trial
  counselâ€™s failure to object to the trial court instructing the jury not to recommend
  a sentence of life based on mercy: â€œyou may recommend
  a sentence of life imprisonment for any reason or for no reason at all other
    than as an act of mercy.â€ (emphasis added).Â  We agree with Rosemond and hold that if a plea for mercy is admitted in evidence, then a jury should be
  entitled to consider it.
In State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45,
  51, 406 S.E.2d 315, 318-19 (1991), this Court held a defendant
  may present witnesses to ask for mercy in the sentencing phase.Â  Further, our
  case law requires a trial court to instruct a jury it may impose a life
  sentence even if it finds a statutory aggravating circumstance.Â  State v.
    Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 218-19, 499 S.E.2d 209, 215 (1998).
During
  the sentencing phase, the testimony of two family friends was properly admitted
  and these witnesses asked the jury for mercy.Â  In contrast, the trial court
  then instructed the jury to discount such pleas by instructing the jury that it
  could not recommend a life sentence based on the evidence of mercy.Â  Notably, the
  trial courtâ€™s jury instruction mirrored the instruction found proper subsequent
  to Rosemondâ€™s trial in State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 459, 529 S.E.2d 721,
  731 (2000).Â  We overrule Hughey to the extent it approved and sanctioned
  the charge given here.
It
  is proper to instruct a jury in a capital sentencing phase that it may
  recommend a life sentence for any reason or no reason at all, including as an
  act of mercy.Â  A juryâ€™s consideration of mercy, if proper evidence of mercy is
  admitted, is well recognized in the sentencing phase of a capital case.Â  Because
  a capital jury may consider properly admitted evidence of mercy in the
  sentencing phase, consideration of mercy is not inconsistent with the instruction
  that â€œthe jury should not be guided by sympathy, prejudice, passion, or public
  opinion . . . .â€Â  State v. Singleton, 284 S.C. 388, 393, 326 S.E.2d 153,
  156 (1985) overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45,
  69 n.5, 406 S.E.2d 315, 328 n.5 (1991).
V.
Due to the
  overwhelming evidence of guilt and want of prejudice, we affirm the PCR courtâ€™s
  denial of relief regarding the assignment of errors related to the guilt phase
  of Rosemondâ€™s trial.Â  We reverse the PCR court and hold Rosemond established
  his entitlement to a new sentencing hearing as a result of trial counselâ€™s
  failure to present any mental health mitigation evidence in the sentencing
  phase. Â We remand the case for a new sentencing hearing.[3] Â We overrule State v. Hughey to the extent it approved the
  instruction that precluded a capital juryâ€™s consideration of mercy evidence in
  the sentencing phase.
AFFIRMED IN
  PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.


[1] We
  acknowledge the practice of the prosecutor selecting the trial judge is
  inappropriate and troubling.Â  We further note this alleged practice is no
  longer possible, as the Chief Justice of the South Carolina Supreme Court makes
  judicial assignments in death penalty cases in conjunction with Court
Administration.
[2] A
competency hearing is, of course, conducted outside the presence of the jury.
[3] As noted, Rosemond is currently not competent.Â 
  A new sentencing hearing is contingent on Rosemond regaining competency.

description: In this case, the Court affirms the master-in-equityâ€™s decision and holds that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 5-31-640 (2004) is unconstitutional and that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 5-31-620 (2004) is also unconstitutional because it is so inextricably intertwined with Â§ 5-31-640, and thus, in the absence of these provisions, various provisions of the Home Rule Act give the municipality the authority the sell the municipal water and sewer system.
